HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Appeals Court Reverses $145 Billion Tobacco Ruling
A Florida appeals court threw out a landmark $145 billion punitive damage award against the nation's cigarette makers, saying the case should never have gone forward as a class-action lawsuit but as separate claims brought by individuals.
 The reversal buoyed the industry's financial outlook and sent the stock prices of cigarette makers higher, including the Altria Group, parent of Philip Morris, which was a defendant. Page A20. 

The World Health Assembly adopted the first treaty ever devoted entirely to health, one intended to discourage cigarette smoking and to reduce the estimated five million deaths it causes every year. A11.

Riskier Drug Type Steered Abroad
A division of Bayer sold millions of dollars of blood-clotting medicine for hemophiliacs -- medicine that carried a high risk of transmitting AIDS -- to Asia and Latin America while selling a new, safer product in the West, records show. A1.

House and Senate Agree on Tax Bill
House and Senate leaders reached an agreement on a bill to reduce taxes by $318 billion over 10 years. The bill should clear Congress before the week is out. The measure would reduce the tax rate on capital gains and dividends to 15 percent for most taxpayers for five years, and then reinstate the higher existing rates in 2008. A1.

Vivendi Lacks Solid Option for a Sale
Vivendi still does not appear to have a single attractive option for selling the United States entertainment assets, despite the entrance of Edgar Bronfman Jr. into the bidding.
Market Place. C6.

More Countries Ban Canadian Beef
Mexico, Japan, Australia and other nations joined the United States in temporarily banning Canadian beef and cattle imports. A8.

Advertisers Carve Out New Segment
An organization has been formed to help raise the profile of the demographic segment it calls "new generation Latinos": second- and older-generation Latinos, from teenagers to those in their 40's, who are bicultural but use mostly English-language media. Advertising. C6.

Stocks Are Mixed in a Tight Range
Wall Street stumbled through an uneven session and closed mixed. The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 25.07 points, or 0.3 percent, at 8,516.43. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 3.69 points, or 0.4 percent, to 923.42. The Nasdaq composite index dipped 1.22 points, or 0.1 percent, to 1,489.87. C9.

Crude oil prices rose 2.2 percent after an Energy Department report showed that inventories last week were lower than a year ago. C9.

Europe Fines Deutsche Telekom
The European Commission fined Deutsche Telekom 12.6 million euros, or $14.7 million, for overcharging competitors for access to its local phone network. "Many new entrants have tried to compete with the incumbent operator," said Mario Monti, left, the European competition commissioner. "None of them has been able to reach a significant market share." World Business, Section W.

The mobile phone network operator mmO2 said it lost $16.7 billion in the fiscal year ended March 31. World Business, Section W.

Stake in DHL Airways Is Sold
The chief executive of DHL Airways and two investors agreed to buy all shares held by Deutsche Post and another investor for $57 million in a move that may end claims that the German company controls DHL. C4.

Demon Deflation: Not Here, Now
Yes, deflation can do real economic damage, with cutbacks spawning more cutbacks. But it won't happen here. Not with a falling dollar and a rising deficit. Virginia Postrel:
Economic Scene. C2.

HEADLINE: AFTEREFFECTS: WARNINGS; 
New Tape, Linked To bin Laden Aide, Urges More Attacks

BYLINE:  By NEIL MacFARQUHAR and DON VAN NATTA Jr. 

DATELINE: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, May 21 

 BODY:
An Arab television network broadcast an audiotape today said to have been recorded by Dr. Ayman al-Zawahiri, the second most powerful figure in Al Qaeda after Osama bin Laden. It called on Muslims to attack Western interests with the same ferocity as the Sept. 11 assaults and derided Arab governments that aided the war on Iraq, even as they claimed to oppose it.
 "Learn the lesson from your 19 brethren who attacked America with their planes, in New York and Washington, wreaking on it unprecedented havoc from which it is still reeling," said one segment of the tape, which was played on Al Jazeera. 
 The sudden appearance of a Qaeda recording, after suicide attacks here and in Morocco attributed to the group, heightened already elevated security concerns about the threat of a terrorist attack. 
As with previous recordings from Qaeda leaders, intelligence analysts warned that it might contain a coded signal to sleeper cells to begin a new wave of attacks. Senior American and Saudi officials have been warning this week that global intelligence monitoring indicated that another attack was "imminent." 
Those concerns were in evidence on Tuesday, when officials from the United States, Britain and Germany announced plans to close their embassies in Saudi Arabia temporarily, while the Bush administration said it was raising the nation's color-coded threat alert to orange, its second-highest level.
Fears of an attack here were compounded by contradictory reports about three Moroccan men arrested Monday at the Jidda airport. The authorities said they suspected the men were Qaeda members preparing to hijack a jet and crash it into a landmark in the kingdom.
Both Saudi and American officials confirmed the account, but late in the day it was called "baseless" by Prince Nayef bin Abdel Aziz, Saudi Arabia's interior minister renowned for discouraging public pronouncements about any security matters. 
"The fact is that two Moroccan people were arrested and they were wanted for previous security issues," the Saudi Press Agency quoted the minister as saying. 
Concern about an attack prompted a flurry of increased security measures in Riyadh. Highways were snarled by traffic backed up behind frequent checkpoints, numerous expatriate schools and diplomatic missions were temporarily closed, and concrete obstacle courses were implanted in front of major hotels. 
Western residential compounds were locked down. Suicide bombers attacked three such residential compounds last week, killing 25 residents and guards.
A senior Saudi official said earlier this week that at least one Qaeda cell remained active in the kingdom and that another had dispersed with its members heading to Europe or North America.
The tape thought to be made by Dr. Zawahiri, an Egyptian physician and intellectual force behind Al Qaeda, made no specific references to events that would indicate when it was recorded. It seemed to have been made right around the beginning of the war against Iraq, as the speaker did mention demonstrations and conferences against the war. 
But he did not mention the fall of Baghdad or last week's terrorist attacks. One theme of the tape was to encourage Iraq to develop an Islamic opposition to the American presence.
In Washington, a senior American counterterrorism official said the tape "needs to be authenticated," and that analysts were struck by the fact that there were no time elements on the tape to indicate when it was made.
The official also noted that often in the past, taped messages from Mr. bin Laden were followed by terrorist strikes. 
At a minimum, analysts consider the tape an attempt by Al Qaeda to emphasize that it is still a force to be reckoned with, despite pronouncements by the American administration that its campaign against terrorism was succeeding. 
Dr. Zawahiri, like Mr. bin Laden, has eluded capture despite a $25million bounty on his head. Western intelligence officials believe he may be hiding in Pakistan, along the border with Afghanistan. 
"The only thing that will do you any good is to carry weapons and attack your enemies, Americans and Jews," the speaker on the tape said. "The Crusaders and Jews understand only the language of killing and blood. They can only be persuaded through returning coffins, devastated interests, burning towers and collapsed economies."
Some words on the poorly recorded message were difficult to understand. A spokesman for Al Jazeera, a satellite network based in Qatar, said it received an 11-minute tape on Tuesday. He would not specify how, but added that the producers found only about three minutes that were worthy of broadcasting. 
The tape urged Muslims to attack Western embassies and companies. 
"Kick those criminals from your lands and do not allow the Americans, British, Australian and Norwegians and other crusades, killers of your brothers in Iraq, to live in our countries, enjoying its prosperous resources and spreading corruption," it said.

HEADLINE: Edwards Makes Rural Voters A Focus of His '04 Campaign 

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21 

 BODY:
Senator John Edwards of North Carolina said today that the Democratic Party and President Bush had failed to address the needs of rural Americans and that he would make an appeal to such voters a central part of his campaign for president.
 Mr. Edwards, one of nine Democrats running for president, offered several proposals intended to help rural Americans, whom he described as struggling even more than urban dwellers with a bad economy. They included providing financial aid and tax credits to encourage development in rural areas, increasing salaries for teachers in rural areas and guaranteeing the installation of broadband Internet service in every rural community in the country. 
 He described his views in a speech in Nevada, Iowa, and in telephone interviews with reporters in Washington.
"Too many Democrats too often act like rural America is just someplace to fly over between a fund-raiser in Manhattan and a fund-raiser in Beverly Hills," Mr. Edwards said in his prepared remarks, adding, "Rural America and small-town America are in trouble, and George W. Bush just doesn't get it."
"In small towns and rural communities, our lifestyle and all the values it represents, are under siege," he said. "While the rest of America grapples with an economic downturn, recession has become a permanent way of life for much of rural America."
The speech came as Democratic candidates have been struggling to win attention in a crowded field. Mr. Edwards's aides described it as a centerpiece of his candidacy, and compared it to the proposal Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri made three weeks ago to finance universal health care.
That speech lifted Mr. Gephardt's profile, to the evident consternation of some of his less-noticed rivals.
Mr. Edwards's advisers invested a good amount of attention in seeking the right setting for his own speech: a patch of rural Iowa, a state where, in January, the Democrats will hold their first nominating caucus. Rural voters are likely to prove pivotal in the general election. 
The prepared text for Mr. Edwards's speech that was e-mailed to reporters included stage directions for the senator -- instructing him to "point if you can see" windmills in the distance, as he talked about their potential to generate inexpensive power for farmers.
Mr. Edwards, a successful trial lawyer, painted himself as a product of rural America, in Robbins, N.C., talking about sweeping floors at the mill and working at a mobile home factory. "When I was growing up, Robbins was a textile mill town," he said. "My dad worked in the mills, and he worked his way up to plant supervisor. My mom's last job was in the post office. I was the first member of my family to go to college."
Reflecting a growing argument among Democratic strategists today, Mr. Edwards said in an interview that rural voters would be crucial in the presidential election and suggested that Democrats had ignored them at their peril. "This goes to the heart of what a lot of Democrats think is one of things we need to win a national election," he said. 
"I want my party to return to its roots," he said. "I want the Democratic Party to champion the forgotten America, not just in the metropolitan areas, but also in the small towns that lie between."
Jim Dyke, a spokesman for the Republican National Committee, suggested that Mr. Edwards would have a tough time presenting himself as the candidate of rural America.
"I guess they wrote that speech at John Edwards's Georgetown mansion," Mr. Dyke said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator John Edwards spoke yesterday in Nevada, Iowa. (Jon Britton/The Tribune, via Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Bush and Japan Leader Share Concern Over Deflation 

BYLINE:  By HOWARD W. FRENCH with KEN BELSON 

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 21 

 BODY:
When the Japanese prime minister, Junichiro Koizumi, pays an overnight visit to President Bush on his Texas ranch on Thursday, there will be much friendly talk about Japan's support for American policies from Afghanistan to Iraq and much concern expressed about a nuclear North Korea.
 It is far less clear how frankly the two leaders will discuss another immediate and potentially devastating threat: deflation. 
 Like a spreading virus, a five-year decline in prices has worked its way deep into Japan's economy, ravaging the nation's banks, eroding corporate profits and stripping savers of interest income. 
After years in denial, the government here is finally confronting the crisis but is doing so amid widespread disagreement over the cure and skepticism about whether the deflationary spiral can be broken. 
Three years after the collapse of global stock prices, America too is starting to wrestle with what is potentially the same set of thorny problems. The Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, made that clear when he said recently that deflation, while a distant threat, was of greater concern now than the historic enemy, inflation. 
While Mr. Bush and Mr. Koizumi would have plenty to discuss along those lines, chances are they will avoid the topic altogether. The specter of a wealth-destroying beast like deflation is so frightening and the tools for fighting it so limited, that both men are likely to feign confidence and talk of things they have more control over, like their shared commitment to stopping North Korea from accumulating nuclear weapons. 
"The global economy is in a particularly delicate position, and Japan is in the deepest trouble, but it's difficult to figure out what levers Japan should pull," Kenneth Courtis, vice chairman at Goldman Sachs Asia, said. 
Prices in Japan fell a record 3.5 percent from January to March, suggesting that deflation is accelerating despite efforts by the Bank of Japan, which has already pushed interest rates to zero. 
Falling prices have increased corporate bankruptcies and created hundreds of billions in non-performing loans, ravaging the financial industry. 
The government funneled $80 billion into the banks in 1999, hoping that would ease the crisis. But last weekend, the nation's fifth-largest bank, Resona Holdings, said it would need a cash infusion of $17.3 billion to survive. 
Although the American financial industry is in far better shape than Japan's, and policymakers have been far more proactive in promptly cutting taxes and interest rates, the United States and Japan have a common challenge: China. The world's most populous nation has turned into the world's factory floor, churning out goods in such quantities and so cheaply that America and Japan have little choice but to shop there for imports. 
While a boon for consumers who can now buy computers for half of what they paid two years ago, the flood of cheap products has triggered a vicious price war that has destroyed balance sheets on both sides of the Pacific. 
In years past, that would have led to calls for tariffs and bans. But that response is no longer appropriate because American and Japanese companies operate the same factories in China that produce the deflation in the first place. 
"Deflation in Japan is the expression of this country not moving as quickly as it should to the emergence of China," said Robert Feldman, a managing director of Morgan Stanley based in Tokyo. 
For years, Japan has kept people working by borrowing heavily and spending the proceeds on construction projects and other public works. But there is a limit to that. At 150 percent of gross domestic product, Japan's debt already is the highest in the developed world. 
The heart of Japan's problem, many experts say, is that it has not managed to find ways to invest its excess capital in profitable businesses. 
"It is not enough to build roads and bridges, to print money and lower interest rates, or spend money on defense," Mr. Feldman said. "You also have to move money resources into new areas and retrain people, which is very hard." 
While financial experts agree that prolonged bouts of deflation are debilitating, they disagree about whether the United States and others are learning from Japan's unprecedented woes. 
Optimists say that policymakers are better prepared to battle deflation because they have studied Japan's experiences and can use them as a powerful cautionary tale to motivate action. 
But pessimists say that although the United States has acted quickly to head off deflation there are signs it may have already exhausted many of the conventional tools, from aggressive interest rate reductions to tax cuts, and so far without great effect. 
Japan was slow to cut interest rates, and in recent years has raised taxes and fees for pensions and health care, cutting into consumer demand just when it is most needed to get the economy rolling. 
"Japan was complacent, basically did everything wrong and is now stuck in a deflationary cycle, with the malaise spreading, which is very worrying," said Peter Tasker, director of Arcus Investments, an equities firm based in Japan. 
"They had no one else's example to follow, whereas the rest of the world now has Japan to look at. The problem is, it is very difficult to say that the American economy is responding, even after quite a few bullets have been shot." 
With interest rates at zero, the Japanese central bank has lost its major tool against deflation. Rock-bottom rates have also failed to spur new bank loans, the lifeblood of any economy, because few companies have any confidence that the money can be profitably invested, and many others fear the prospect of being forced to pay it back when prices, revenues and income are falling. 
The stock market has fallen to 20-year lows, destroying pension funds. Weakened companies are also laying off more workers and cutting wages, which leads consumers to think twice about making big purchases. 
The long slide in real estate prices, which have fallen 75 percent from their 1991 peak, has also hurt homeowners, who are stuck with mortgages priced at much higher rates. Personal bankruptcies have quintupled in the last decade.
"In a deflationary environment like this, everyone who borrows money finds it harder to service their debt, not just the so-called zombie companies, but everyone from the government down to the smallest borrower," Mr. Tasker said.

HEADLINE: Bush Links Europe's Ban on Bio-Crops With Hunger 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: NEW LONDON, Conn., May 21 

 BODY:
President Bush charged today that Europe's ban on genetically modified food had discouraged third world countries from using that technology and thus undermined efforts to end hunger in Africa.
 Mr. Bush's accusation was made during a graduation speech at the United States Coast Guard Academy that dwelled on initiatives to combat AIDS and poverty. 
 It is almost certain to exacerbate the divisions between Washington and Europe that emerged before the war in Iraq. While Mr. Bush has made the case before that Europe should stop obstructing the sale of genetically modified food, today was the first time he linked that policy with world hunger. 
The speech signaled the tough stance Mr. Bush is likely to take when he goes to France in 10 days for the annual economic summit meeting of seven major industrialized nations and Russia. White House officials have already said Mr. Bush plans no reconciliation with the leaders of France and Germany, beyond what they call a perfunctory "courtesy visit" to President Jacques Chirac during the summit meeting, to be held in the French town of Evian.
In a speech that the White House said would put forward what aides called a positive agenda that would show a far softer side to American foreign policy, Mr. Bush insisted that widened use of "high-yield bio-crops" would greatly increase agricultural productivity in some of the poorest nations.
"Yet our partners in Europe are impeding this effort," he said, clearly meaning France and Germany, though he named no countries. "They have blocked all new bio-crops because of unfounded, unscientific fears." 
The result, he charged, was that African nations that fear being shut out of European markets are not investing in the technology. He appeared to be referring to countries like Uganda and Namibia.
"European governments should join, not hinder, the great cause of ending hunger in Africa," he said.
Mr. Bush made no mention of the United States' own strong economic interest in the outcome of the dispute with Europe. American corporations lead the world in biotechnology and are anxious to open the lucrative European market.
Last week the administration filed the equivalent of a lawsuit with the World Trade Organization to force Europe to lift its ban on genetically modified food, a step that Mr. Bush had delayed during the debate on Iraq. 
Inside the White House, the emotions about the countries that tried to stop the invasion are still raw; recently a senior administration official told reporters that diplomacy to disarm Saddam Hussein had been going well until, in the official's view, France stabbed the United States in the back. The French have complained that such comments are part of a concerted effort by the administration to turn the American public against France and its goods.
Today the United States trade representative, Robert B. Zoellick, wrote an op-ed article in The Wall Street Journal accusing the European Union of disregarding scientific evidence and sending "a devastating signal to developing countries that stand to benefit most from innovative agricultural technologies." 
He charged that some African countries were refusing American food aid "because of fabricated fears stoked by irresponsible rhetoric about food safety."
The European public has been highly reluctant to purchase any genetically modified products, citing unknown long-term health and environmental risks. European officials have said that the Bush administration can argue over the openness of the European market but that they reject as underhanded the implication that their stricter rules on genetically modified food are somehow responsible for hunger in Africa.
Tony van der Haegen, the expert for food safety at the European Union, said administration officials had been "a bit unfair to whip Europeans" when they had never blocked food aid. Last week European officials charged that the administration was manufacturing its claims. 
"The U.S. claims that there is a so-called moratorium," Pascal Lamy, the top European trade official, said last week, "but the fact is that the E.U. has authorized G.M. varieties in the past and is currently processing applications. So what is the real U.S. motive in bringing a case?"
Yet as a practical matter, the European Union had an unwritten moratorium on new varieties of bio-crops until last year. Since then it has approved only two applications for new imports.
Europeans have also demanded that any genetically modified foods be labeled, a move that American farmers say would condemn the products to the back shelves, where they would sit unsold. The United States suit has been joined by a number of other nations, many of which are seeking free trade agreements with the United States.
Mr. Bush's speech here, delivered in a drizzling rain as Coast Guard vessels bobbed in the waters behind him, marked a return to the state where he was born -- a native status that the adopted Texan rarely talks about, identifying himself more with Midland, the Texas town in which he grew up. 
But his birthplace was just too close today to be ignored, and Mr. Bush opened his speech by saying, "You know, I was born in this state, just down the road." He was greeted by laughter, then applause. "I've still got relatives living here," he said.
In his speech, Mr. Bush commended Congress for passing legislation authorizing greater spending around the world on AIDS treatment, a bill he said he would sign next week. 
He called anew for financing for the Millennium Challenge Account, a new approach to development aid that would grant money to nations that demonstrated a commitment to remaking their justice systems, spending more on health and education, and adopting market-opening measures.
"When I'm in Europe," he said, pointing to another likely subject of contention, "I will call on America's partners to join us in moving beyond the broken development policies of the past, and encourage the freedom and reform that lead to prosperity."

HEADLINE: Back Campaigning, Bush Raises $22 Million 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21 

 BODY:
President Bush flexed his political muscles tonight for the first time since declaring himself a candidate for re-election, raising $22 million for Republican House and Senate candidates in his initial fund-raising appearance of the 2004 election cycle.
 The evening's take was an early indication of Mr. Bush's ability to raise record-setting amounts of money for his own candidacy and for Republicans further down the ticket. 
 In what amounted to his first overt campaign appearance since last fall's midterm Congressional elections, Mr. Bush made clear, if any doubt remained, that he would seek re-election by meshing his role as commander in chief in a continuing war on terrorism with his push for conservative domestic policies, most notably his drive for tax cuts. 
Speaking to an audience of 7,500 donors in the cavernous new Washington Convention Center, Mr. Bush said the last two and a half years had shown Americans to be "courageous, resolute, tough when we have to be and a compassionate people" -- the same attributes that the White House has sought to attach to the president after a terrorist attack, two wars, a recession and a corporate scandal.
Reprising a line from his 2000 campaign, he spoke of progress in restoring "honor and dignity" to the presidency. He hailed Vice President Dick Cheney and applauded Congress for passing much of his agenda. But he said there was still "a lot to do," especially in fighting terrorism and righting the faltering economy.
Casting the war on terrorism as an epic struggle, he said the United States "will not stop until the danger to civilization is removed." 
Having said that, he also seemed to acknowledge that his political fortunes will hinge on his ability to make the economy more vibrant and stop the steady erosion of jobs.
"Our most urgent mission in the months ahead is to strengthen the economy," he said.
Mr. Bush, who formally established his re-election committee last week, will begin raising money for his own candidacy next month with events in Washington on June 17 and New York on June 23. His postwar popularity and proven fund-raising prowess have led some Republicans to predict that he and Vice President Cheney could raise as much as $200 million for their campaign, twice the record-setting $100 million Mr. Bush raised for his race in 2000. 
The money Mr. Bush raised tonight will go to the National Republican Senatorial Committee and the National Republican Congressional Committee, the fund-raising organizations for House and Senate races. It is all so-called hard money -- mostly from $2,500 per-person tickets -- that can be used for any purpose. Under the new campaign finance law -- which is about to undergo review by the Supreme Court -- individuals can give up to $25,000 to a party committee per year, up to a maximum of $57,500 per two-year election cycle.
Although the same dinner last year raised $30 million, about two-thirds of that was largely unregulated contributions known as soft money, which has been banned under the campaign finance law.
For Mr. Bush, it was an efficient appearance. He listened to the Oak Ridge Boys sing the National Anthem and then, at his request, "Amazing Grace." He spoke for half an hour, and although the evening was billed as "the President's Dinner," he did not stay to eat the filet mignon, hustling out after a few brief handshakes with donors on the dais, including Steve Case, the former chairman of AOL Time Warner.
Republicans at the dinner said it was taking more work to raise money this year, given the weak stock market and the soft economy.
"It took a lot more calls than were made a year ago to get this amount of money," said Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi.
Mr. Lott, who stepped down late last year as Senate majority leader after making remarks that appeared to embrace the segregationist platform of Strom Thurmond's 1948 presidential bid, was one face in a sea of Republicans, from Cabinet members to small-town mayors.
Indeed, Mr. Lott, who was seated near the back of the room about a football field away from Mr. Bush, noted that he was at table No. 742, "a drop of 741 in one day" from his seat of honor last year.
Mr. Lott said the evening was the opening of an 18-month campaign season that was probably too long for everyone involved, but that it demonstrated the party's ability to raise money under the new law.
"This is what John McCain always said would happen, that we'd be better off under the new campaign finance laws because we have a better ability to raise hard money," Mr. Lott said.

HEADLINE: The Republicans Party On 

 BODY:
Against some of the best economic advice in the land, President Bush and his Republican Congressional leaders have concocted a benighted final tax-cut plan that will do far more to deepen the nation's deficits and debt than to stimulate the wallowing economy. In a rush for approval by Memorial Day, the leaders have cannibalized parts of competing packages into a tentative $318 billion grab bag that again offers the most significant relief to the upper-bracket Americans so dear to the administration. Dividend taxes will be cut, not eliminated as the president hoped, but so will capital gains taxes. The latter was a conservative chestnut rejected two years ago when the first Bush cuts were enacted in the long-ago euphoria of an actual budget surplus. 
 This time, with the budget hemorrhaging red ink, the G.O.P. takes care to include $20 billion in much needed fiscal relief for battered state and local budgets, whose problems can be traced in part to the first Bush cuts. And the leaders are wrapping their package in middle-class sweeteners like child-care credits and relief for married taxpayers. But those boons are cynically "sunsetted" to expire after three years to fit into fictitious limits of fiscal responsibility. In contrast, there is no such asterisk on the accelerated cut in all tax rates, including the most controversial drop in the top rate, to 35 percent from 38.6 percent -- a windfall of scores of thousands of dollars annually for wealthy Americans. 
 This version of the president's "growth" plan will increase the deficit by hundreds of billions of dollars across the next decade. To help pay for it, the G.O.P. budget hawks of yore, born again now as deficit spenders of record proportions, will soon have to raise the national debt limit by almost a trillion dollars from the current $6.4 trillion. This is particularly urgent now that the current year's deficit is ballooning beyond estimates, toward $400 billion, with the two Bush tax cuts expected to add well over $2 trillion in deficits by 2013. "Deficits do matter," the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, warned Congress, sounding like a Dickensian wraith ominously foreseeing a future of red-ink borrowing and rising interest rates. But the Republicans appear set to party on now and roll the tab over the far horizon.

HEADLINE: $15 Billion AIDS Plan Wins Final Approval in Congress 

BYLINE:  By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21 

 BODY:
The House gave final approval to President Bush's $15 billion global AIDS initiative today, clearing the way for Mr. Bush to sign the measure before he leaves next week to meet Western leaders for an economic meeting in Evian, France.
 The bill, which gives the federal government the authority to triple spending on global AIDS over the next five years, is an important symbol for Mr. Bush, who has made spending to combat AIDS a centerpiece of his "compassionate conservative" agenda at home and abroad. It is intended to prevent and treat AIDS in 12 nations in Africa and 2 in the Caribbean. 
 "The AIDS virus is a moral challenge to our civilization," Representative Henry J. Hyde of Illinois, chairman of the House International Relations Committee and the chiefRepublican sponsor of the measure, said today in the House chamber. "I know that today my colleagues will be animated by the compassion and vision that has always defined what it means to be an American."
That is the message President Bush wants to take to next week's forum, where he will meet with European leaders who are still irritated with the United States over the war in Iraq. The White House is seeking to use the AIDS initiative to demonstrate Mr. Bush's commitment to moral causes as well as military ones. At the same time, the president plans to make the argument that other nations should follow the lead of the United States and increase spending on AIDS.
Today's action, by voice vote, brought Mr. Hyde's measure -- which passed the House this month by the overwhelming vote of 375 to 41 -- into line with a version the Senate passed last week. That bill added a provision encouraging the Bush administration to begin negotiations that could lead to debt relief for nations hardest hit by AIDS.
The overall measure makes good on a promise President Bush made in January in his State of the Union address. The White House says it will prevent 7 million new infections, provide antiretroviral drugs for 2 million infected people and care for 10 million patients and children who have lost their parents to the disease. 
But the measure does not provide the money to pay for the initiative; that will be left to House and Senate appropriators. And it is not without controversy; some advocates for AIDS patients say it provides too little money for a global fund to fight the disease, while others are upset about a provision that requires one-third of the prevention money in the bill to be set aside for programs that exclusively promote sexual abstinence until marriage.
But the initiative's backers say it is an important step toward curbing the global AIDS epidemic, which has claimed 23 million lives since 1981, when the disease was first recognized. Today nearly 10,000 people in Africa are infected each day with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS.
"It's rare that we pass legislation that has the true power to save the lives of millions of people worldwide," said Senator Bill Frist of Tennessee, the Republican majority leader, who has been a major proponent of increasing spending on AIDS.
Mr. Frist called the bill a "truly historic leap that may very well turn the tide of this devastating disease."
Despite bipartisan support for the increased spending, the initiative proved contentious. Conservatives worried that the money would be steered to agencies that provide abortions and tried, unsuccessfully, to draft legislation that would have included language prohibiting AIDS money from going to such programs.
Instead, the White House brokered a compromise in which agencies may provide abortions and also receive federal AIDS financing, as long as the programs are separate and the money is strictly accounted for.
Republicans and Democrats were also at odds over whether money should be steered toward programs that promote sexual abstinence only, and they had difficulty agreeing on how much should go to the new global fund, set up two years ago by the United Nations. Republicans said the fund was untested; Democrats said it needed more money.
The disagreements were so severe that Mr. Frist was unable to reach a compromise in the Senate; that task fell to Mr. Hyde in the House.
Mr. Hyde said of AIDS, "Left unchecked, this plague will further rip the fabric of developing societies, pushing fragile governments and economies to the point of collapse."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
A Muddled Day on Wall St. Ends Close to Where It Began

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Wall Street stumbled through an uneven session yesterday and closed mixed after the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, said he was unable to make a firm judgment about the health of the economy.
 In testimony to the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, Mr. Greenspan said economic signals remained mixed; his comments increased the concerns of some investors about the pace of recovery and sent stocks falling. But prices rebounded as some traders took advantage of lower prices after three days of selling. 
 There were also undercurrents of caution after reports that a case of mad cow disease had been identified in Canada and as the federal government raised the terror alert level.
At the end of the day's trading, the major stock indexes had moved relatively little. The blue-chip Dow Jones industrial average, shaking off early declines, closed up 25.07 points, or 0.3 percent, at 8,516.43. It was the Dow's first gain in four sessions. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 3.69 points, or 0.4 percent, to 923.42. But the technology-focused Nasdaq composite index, in its fourth consecutive decline, dipped 1.22 points -- less than 0.1 percent -- to 1,489.87.
On the New York Stock Exchange, advancing issues outnumbered those declining by a margin around 3 to 2. Volume eased to 1.46 billion shares from 1.52 billion on Tuesday.
Strategists seemed hard pressed for a consistent explanation of stock behavior. "The strength in the market is still there," said Peter Cardillo, president and chief strategist at Global Partner Securities. "We are looking at a market that still wants to go higher."
But others thought that the market would have trouble rallying further until there were new signs the economy was rebounding and stocks were fairly priced. Richard A. Dickson, senior market strategist at Lowry's Research Reports in Palm Beach, Fla., wrote, "Lacking any clear evidence of a market bottom, any near-term rally is likely to be, in our opinion, short lived." 
Shares of tobacco companies rose after a Florida appeals court overturned a record-setting $145 billion award against Philip Morris USA and othercompanies. Wall Street also seemed unfazed by agreement at the World Health Organization on the severe terms of a treaty intended to discourage smoking.
The stock price of the Altria Group, the parent of Philip Morris, rose $3.39, or 9.7 percent, to $38.30; R. J. Reynolds gained $1.57, or nearly 5 percent, to $33.28; and Loews rose $1.82, or 4.3 percent, to $44.10.
Among stocks advancing yesterday, McDonald's rose 35 cents, to $17.30, recouping some of the $1.21 it lost on Tuesday amid the fears of mad cow disease. Lehman Brothers upgraded the company's shares and minimized the severity of the situation in Canada. Officials said the infected cow did not enter the food chain and its calves are quarantined.
Among technology stocks, Hewlett-Packard rose 89 cents, to $17.94, having reported earnings late Tuesday that surpassed analysts' expectations and indicated that the absorption of Compaq Computer was almost complete.
But Cisco Systems declined 29 cents, to $15.70, after Deutsche Securities lowered its recommendation on the company to hold from buy.
Eaton Vance, a mutual fund and investment company, fell $1.10, to $29.10, after its second-quarter earnings missed analysts' estimates by 3 cents a share.

	 	 		--------------------	 	

Treasury Prices Vary
By Bloomberg News
Treasury notes fell yesterday, pushing two-year yields up from 53-year lows, after Mr. Greenspan, the Fed chief, expressed optimism that a forecast for faster economic growth was "not unreasonable."
His testimony led traders to lower expectations of another cut in interest rates next month. Ten-year yields rose less as some traders interpreted Greenspan remarks to mean that the Fed might buy longer-maturity securities to spur growth.
Yields on the two-year notes rose to 1.36 percent from 1.26 percent on Tuesday. The price, which moves in the opposite direction, dropped 5/32 , to 100 16/32 .
The benchmark 10-year Treasury note fell 11/32 , to 101 29/32 . Its yield rose to 3.40 percent from 3.36 percent.
But the price of the 30-year bond gained 3/32 , to 116 14/32 ; its yield eased to 4.35 percent from 4.36 percent.

HEADLINE: Greenspan, Broadly Positive, Spells OutDeflation Worries 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21 

 BODY:
While offering a generally optimistic view of the economy, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, issued his strongest warning yet today about the dangers posed by deflation.
 "We at the Federal Reserve recognize that deflation is a possibility," Mr. Greenspan told members of Congress. "Even though we perceive the risks as minor, the potential consequences are very substantial and could be quite negative." 
 The Fed, he said, is closely monitoring deflation, a sustained decline in prices, for ways to combat it if it takes hold.
Mr. Greenspan emphasized that growth was likely to improve this year. If it did not, he said, the Fed could inject money into the economy to halt any deflation -- which can cripple an economy by causing people to reduce their spending in anticipation of future bargains -- and by effectively increasing debt loads. He said that the prospect of deflation had created an unusual degree of uncertainty because "we never dealt with this before."
Reiterating his concern that the rising federal budget deficit could harm the economy by driving up interest rates and raising the cost of money for consumers and businesses, Mr. Greenspan also gave political support to policy makers who have argued for a smaller tax cut.
"Deficits do matter," he said. "In any evaluation of a program, what happens to deficits is an integral part of the analysis."
Mr. Greenspan avoided taking positions on specific parts of the tax-cut legislation before Congress, instead lamenting the lack of discussion about reductions in government spending. He offered general praise for the elimination of taxes on dividends and capital gains, a Republican priority, and for unemployment benefits, which Democrats want to extend.
Stock and bond prices were mixed today, with most gauges only slightly changed. Bonds had fallen during Mr. Greenspan's testimony, before the Joint Economic Committee, as traders seemed to interpret his remarks as a sign that the Fed was unlikely to raise its benchmark short-term interest rate any time soon and might cut it at its next meeting in June.
But Mr. Greenspan's overall evaluation of the economy was consistent with the optimistic message he had been delivering in recent months, a period when some other Fed officials grew more concerned about the possibility of a new economic downturn. Mr. Greenspan and other optimists have argued that interest rates are low enough to encourage spending and lift the economy, while some officials in the Fed's 12 regional banks favor a precautionary rate reduction to keep prices rising.
The Fed's main policy tool is its ability to set the interest rate on overnight loans between banks, which affects the rate on many other loans and the pace at which consumers and businesses spend money. But officials have emphasized that if they lower the rate -- now at 1.25 percent, a 40-year low -- to zero, and the economy remains weak, they can buy long-term bonds or take other steps to stimulate growth. 
Mr. Greenspan said today that low interest rates, the decline in oil prices, the end of the war in Iraq and a recent overall rise in stock prices suggested that the economy would emerge this year from its long slump. But calling recent data about employment and production "on the weak side," he said that growth had not yet picked up and that he remained uncertain about when it would and how strong the rebound would be. The central question, he added, is when companies will increase their spending on new factories and equipment.
Richard J. DeKaser, chief economist at the National City Corporation in Cleveland, said, "The message is that there are very hopeful leading indicators, but we have scant evidence of any real traction in the economy."
Although the subject of deflation has attracted attention recently, before today Mr. Greenspan had rarely used the word in public. And the Fed's statement after its most recent meeting discussed the minor possibility of "an unwelcome substantial fall in inflation." 
During a speech in December, when he last spoke of deflation in detail, Mr. Greenspan said, "The United States is nowhere close to sliding into a pernicious deflation."
Since then, some measures of inflation have dropped to their lowest levels in decades, raising fears that weak demand for new products could push the country into the kind of spiral that has afflicted Japan. 
In an exchange today with Senator Robert F. Bennett, Republican of Utah, Mr. Greenspan acknowledged the scrutiny that his often murky discussion of the recent decline in inflation receives -- interrupting Senator Bennett after he had said that Mr. Greenspan mentioned deflation the last time he testified to Congress.
The Fed chief interjected, "Did I use the word 'deflation?' "
Mr. Bennett responded, "You kind of danced around it, but that's the way it came across."
Mr. Greenspan, smiling broadly, said, "It was my interpreter."
Today, he showed little such reticence, giving a detailed history of the successful battle that central bankers had fought against inflation and saying that they now had to study the causes of deflation to learn how to defeat it. Fed officials have made "very substantial progress," he added, but the matter continued to warrant "very close scrutiny" and "maybe action."
Yet, in an encouraging sign, surveys show that consumers do not expect prices to begin falling, Mr. Greenspan said, suggesting that they would not curtail their spending. 
If inflation continues to decline or the economy does not show signs of improvement in coming weeks, economists predict that the Fed will cut its benchmark rate.
Asked by senators about the value of the dollar, Mr. Greenspan declined to comment, saying that only the Treasury secretary, John W. Snow, should do so. A decline in the dollar's value, which has accelerated since Mr. Snow suggested that the Bush administration was comfortable with the fall, has made deflation less likely by increasing the price of imports, economists say. 
The Fed chief did mention a sharp rise in the cost of natural gas, which he said had not received enough attention. In the last year, natural gas prices have risen 65 percent, according to Economy.com in West Chester, Pa., as demand for it has increased faster than production. "It is a very serious problem," Mr. Greenspan said.
Asked about jobless benefits, Mr. Greenspan said that they should be "temporarily generous" during economic downturns, when people are forced out of work, but that if Congress decides to extend them -- a subject of current debate -- it should do so only briefly and then revisit the issue. In other countries, where benefits are bigger and last longer, people sometimes have an incentive not to work, he said.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY 

 BODY:
 INTERNATIONAL A3-12

C.I.A. Begins to Review Prewar Iraq Intelligence
George J. Tenet, the director of central intelligence, has named a team of experts to find out whether American intelligence erred in its prewar assessments of Saddam Hussein's government, including evaluations of Iraq's links to terrorism and its unconventional weapons programs. A1

France, Russia and Germany have approved a resolution giving tremendous authority over the political and economic affairs of Iraq to the United States and Britain and a limited but independent role to the United Nations. It is expected to win support in a Security Council vote. A1

An Arab television network broadcast an audiotape said to have been recorded by a top leader of Al Qaeda, Ayman al-Zawahiri, that calls on Muslims to attack Western interests and derides Arab governments that aided the war on Iraq. A1

The Bush administration called on the Tehran government to act against leaders of Al Qaeda said to be in Iran, but declined to say whether a clear connection had been established between those leaders and last week's bombing attacks in Saudi Arabia. A14

Earthquake Hits Algeria
Algeria's deadliest earthquake in years struck the capital and nearby towns on Wednesday, killing at least 530 people and injuring thousands. A1

President Bush criticized Europe's ban on genetically modified foods, saying it undermined efforts to end hunger in Africa. The comments were almost certain to exacerbate tensions between Washington and Europe over the war in Iraq. A3

Mexico, Japan, Australia and several other nations joined the United States in placing a temporary ban on the import of Canadian beef, as health officials raced to find out how a cow in Alberta contracted mad cow disease. A8

Christie Whitman said that she was resigning as administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency. Her 28-month tenure was marked by tensions within the Bush administration. A1

The fight over the flight of Democratic legislators got fiercer as the state Department of Public Safety admitted that it had destroyed documents collected as state troopers searched for the missing lawmakers last week. A16

In two of the first controlled clinical trials to test the 31-year-old Atkins diet participants experienced just marginally more effective weight loss but achieved lower triglycerides, blood fats that can contribute to plaque buildup in the arteries. A20

In Connecticut, the practice of keeping all records of certain court cases secret, known as supersealing, was unknown by most state lawmakers. But last week, after months of embarrassment, most of the state's judges voted unanimously to end supersealing. B1

HEADLINE: TAKING THE CHILDREN; 
Men Without Paychecks, Now Minding the Children

BYLINE:  By Peter M. Nichols 

 BODY:
Daddy Day Care
Eddie Murphy, Jeff Garlin, Steve Zahn, Regina King, Khamani Griffin, Anjelica Huston
Directed by Steve Carr
PG 93 minutes
 Trying to promote a vegetable-based breakfast cereal called Veggios, the marketing man Charlie Hinton (Mr. Murphy) winds up on unemployment. Charlie has a Mercedes convertible and a nice house. Soon he will have a monthly day care bill that his wife, Kim (Ms. King), at first mistakes for an annual rate. Chapman Academy is expensive, but the 4-year-olds wear blazers and learn German. The headmistress, Miss Harridan (Ms. Huston), assures the Hintons that there is no more enriching place for their son, Ben (Khamani Griffin). 
 Lower-priced alternatives seem to be run by America's most wanted. "If somebody opened a decent day care around here, they'd make a killing," says a woman on a park bench.
By now Charlie and his friend Phil (Mr. Garlin), another Veggios casualty, are at the park every day with their children. Why not tend kids for money? Charlie and Phil will open Daddy Day Care in Charlie's house. Neighborhood children are recruited, some of them from families fed up with Harridan's mini-Harvard. Prospects express their views about daddies in this kind of work: unnatural, says one; sicko, says another. Soon, though, a group of children is gathered and ready to wreck Charlie's place.
A sugary lunch gets things hopping. In subsequent days Charlie and Phil struggle but survive. Charlie says they need games and activities; Phil advocates Ritalin and leashes. Gradually the children calm down and get interested. One little boy sheds the Flash Gordon outfit he has worn for weeks. Others develop skills and self-confidence. With Charlie at home, he and Ben develop a new closeness.
A fellow ex-employee, Marvin (Mr. Zahn), joins the staff. He wore the carrot suit in the Veggios promotion. Soon Daddy Day Care needs larger quarters. An open house is part circus, part rock concert. Charlie gets his old job back at twice the money, but how can he walk away from all these other rewards?

VIOLENCE -- None.
SEX -- Marvin unwittingly utters some very mild double entendres when talking to a mother.
PROFANITY -- Some potty talk.

For Which Children?
AGES 3-6 -- This category will relate to children in the film, who are about their age. It's hard to find anything too objectionable.
AGES 7-10 -- A sweet film doesn't work very hard at fresh insights, but it's full of good feelings and intentions. Mr. Murphy is an appealing dad.
AGES 10 AND UP -- Fine, if they like.

Down With Love
Renee Zellweger, Ewan McGregor, David Hyde Pierce, Sarah Paulson, Rachel Dratch
Directed by Peyton Reed
PG-13 100 minutes
It's 1962 and a spankingly fresh day in Mr. Reed's naughty candy-
colored spoof of the Rock Hudson-Doris Day movies ("Pillow Talk," "Lover Come Back," "Send Me No Flowers").
Recently arrived from Maine, the hugely enthusiastic Barbara Novak (Ms. Zellweger) checks in at her Manhattan publisher, meets her frenzied editor (Ms. Paulson) and marvels at the whirl and bustle of the fast-track New York scene.
Barbara has written "Down With Love," a provocative blockbuster that is about to change the way the world does things. It's Barbara's contention that women should enjoy equal participation in the workplace, and to do this they should exclude themselves from relationships with men. Sex is still allowed, but it should be casual and with no strings.
The book takes off after Judy Garland helps promote it on "The Ed Sullivan Show." Soon every woman on the planet is out looking for a job. Across town at Know Publications, Barbara and all the hubbub catch the attention of a sleek cad of an ace reporter named Catcher Block (Mr. McGregor). Know's publisher, Peter McManus (Mr. Pierce), has been pressuring Catcher for his next big scoop, and Barbara has the makings.
But after Catcher stands her up at one too many interview appointments, Barbara drops out. Catcher is miffed and decides to turn his profile into an expose. He and Barbara are unacquainted at this point, so he disguises himself as an astronaut, and the two fall into a coy romance.
Would they, should they, will they have sex? Barbara wants to, as long as it's casual. Catcher plays hard to get. Will these two ever have a Las Vegas wedding?

VIOLENCE -- None.
SEX -- Male endowment is discussed through double entendre, and there is much sexual suggestion and talk about sex.
PROFANITY -- Risque talk.

For Which Children?
UNDER AGE 11 -- Many parents will decide not.
AGES 11-13 -- The film is fun and harmless.

The Matrix Reloaded
Keanu Reeves, Carrie-Anne Moss, Laurence Fishburne, Hugo Weaving, Jada Pinkett Smith, Gloria Foster, Harold Perrineau
Directed by the Wachowski Brothers
R 138 minutes
Zion, the underground last refuge of the human species, is under attack by an army of machines chewing their way down with devices that resemble whirling octopuses. Morpheus (Mr. Fishburne), Zion's most respected sage, and Link (Mr. Perrineau), the humans' best computer jockey, barely make it home.
Morpheus tells the assembled throng that if they stand up and resist, deliverance is at hand. In the dingy underworld, that sets off drums and begins a torchlight dance of celebration reminiscent of the rites in "King Kong." But salvation is in the hands of Neo (Mr. Reeves), called the One, a supposed messiah with ultimate powers.
Neo, however, has doubts. In a recurring dream, his lover and right-hand wonderwoman, Trinity (Ms. Moss), is killed by a machine operative named Agent Smith (Mr. Weaving). This upsets Neo and makes him tentative about doing his best against the machines. Morpheus says they must consult the Oracle (Ms. Foster), a grandmotherly type on a park bench.
As was the case in "The Matrix," the first film in the series, the Oracle has no easy remedy. She tells Neo that his decision to act or not has already been made. Now he must understand why he made it, or Zion will be destroyed. "To be concluded," reads the caption announcing the third "Matrix" installment, scheduled for November.

VIOLENCE -- Spectacular action sequences introduce much hand-to-hand and mechanized violence. It's highly stylized and not very believable, but very violent nonetheless.
SEX -- The nude Neo and Trinity make love in an extended scene.
PROFANITY -- Strong language but relatively few obscenities.

For Which Children?
UNDER AGE 12 -- The violence and sex rule it out by most parental guidelines.
AGES 12-14 -- Parents might disagree, but by now children should be old enough.
AGES 15 AND UP -- Tolerable by most standards.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Khamani Griffin is the son; Eddie Murphy is "Daddy Day Care." (Bruce McBroom/Columbia Pictures)
