LENGTH: 4608 words

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums children under 12 and museum members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Museums

* "ART OF THE FIRST CITIES: THE THIRD MILLENNIUM B.C. FROM THE MEDITERRANEAN TO THE INDUS," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Aug. 17). The most timely exhibition in years, as well as diplomatically dexterous and beautiful. It surveys the culture of the third millennium B.C., mainly centered in Mesopotamia, the crucible of Sumerian civilization, where art, architecture, law and writing developed with the rise of the earliest cities. The beginnings of a cosmopolitan art are in tiny cylinder seals and in figurines. The show is full of small objects that are monumental in concept. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $12; students and 65+, $7 (Michael Kimmelman).

* "MATTHEW BARNEY: THE CREMASTER CYCLE," Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through June 11). The most anticipated show by any American artist to emerge in a decade or more. "Cremaster," Mr. Barney's nine-year, five-film project, here presented whole for the first time, is an inspired benchmark of ambition, scope and forthright provocation for art in the new century. I recall Elizabeth Murray's describing how Philip Guston's crazy late works gave her heart to do her own mature paintings. Mr. Barney has brought to the art world a new freedom to explore narrative. He has introduced a new repertory of materials -- gooey, strange, malleable and synthetic -- that nobody thought of as germane before. Never mind that the films and many (not all) of his related sculptures, installations and photographs are very beautiful. The show, an installation itself, brings them together. The earliest "Cremaster" sculptures are film props, cobbled into installations that don't jell. But the latest are better: twin steel towers framed in plastic, a suite of abstract sculptures derived from automobile chassis. Vaseline and plastic combine with cement and steel -- pink and gray, rough and smooth, hard and soft -- the materials sustaining a narrative of formal eloquence. Hours: Saturdays through Wednesdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $15; students and 65+, $10 (Kimmelman).

"BEALS, HERVEY AND HEWITT: WOMEN PIONEERS OF ARCHITECTURE AND DESIGN PHOTOGRAPHY," New-York Historical Society, 2 West 77th Street, (212) 873-3400 (through July 13). Three female photographers, saluted for their successes in early-20th-century New York. The artistic oddball was Antoinette Bryant Hervey (1857-1945), who carried out an obsessive 40-year photographic documentation of the construction of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine and produced an epic of great artistry as well as historical value. Greenwich Village was the stamping ground of Jessie Tarbox Beals (1870-1942), the best known of the three, who engagingly turned her lens on Village haunts, architecture and personalities. Mattie Edwards Hewitt (circa 1870-1956) did homes and gardens designed for the era's rich and famous, like Conde Nast and Margaret Bourke-White. Although this mix is a little forced, individually each woman is worth a salute. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; students and 65+, $3 (Grace Glueck).

* "EGYPT REBORN: ART FOR ETERNITY," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (permanent installation). The second and final phase in the museum's reinstallation of its world-
renowned holdings of ancient Egyptian art, this dazzling display rounds up more than 600 objects -- from king-and-queen-size monuments to tiny rings and amulets -- from the predynastic period to the 18th dynasty. Together with the first phase, which opened in 1993 and covers later Egyptian art, visitors will now be able to trace the entire course of this brilliant and complex civilization from its beginnings to its absorption by the Roman Empire in 30 B.C. The heart of the new installation is an introductory gallery that provides a wonderful summation, with a survey of sculptural styles and displays of weapons, pottery, cosmetics, jewelry, furniture and funerary arts. The adjacent galleries are devoted to an extensive chronological survey. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (until 11 p.m. the first Saturday of each month). Admission: $6; students and 62+, $3 (Glueck).

* "MANET/VELAZQUEZ: THE FRENCH TASTE FOR SPANISH PAINTING," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through June 29). The Met has clearly called in every chip to make this show spectacular. The first rooms are a virtual survey of great Spanish painting of the 17th and 18th centuries; after that comes a virtual Manet retrospective, with some Degas and Courbet thrown in for good measure; then a virtual 19th-century American overview of the most gifted portraitists influenced by Spanish painting via Manet, Degas and Courbet: Eakins, Chase, Sargent and Whistler. The thesis of Spanish influence on French art is hardly new, but it is explored in such precise and fresh detail, discreetly, without pushing comparisons (in that respect it's not like "Matisse Picasso" at the Modern, notwithstanding the coincidental titled pairings) that you would have to be churlish not to leave edified and amazed. Hours and admission: See above (Kimmelman).

"MATERIAL DIFFERENCES: ART AND IDENTITY IN AFRICA," Museum for African Art, 36-01 43rd Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-7700 (through Aug. 15). Part Art Methods 101, part Advanced Connoisseurship, this handsome, thoughtful show examines the potent connection between matter and meaning in diverse African cultures and shows them to be organically connected. The material is spiritual in these cultures, and the show's 130 mostly ceremonial objects, arranged strictly according to materials and techniques, reflect the power of that belief. Hours: Mondays, Thursdays and Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; students and 65+, $2.50 (Roberta Smith).

"ELIE NADELMAN: SCULPTOR OF MODERN LIFE," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3600 (through July 20). Despite the clarion title, this exhibition is too monotonous, stiffly installed and short on drawings to do full justice to the erudite, polymorphous achievement of the Polish-born American sculptor Elie Nadelman (1882-1946). Still, don't miss this opportunity to see his work in quantity, especially the streamlined wood figures from the 1920's and the small truculent plaster figurines, which were found in his studio after his death. Their suave economy, ineffable stillness, delicate gestures and seamless blend of historical and popular sources place them among the most complex, fully visual sculptures in Western art. Hours and admission: See above Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $12; students and 62+, $9.50 (Smith).

* "CHRISTIAN SCHAD AND THE NEUE SACHLICHKEIT," Neue Galerie, 1048 Fifth Avenue, at 86th Street, (212) 628-6200 (through June 9). Schad's career effectively lasted only 15 years, from around 1915 to 1930, and for just two or three of those years was he doing what deserves to be remembered now. Not much time. But just enough. Schad at his mordant best precisely captured an anxious culture affected by war and the threat of it: his bloodless portraits in Vienna and Berlin suggest deep unease and foreboding beneath porcelain surfaces. They are explicitly unemotional, even when they are frankly erotic, as they frequently are. His drawings, akin to some done by Dix and Grosz, shy away from the issues of class conflict that inflamed both of those other artists. To the end, Schad remained aloof. Hours: Fridays, 11 a.m. to 9 p.m.; Saturdays, Sundays and Mondays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $10; students and 65+, $7 (Kimmelman).

ROSEMARIE TROCKEL, "Spleen," Dia Center for the Arts, 535 West 22nd Street, (212) 989-5566 (through June 15). This German Conceptualist is known for machine-knitted fabric works patterned with corporate logos. Her installation consists of five massive, freestanding walls covered on one side by grids of painted metal plates. Short films projected on the reverse sides are mystifyingly oblique. The Dia curator Lynne Cooke says they allude to gender roles, hysterical pregnancy, grassroots politics of the 60's, Bertolt Brecht's play "Mother Courage," the cold war and much more. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $6; children, students and 60+, $3 (Ken Johnson).

ROBERT WHITMAN, "Playback," Dia Center for the Arts, 535 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (212) 989-5566 (through June 15). Mr. Whitman, who was born in 1935, was a pioneer in the use of new technologies in art and performance. In his work from the 1960's and 70's on view here, he was less a technical wizard than a Surrealist poet. Like the paintings of Rene Magritte, his combinations of sculptural installation and film play with illusion and reality to perceptually disorienting and mystically exciting effect. Hours and admission: See above (Johnson).

Galleries: Uptown

"SALLY MICHEL, MILTON AVERY: A PORTRAIT," Knoedler & Company, 19 East 70th Street, (212) 794-0550 (through May 30). Also known as Mrs. Milton Avery, the widow of the artist, Sally Michel used her own name as a painter in her own right. This warm memorial tribute to Michel and Avery mounts a group of informal, private portraits of each artist done by the other. A wall of Avery by Michel, who died in January, shows him painting, napping, smoking, reading, thinking, leaning. A facing wall of portraits by Avery (1885-1965) shows Michel smiling, mothering their daughter, March, wearing a new hat and painting a portrait of her husband. This small show is an engaging celebration of a highly productive relationship (Glueck).

GEORGE SEGAL, "Bronze," Mitchell-Innes & Nash, 1018 Madison Avenue, near 78th Street, (212) 744-7400 (through June 14). There was always a Hopperesque ennui about Segal's plaster-cast figures. Late works cast in bronze are truly lugubrious. Four chunky women in balletic poses perform a ponderous dance; three dark gray people with the closed eyes of sleepwalkers meet under one-way street signs pointing in two directions; and in "Street Crossing," seven blind souls painted white wander aimlessly in a modern purgatory (Johnson).

HELEN TORR, "Out of the Shadows," James Graham, 1014 Madison Avenue, at 78th Street, (212) 535-5767 (through June 8). Torr, the wife of Arthur Dove, was an accomplished if not highly original painter and an excellent draftsman in her own right. This retrospective, organized by Anne Cohen DePietro of the Heckscher Museum on Long Island, is studded by gems in a range of styles, from ecstatic Dove-esque abstractions to delicate yet sumptuous still lifes that Georgia O'Keeffe might have envied (Johnson).

* "WEAVING CHINA'S PAST: THE AMY S. CLAGUE COLLECTION OF CHINESE TEXTILES," China Institute Gallery, 125 East 65th Street, (212) 744-8181 (through June 7). This gallery has a sterling record in presenting small, fine-tuned scholarly shows and this one, imported from the Phoenix Art Museum, exactly fits the description. With precious examples of silk brocades, tapestries and embroideries, including Buddhist ritual pieces, dating from the Jin to Qing dynasty, it gives a vivid sense of the material past in a powerful imperial culture (Holland Cotter).

Galleries: 57th Street

JOHN CEDERQUIST, "Furniture That Builds Itself," Franklin Parrasch, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 246-5360 (through June 7). Mr. Cederquist's beautifully made woodworks are simultaneously functional pieces of furniture and zany cartoons in two and three dimensions. With painted Mickey Mouse arms wielding drills and planes as if in the act of building, these funky sculptures are deceptively whimsical meditations on the mind's construction of reality (Johnson).

"HEAVEN AND HELL," Barbara Mathes Gallery, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 752-5135, (through June 6). This high-low meditation includes Stephen Balkenhol's rough, wooden Everyman twins as an angel and a devil; a leering antique silver Satan photographed by Robert Mapplethorpe; montages illustrating Dante's "Inferno" by Robert Rauschenberg; a big celestial photograph by Thomas Ruff; a terrestrial paradise photographed by Thomas Struth; painful signs by Jenny Holzer; and the convergence of an angel and a manhole cover in a luminous nocturne by Joseph Cornell (Johnson).

HENRY PEARSON, "Selected Drawings 1959-1969," Alexandre Gallery, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 755-2828 (through May 30). Breathing, pulsating surfaces of labyrinthine whorls and lines, these small-scale abstract drawings in color and in black-and-white suggest rippling water, the combings of plowed land, fingerprints, the heavings and foldings of earth and ocean. Usually their intricate striations cover rectangular areas, but sometimes there are circular fields coursed by wavy, irregular edged bands of repeated colors. Among the 17 works in this small show, those in black-and-white are the more arresting. As taut and pithy as good poems, they have a rich presence (Glueck).

TOMAS SANCHEZ, Marlborough, 40 West 57th Street, (212) 541-4900 (through May 31). Making fluent use of charcoal and pastel, this Cuban-born artist evokes his country in idealized land and waterscapes -- colored and black-and-white -- in which clouds and cascades figure prominently. But their tranquillity is sometimes invaded by figures or tornadoes. Paradoxically, he also depicts vast garbage dumps that disfigure the land with masses of urban detritus. Despite the artist's proficiency, there is a frozen, static quality to these scenes. Perfect as they are descriptively, they have a stifled, lifeless quality that soon turns off the eye (Glueck).

"SCULPTURE," Grant Selwyn, 37 West 57th Street, (212) 755-0434 (through next Friday). This surprisingly good, all-star sculpture show includes two beauties by Donald Judd, one in magenta and gold, the of other buttery Cor-Ten; a vintage John Chamberlain in crumpled chrome, brick red and pink metal; a big natural sponge saturated in electric blue by Yves Klein; plastic water glasses rendered in sumptuous colored waxes, by George Stoll; and a delicate small mobile threaded through a surrealistic little chair, by Alexander Calder (Johnson).

TOM WESSELMANN, "The Great American 60's," Maxwell Davidson, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 759-7555 (through June 13). This selection of works from the 1960's includes one of the Pop Art master's classic Great American Nude apartment paintings -- real telephone and radiator included -- and seductive small studies of female body parts: pillowy lips, nubile breasts and coy painted toes (Johnson).

Galleries: Chelsea

JAY BATLLE AND PAUL PAGK, Thomas Erben, 516 West 20th Street, (212) 645-8701 (through May 31). Mr. Batlle, a sculptor, and Mr. Pagk, a painter, have extremely different sensiblities, yet somehow their dissonant meeting works. The sculptor creates ramshackle works, like a tree with sheet metal leaves that grows up through a funky wooden fire escape. The painter makes sensuous, optically subtle abstractions, in which linear patterns are embedded in fields of lush, glossy color (Johnson).

"RUDOLF BAUER, HILLA REBAY, ROLPH SCARLETT AND THE MUSEUM OF NONOBJECTIVE PAINTING," Gary Snyder, 601 West 29th Street, (212) 871-1077 (through May 31). The surprise of this exhibition is that Baroness Rebay, founding director of what became the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, was not such a bad painter. Bauer and Scarlett look like dull Kandinsky imitators, but a survey of Rebay's work on paper includes abstract watercolors that are remarkable for their richly worked, luminous personality (Johnson).

* ATUL DODIYA, "Broken Branches," Bose Pacia Modern, 508 West 26th Street, (212) 989-7074 (through May 31). The centerpiece of Mr. Dodiya's haunting New York solo debut show is an installation of nine tall glass-fronted wooden cabinets filled with well-worn objects, including old photographs, tools and handmade prosthetic limbs. The cabinets are copies of those found in a museum at Gandhi's birthplace, and the meticulously composed still lifes inside are political and personal portraits of the texture of India itself, a nation rich in social and spiritual resources but crippled by sectarian hatred. The show also includes a series of beautiful large-scale watercolors, which draw connections between India, where Mr. Dodiya lives, and the larger world (Cotter).

CHERYL DONEGAN, "Junk Space," Oliver Kamm/Apartment 5BE Gallery, 504 West 22nd Street, (212) 807-0420 (through May 31). An artist known for videos of her own improbable performances directs her attention elsewhere. "File," an eight-minute loop, is a blurry, wide-angle pan of striped fabrics and mirror reflections -- a vague, floating daydream about abstraction. The same subject matter appears in Cubistic paintings so wispy and pale they are barely there (Johnson).

MAIRA KALMAN, "Just Looking," Julie Saul, 535 West 22nd Street, (212) 627-2410 (through June 14). Ms. Kalman's sweet, sometimes mildly acerbic gouache paintings suggest Alice Neel under the influence of Indian miniature painting. Working on paper with a fine brush and cheerful colors, the prolific children's book illustrator and New Yorker cover artist (co-creator of the "Newyorkistan" map) paints goofy people in parks, portraits of famous designers' dogs and a green plastic pail captioned "Dear Bucket" (Johnson).

"KARAOKE DEATH MACHINE," Daniel Reich, 308 West 21st Street, (917) 408-9097 (through June 2). This is more like a visit to someone's tiny, dark and incredibly cluttered apartment than to a gallery exhibition; actually it is Mr. Reich's tiny, dark and incredibly cluttered apartment-cum-gallery. A stream-of-consciousness salon-style installation of more than 100 small works by more than two dozen artists as well as many images lifted directly from commercial media, the show is uneven, to say the least. But it has a grainy video copy of an early film by Niki de Saint Phalle and an excellent title (Johnson).

BLAKE RAYNE, "August Evening Walkout," Greene Naftali, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 463-7770 (through June 8). There is one lightweight knockout of a picture in this exhibition of semi-abstract paintings in a style you might call postmodern Impressionism. Across the 10-foot-wide sky-blue expanse of "Radically Casual Fridays" stretch two strings of white, green and orange pennants (like those decorating a used car lot). A merger of Pop and Color Field, it's as ephemerally perfect as a sunny spring day in New York (Johnson).

NADINE ROBINSON, "White We," Caren Golden, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 727-8304 (through May 31). In her New York gallery debut, a conceptualist known for socially provocative speaker installations sets up suggestive tensions between Modernist aesthetics and vernacular semiotics. White, the color of Modernist purity and racial supremacy, is the main signifier, as in braided ruglike circles made of white synthetic hair from which small speakers emit sounds from the movie "Mahogany." It's an obscurely fraught allegory of high-low prejudice (Johnson).

CLAUDE WAMPLER, "Vive la France," Postmasters, 459 West 19th Street, (212) 727-3323 (through May 31). When the white lights go off and the purple ones come on, sequences of fluorescent paintings of women performing modern dances appear. They disappear when the lights change again, and the exhibition quickly fades from memory once one has left the gallery (Johnson).

JIM ZIVIC, Leslie Tonkonow, 535 West 22nd Street, (212) 255-8450 (through May 31). Unlike the works of Andrea Zittel or Jorge Pardo, Mr. Zivic's industrial-chic home furnishings don't blur the line between art and design, nor are they meant to. His chocolate-brown cowhide rugs, side tables made from polished chunks of coal and seats of natural rubber have a certain sculptural panache, while remaining decidedly utilitarian (Johnson).

Galleries: SoHo

ROBERT BECK, "Once Across the Mason-Dixon," Susan Inglett, 100 Wooster Street, (212) 343-0573 (through May 31). This multimedia conceptualist has come up with a device that may sound gimmicky, but it casts a noirish spell. Looking into a classic children's toy, the View-Master, you see startlingly dimensional, photographic scenes that could be stills from a David Lynch movie: yellow-striped pavement veering into the night, a hitchhiker's extended arm, a vintage Lincoln in a field. There's no clear narrative, but there is a feeling of exhilarating dread (Johnson).

MICHAEL GOLDBERG, "Over the Moon," Lennon, Weinberg, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 941-0012 (through May 31). Mr. Goldberg's paintings of snarly, all-over line and rough patches of acidic color recall paintings from the late 1940's by Pollock and de Kooning, butthe mood is playful, comic and hedonistic rather than tragic, furious or angst-ridden. The painter sometimes overworks his canvases and they get muddy. The better ones have a looser weave in which different modes of attack are more clearly discernible, creating a bracing dissonance (Johnson).

* "THE STAGE OF DRAWING: GESTURE AND ACT," Drawing Center, 35 Wooster Street, (212) 219-2166 (through May 31). It's not easy to assemble a truly engaging show from a vast collection of drawings like that owned by England's Tate. But this one, selected by a British artist, Avis Newman, with Catherine de Zegher, director of the Drawing Center, really works. Not a tiresome institutional tour but a vividly personal one, it views drawing as "an open-ended and exploratory activity," with exhibits ranging from a 295-foot line on a roll of wrapped paper to precise renderings of 19th-century hairdos. The mix of artists runs from J. M. W. Turner to Andy Warhol; the juxtapositions reveal affinities across centuries and cultures (Glueck).

Other Galleries

ANN SPERRY, "30 Pieces/30 Years," Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion Museum, 1 West Fourth Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 824-2205 (through June 26). Since the early 1970's, Ms. Sperry has been bending, shaping and welding metal into metaphorically suggestive abstractions. The best works in this retrospective have an industrial surrealism similar to, though not as surprising as, that of Donald Lipski (Johnson).

Last Chance

* "BRONZEVILLE: BLACK CHICAGO IN PICTURES, 1941-1943," International Center of Photography, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43rd Street, (212) 857-0000 (through Sunday). For much of the early 20th century, waves of black migrants traveled from a no-hope rural South to a some-hope urban North. One of the places they went was Chicago, which with its steel mills and stockyards seemed like a good bet for finding work. There they lived for the most part in the huge enclave on the city's South Side called Bronzeville. Like New York's Harlem, for a while it was a success story; then, with the Depression, it went into decline. Now it is the subject of this exceptional, complex show of photographs made under the auspices of the Farm Security Administration in the early 1940's. Hours and admission: Tuesdays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $9; students and 62+, $6 (Cotter).

ALEXANDER CALDER, Van de Weghe, 521 West 23rd Street, Chelsea, (212) 929-6633 (through today). This sampler includes a huge mobile that is too big for the gallery's main room and a bright red nonmoving abstraction of a winged lion. Best are the smaller mobiles, some hung from the ceiling, some balanced on low structures on the floor. These harmoniously choreographed, Miroesque constellations of sweeping lines and biomorphic shapes might be Platonic models for an ecology of mind and soul (Johnson).

* "SCANNING: THE ABERRANT ARCHITECTURES OF DILLER & SCOFIDIO," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3676 (through Sunday). This retrospective of the work of Elizabeth Diller and Ricardo Scofidio, New York's brainiest architectural team, surveys 21 projects in a variety of mediums, including buildings, building additions, product designs, temporary museum installations, commercial interiors, public art and theater design. Aberrance is the last label I would slap on Diller & Scofidio, even in ironic jest. Their typical procedure is to slam opposite concepts together -- outside-inside, public-private, transparent-opaque -- and then explore the richly nuanced terrain that emerges from the overlap. Holding opposites together is a primary function of classical art, and Ms. Diller and Mr. Scofidio are classicists in this dialectical sense. The good, the true and the satirical are their stock in trade. Beauty slips in, too. Hours and admission: See above (Herbert Muschamp).

* "KURT SCHWITTERS: COLLAGES, PAINTINGS, DRAWINGS, OBJECTS, EPHEMERA," Ubu Gallery, 416 East 59th Street, (212) 753-4444 (through today). The German artist Kurt Schwitters (1887-1948) made artful arrangements of found scraps -- torn photographs, ticket stubs, labels, newspaper clips and other discarded bits -- into abstract compositions that balanced colors, forms, textures and printed matter to dazzling effect. More than 60 of his works, Dada-oriented but also much influenced by Constructivism and Russian Suprematism, are brought together here in a museum-quality display that ranges in date from before 1920 to the late 1940's. One standout in this bountiful show is a gem from 1931, "Untitled (Red, Gray, Black)," a rigorously structured composition with all the elegant trappings of Suprematism-Constructivism brilliantly translated into "Merz," Schwitters's no-meaning name for his own visual language (Glueck).

JOAN SEMMEL, Mitchell Algus, 511 West 25th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-6242 (through tomorrow). Ms. Semmel made an enduring name for herself in feminist art history with paintings of her naked body viewed from her own subjective perspective. In new paintings, based on images of the artist with a camera taking her own photograph in a mirror, her nude self, painted with matter-of-fact realism, is considerably matured. One thinks of John Coplans's photographs of his own aging, corpulent body (Johnson).

AMY SILLMAN, Brent Sikkema, 530 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (212) 929-2262 (through Wednesday). The artist brings her unconscious to the canvas in fanciful, watery, half-abstract, half-readable images that conjure up dreamlike lands and beings in a seemingly narrative flow. Boats, water, semblances of people with pipestem limbs and balloon heads, creatures and ghosts of creatures, wayward lines and markings together with descriptive ones, bursts of activity and empty passages inhabit these ephemeral works, welding some discernible influences into a language of the artist's own. Enshrining the artist's every wayward mood and thought, the work comes off as more than a little glib, not to say loosey-goosey. Still, with its bubbleheaded beings and oddities of place and event, it's not without charm (Glueck).

GRAPHIC: Photos: Large detail from "Painting by the Window" (circa late 1950's), by Sally Michel, from "Sally Michel, Milton Avery" at Knoedler uptown. (Knoedler & Company); At the Met: third-century B.C. item from "Art of the First Cities." (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: HAVENS; 
A House for the Summer? Rents Drop Around the Nation

BYLINE:  By WALECIA KONRAD

 BODY:
STILL haven't found a place for the summer? You're in luck. The economy has devastated much of the seasonal rental market around the country, which means there are great houses left for procrastinators. Whether you are looking for the whole season or just a week or two, homeowners out there are panicking. They want to make a deal.
 The reason for the downturn, say real estate agents from coast to coast, is as simple as supply and demand. Sales of second homes in popular vacation communities like Martha's Vineyard in Massachusetts and the Hamptons in New York have exploded in the last three years. Buyers, looking for investments more stable than the troubled stock market, are taking advantage of record low mortgage rates. But this new crop of second-home owners are buying at peak prices, and many count on renting their new houses at least part of the season to help cover the mortgage and taxes. 
 The result is an increase in available rentals, just as worries over terrorism, the economy and job security have made potential renters jittery and indecisive. 
Here is a look at what is still available in popular vacation spots near four major cities, as of yesterday.

New York
In years past, the best of the Hamptons summer rentals were locked up just after the Presidents' Day weekend. Anyone who waited until May could still find something, usually the dregs -- old houses, shabby interiors, bad locations. But last year renters didn't show up until May, often picking up great houses for reduced prices from desperate landlords.
This year, after a disastrous Presidents' Day blizzard and a generally cold and nasty spring, renters waited even longer to make decisions. "This past weekend things finally picked up and now we've just about caught up with last year," said Diane Saatchi, the president of Dayton-Halstead Real Estate in East Hampton. "But before that we were having a lot of trouble getting homeowners and renters to make a deal."
Lower prices help. A one-story contemporary in East Hampton, with air-conditioning and a heated pool a block from the bay, was recently reduced from $36,000 for the season to $29,000, according to Bill Williams, an agent in the East Hampton office of Devlin McNiff Real Estate. Mr. Williams said the number of rental houses available in his area has grown 10 percent to 15 percent in the last two years. As a result, "really good houses are still available," he said. "And homeowners are still calling me asking to list their property." Another desirable house that is still available: a large four-bedroom on fashionable Huntting Lane in East Hampton, for $75,000 for July and August. "Normally something that nice would have been long gone, even at this price," Mr. Williams said.
The scene is the same on Fire Island. "It's much slower this year," said Bonnie Nolter, an agent with Red Wagon Realty in Ocean Beach who has several rentals still available for the season and for July and August. Last-minute bargain hunters can also find rentals in Saltaire. That is because the village has an ordinance against outdoor grilling, a rule that has become an issue in today's mayoral and trustee election. "If I have a prospective tenant, they would just as soon rent a house in another community rather than forgo barbecuing," said Grace Corradino, who owns Fire Island Living, a real estate company. As a result, she has a three-bedroom, two-bath house on the bay for the month of August available for $25,000 and a three-bedroom, one-bath cottage available for two weeks in August for $7,000.
In the Berkshire Mountains, renters have also been slow to sign contracts, said Scott Sawyer, an agent with Stone House Properties in Stockbridge, Mass. Houses usually rent for July and August and can cost anywhere from $2,500 a month for a small country cottage to $25,000 a month for the 7,000-square-foot estate house with mountain views that is still available. A three-bedroom contemporary with a guest apartment is still open for July and August for $12,000 a month, and a three-bedroom, two-and-a-half-bath house is available for July and August at $8,500 a month.

Boston
Real estate agents on Cape Cod and Martha's Vineyard, two of the most popular beach destinations for Bostonians and other Massachusetts residents, are biting their fingernails wondering when the summer rental season is going to start in earnest. Like the Hamptons, Cape Cod is seeing plenty of empty houses and very few renters. "We've got a book of listings sitting here three or four inches thick," said Sheila Bolton, a broker with Foley Real Estate in Falmouth, Mass., last week. "I recently got a phone call from a homeowner who was desperately looking to rent the house she had just bought this year. I had to tell her that I've never seen it this bad."
Why the market collapse? "Some people blame the economy or the war; if it isn't one thing it's another," Ms. Bolton said. "Personally I think people have gotten greedy in the past few years and jacked up the prices too much."
That may be about to change. Ms. Bolton and other Cape Cod real estate agents estimate that homeowners are negotiating up to 20 percent off last year's rates. A five-bedroom, two-bath beachfront house, for example, is booked for all of August and part of July partly because its $3,500 weekly rate is less than last year's rate.
Prices are also dropping on Martha's Vineyard. Susanne Faraca, an agent at Kelleher Real Estate in West Tisbury, said she recently showed a potential renter several homes. "The woman was interested in several, but then came back to me and said she found a homeowner willing to take $800 off of her $4,800 two-week rental. That's a big discount. I couldn't match it."
Ms. Faraca said she had about a third more rental houses in her inventory than she did last year at this time. On the Vineyard, the increase is mainly attributed to a growing number of full-time residents who, watching property values skyrocket, decided to cash out. They sell to someone who needs the rent to cover the purchase costs and suddenly there are a lot more rentals on the market. "I might have a fabulous house on the water," Ms. Faraca said. "But guess what? Now there are 30 of those fabulous houses on the water. Five years ago there were only 15." For example, a five-bedroom house on the ocean with its own dock in Oak Bluff is available for all of July for $7,500 a week. Off the water, a three-bedroom in Vineyard Haven a short walk from town is available almost all summer for $2,300 a week.
If Cape Cod's legendary traffic jams and the Vineyard ferry schedule are not your thing, there are also plenty of rentals available in Mount Washington Valley in the White Mountains of New Hampshire. Susie McDougal, a broker at Coldwell Banker Wright Realty in the village of Conway, N.H., said the rental market was "slower than usual but not worrisome." Seasonal rentals have picked up in recent weeks, she said. Ms. McDougal said she did have one attractive listing left, a three-bedroom with a deck, a sun porch and a large yard available from June 17 to Sept. 15 for $6,000. Meanwhile, there are plenty of weekly rentals available. They range from $600 for a woodlands cabin to $1,200 for a house on Silver Lake. "We try to keep it affordable," Ms. McDougal said. "That's part of why people come here."

Washington
For decades, people have escaped the summer heat of Washington and Baltimore by flocking to the Delaware and Maryland beaches. Until about three years ago the best of the weekly rentals in the Delaware towns of Rehoboth Beach, Dewey Beach and Bethany Beach and in Ocean City, Md., were snapped up by April, said Jim Waggoner, director of resort rentals at Long & Foster, a real estate and rental management company with more than 1,200 rental properties in Delaware beach towns. "But now the trend is to book later and later," he said. Mr. Waggoner said rentals were down anywhere from 9 percent to 20 percent from last year in his areas in the beginning of May, with the exception of Rehoboth Beach, which was running about even with last year. A flurry of activity in the last two weeks has brought those numbers up. As of yesterday, bookings in most areas had caught up to last year's and in Rehoboth Beach they were actually higher than at this time last year. Prices throughout the area, he said, are not declining, but they have stopped rising.
"During most of the 1990's, homeowners increased their rents 10 to 12 percent a year," Mr. Waggoner said. "Now, with this economy, that's over."
Available weekly rentals in Rehoboth Beach range from a seven-bedroom, five-and-a-half-bath house a block from the ocean for $4,500 to a five-bedroom, two-bath cottage in a woodland area for $2,400 a week, to a two-bedroom, two-and-a-half-bath condominium six blocks from the beach for $850 a week.

Chicago
The brightest spot in this informal survey is Door County, Wis. Located on the easternmost point of the state, Door County is a peninsula surrounded by Green Bay and Lake Michigan that draws summer visitors mainly from the Chicago and Milwaukee areas. The rental business is actually better than it was last year, according to Andrea Lundquist, owner of Lundquist Realty and Vacation Rentals. She said that reservations were up about 10 percent and that prices were about the same as last year.
Door County covers a lot of ground, however, with almost 500 square miles and 250 miles of shore, and has housing that ranges from condos to estates. So there are still some rentals available. A three-bedroom, three-bath house called the Beach Road House, in Sister Bay, still has five weeks open in July and August. It is on a bluff overlooking the water and rents for $2,200 a week. The Elm Log Cabin (houses tend to have names in Door County), in Egg Harbor but away from the water, sleeps five comfortably and rents for $800 a week.

GRAPHIC: Photos: EAST HAMPTON -- This four-bedroom house rents for $75,000 for July and August.; DOOR COUNTY, WIS. -- The Elm Log Cabin sleeps five and rents for $800 a week.; THE BERKSHIRES -- For $25,000 a month, 7,000 square feet with mountain views.; A RENTER'S MARKET -- Prospective tenants have been waiting to make decisions about rental properties in the Hamptons this summer. (Gordon M. Grant for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: HAVENS; 
For Summer Renters, Procrastination Pays

 BODY:
 IF you haven't found a summer rental yet, whether it's a cottage by the beach or a cabin in the mountains, you may be in luck. 
Largely because of the bleak economy and a glut of rental properties, there are a number of reasonably priced houses still available. A report on the summer rental market in the resort communities of the Hamptons, Fire Island, Cape Cod, the Berkshires, Martha's Vineyard, the Maryland and Delaware shores and Lake Michigan. Page 6.

HEADLINE: McDonald's Chief Stresses Food Safety 

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY 

DATELINE: OAK BROOK, Ill., May 22 

 BODY:
In his first face-to-face meeting with shareholders, James R. Cantalupo, McDonald's new chief executive, tried today to play down concerns about mad cow disease in Canada and focus instead on his plan to revitalize the McDonald's brand.
 "McDonald's has tremendous experience in food safety," said Mr. Cantalupo, addressing shareholders at McLodge, a hotel on McDonald's corporate campus here. "We have a proven track record in dealing with concerns like this." 
 In recent years, sales at McDonald's restaurants in Japan and Europe fell sharply after outbreaks of mad cow disease. But so far, the company said, sales at North American operations do not appear to be affected by the discovery of a single case of the disease in a dead cow in Alberta. In Canada, McDonald's said sales increased a few percentage points at its restaurants on Wednesday, the day after the announcement.
Mr. Cantalupo, who worked at McDonald's for 27 years, came out of retirement in January to succeed Jack M. Greenberg. Because his predecessor was unable to reverse slumping sales, Mr. Cantalupo has focused much of his efforts since then on rebuilding the McDonald's brand. Like many burger chains, McDonald's has had declining sales in recent years as consumers have begun to favor healthier food, upscale restaurants and ethnic food.
To reignite interest in McDonald's, which though struggling is still the No. 1 hamburger chain in the nation, Mr. Cantalupo and his management team have pledged to slow the building of restaurants in favor of cultivating relationships with new and old customers. The goal, Mr. Cantalupo told shareholders, is to significantly improve customer service, food offerings and the overall cleanliness and appearance of restaurants. While some of the McDonald's menu will be eliminated, several products will be added, including McGriddles, which are breakfast pancake sandwiches. The company is also trying to shed its image as a purveyor of unhealthy food with new premium salads topped with warm chicken and Newman's Own salad dressing and healthier Happy Meals for children, which are available in some countries with the option of milk and sugarless juice instead of soda, and miniature bags of fresh fruit. 
The company will also reorganize its marketing campaigns to include greater participation from Ronald McDonald, update its hamburger seasonings and buns and trim operating costs by installing automatic beverage machines and self-ordering kiosks, executives said. 
Mr. Cantalupo also renewed his pledge to achieve 3 percent to 5 percent growth in sales and a 6 percent to 7 percent increase in operating income by 2005. He said the company would buy back shares and increase the dividend. 
After his presentation, shareholders used the time allocated for questions to offer suggestions on improving the everyday coffee and introducing specialty coffee shops in some stores.
Among the questions was one on how the company was being affected by severe acute respiratory syndrome. Mr. Cantalupo said only a small percentage of McDonald's business was in markets that had been affected by SARS. Business in those markets was rebounding, he said.
Mr. Cantalupo also sought to dispel rumors that the company's partner brands, Chipotle Mexican Grill, Boston Market and Donatos Pizzeria, are on the auction block.
"There's no for-sale signs on the partner brands," said Mr. Cantalupo, who insisted that the company was performing a strategic review of its entire business. "Everything is on the table, and we're looking at everything. We continue to do that."
Bob Ryan, a shareholder who worked as a McDonald's executive with Ray Kroc, the company's founder, was pleased. "This guy's really got the right idea," Mr. Ryan said of Mr. Cantalupo, adding, "I think we're on the right track." Mr. Ryan said that Mr. Cantalupo was following the ideas of the company's founders. Other shareholders doubted that Mr. Cantalupo would be able to return McDonald's to performance results it achieved in its heyday.
"If he's been in the company for 30 years, why is the situation the way it is now," Judith M. Koenick, a retired teacher from Maryland, said of Mr. Cantalupo and his plans. "Do I really think it's going to be any different? I'm not sure." Ms. Koenick came to the meeting to complain about dirty restrooms and the misuse of handicap parking spaces at her local McDonald's.
Analysts said it was too early to tell whether Mr. Cantalupo would be successful and if McDonald's, which said sales at stores open at least a year improved in April, is in the midst of a true turnaround.
"The question is, is he taking the right actions and is he taking them rapidly enough to achieve that kind of a turnaround in two years," said Darrell K. Rigby, the director of global retail at Bain & Company. "I have not yet seen the operating milestones that will allow outsiders to track whether he's on that path or not yet."

HEADLINE: Phone Companies See Their Future In Flat-Rate Plans Of Many Services 

BYLINE:  By NICHOLAS THOMPSON 

 BODY:
Fifteen years ago, Arthur C. Clarke in the science-fiction novel "2061: Odyssey Three" predicted a future as follows: "With the historic abolition of long-distance charges on 31 December 2000, every telephone call became a local one, and the human race greeted the new millennium by transforming itself into one huge, gossiping family."
 That future may be at hand, only a few years behind schedule, as a result of the telephone industry's declining economic fortunes, increasing competition and recent technological advances. Starting with MCI, which introduced its Neighborhood plan in April 2002, most leading phone companies -- AT&T, BellSouth, Qwest Communications, SBC Communications and Verizon -- have rolled out programs that allow customers in some states to make unlimited local and national calls for one flat monthly price. 
 These unlimited-use plans offer callers the advantage of predictability and less time spent checking monthly bills. They commonly cost $50 to $60 a month with services like voice mail and caller ID bundled in, making the price only slightly higher than the $48 that American households typically spend on local and long-distance calling, according to the Federal Communications Commission. 
The introduction of the flat-rate plan at MCI, formerly WorldCom, a company currently going through bankruptcy proceedings, is "exceeding expectations," according to a spokeswoman, Claire Hassett.
A spokesman for Verizon, Jim Smith, calls his company's program a "ripping success." 
Such positive responses from customers are good news for an industry that faces a number of incipient threats, including the loss of market share to calls made over the Internet, cellphone-addicted young customers who spurn land lines, and families who swap their second telephone lines for high-speed Internet connections. 
In its last quarterly statement, Verizon, for example, reported that its total telecommunications revenue was down 3 percent but that its bundled plans had helped prevent a greater loss.
Jeffrey Kagan, an Atlanta-based telecommunications analyst, calls the unlimited plans "the defibrillator for the industry." 
The move toward unlimited access plans stems from the Telecommunications Act of 1996, which created a regulatory process that allowed local phone companies to enter the long-distance market.
It has taken years for these companies, the so-called Baby Bells, to win federal approval in many areas, and they can now offer long-distance service in 41 states and the District of Columbia.
Over all, the Bell companies provide about 16 percent of residential long-distance service, according to the F.C.C.
In the meantime, the long-distance carriers -- which hold about 9 percent of the local service market, according to the New Paradigm Resources Group, a Chicago-based research firm -- are hoping that unlimited bundled programs will enhance their business. MCI, for example, provides 3.5 million customers with local service, but 2 million of those are signed up with its Neighborhood plan.
The Bells and the long-distance companies both see growth in bundled plans, made possible by technology and changing consumer habits, as a way to secure market share. 
Most calls now travel most of their journey over fiber optic lines that connect the whole country. A company's expense in routing a call depends very little on the distance the call travels, but largely on whether a call needs to travel across lines owned by other phone companies and the access fees charged for that use. In most cases, calling a friend across the country now costs your phone company about as much as calling your next-door neighbor. 
New customer habits also make selling unlimited plans easier. Consumers have become accustomed to paying a flat fee for other services like cable television, regardless of whether they watch it 3 or 30 hours a week. 
For generations, telephone companies have billed calls individually, taking into account both the geographical distance between those talking and the length of the call. But with the wireless phone industry selling plans with unlimited access, customers have become used to flexible plans and have started to demand them from their land-line providers.
"Wireless plans started to tear down the thinking of distance-dependent calling," says Charles Golvin, a senior analyst with Forrester Research. 
For phone companies, bundled plans create a predictable revenue flow and decrease the paperwork involved in separate billing systems and itemized phone bills. The plans have not been around long enough to show how they affect the churn rate, the percentage of a company's clients who leave for a competitor during a given period. Still, managers of most companies think that customers who buy these packages are more loyal.
"It's human nature," said Eileen Connolly, a spokeswoman for AT&T. "People have less desire to move away from you if you have all their business." 
The companies are also hoping that these customers will be more likely to buy other bundled services -- like cellular, digital subscriber lines for connecting to the Internet, and other future services.
The bundling strategy is particularly important as cable companies start to offer phone service along with high-speed Internet access. Mr. Smith of Verizon said he did not worry about customers who may end up paying less under unlimited-use plans than under standard plans. "We'll end up selling them more sooner or later," he said.
No one is certain how customer use will change as people switch to these plans. But evidence from other industries suggests that it will increase significantly. "Usage more than doubles on unlimited wireless-calling plans," said Berge Ayvazian, a senior research fellow at The Yankee Group, a market research firm, "and if broadband is always on, the Internet is always in use."
But there will be a limit, of course. There are only 24 hours in a day and unlimited-use plans for cellphones, land lines and broadband Internet access will all be competing for consumer time.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate; 
Market-Rate Rents Continue Downturn

BYLINE:  By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
Rents for market-rate apartments in and around New York City have continued to slip this year, according to rental brokers and landlords, but not as steeply as they had during their nose dive from a breath-catching peak two years ago.
 "It's not good for landlords, but it's certainly good for people entering the rental market," said James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University. 
 Dr. Hughes pointed out that along with the city's loss of more than 200,000 jobs since the start of the recession in 2001, a key factor in the rental market has been a 40-year low for mortgage interest rates. "That makes owning much more affordable and undercuts the rental market," he said. 
"There certainly has been slippage," said Nancy Packes, president of Halstead/Feathered Nest Leasing Consultants, which markets new buildings. According to its year-end report, the average rent for studios in Manhattan below 96th Street was $1,705 in December, down 16.2 percent from their peak of $2,036 at midyear 2001. After surveying about 200 leases handled by her company so far this year, Ms. Packes said the average for studios now stands at $1,680, down 1.47 percent since December. 
In the one-bedroom category, the average Manhattan rent was $2,331 in December, down 18.4 percent from a high of $2,859 at the end of 2000. "And since January, the average has been $2,290," Ms. Packes said, a 1.76 percent slip since December. 
For two bedrooms, the average was $3,527 at the end of 2002, down 19.8 percent from $4,400 at the end of 2000. "So far this year the average has been $3,375, down $148, or 4.31 percent" since December, Ms. Packes said. 
A similar pattern was reflected in statistics gathered by Citi Habitats, a Manhattan brokerage firm that says it handles about 8,000 leases a year. According to Citi Habitats, the average rent for studios during April was $1,574, down 3.1 percent from $1,624 last December, and down 13 percent from the peak of $1,810 in April 2001. 
Rents for one-bedroom apartments averaged $2,200 in April, the report said, down 3.6 percent from $2,284 in December and 15.2 percent from $2,596 two years ago. For two bedrooms, the average was $3,350 in April, barely up from $3,344 in December, but down 16.6 percent from $4,020 in April 2001. And for three bedrooms, the average in April was $4,291, up 2.9 percent from $4,170 in December, but down 18.6 percent from $5,277 in February 2001. 
Pointing to the traditional boost in the market as college graduates seek work and rental housing in the city, Andrew Heiberger, the president of Citi Habitats, said, "I think the market has found its bottom." 
But Christopher Thomas, president for Brooklyn at the William B. May Company, was not so optimistic. "We have about 20 percent more inventory now than we had at this time last year, and that brings rents down," Mr. Thomas said. "There's so much vacancy because there's so much market-rate rental construction in Manhattan that still hasn't been absorbed." 
Mr. Thomas said that his company's statistics for Brooklyn Heights and Cobble Hill show that "rents for studios this year have ranged from $1,100 to $1,600; last year, they were $1,250 to $1,800." 
"For one-bedrooms," he said, "it's $1,300 to $3,000 this year; a year ago, $1,450 to $3,500. And two-bedroom apartments are currently $1,900 to $5,000; last year, $2,200 to $5,500."
Gerard Longo, president of Madison Estates and Properties in Brooklyn, said: "A one-bedroom in Park Slope that was renting for close to $2,000 two years ago is now around $1,800. A two-bedroom on Shore Road in Bay Ridge gets $2,800, down from $3,100 two years ago. And now we would even take $2,700." 
Across the Hudson River, along what some people now refer to as New Jersey's "gold coast," the Lefrak Organization owns 10 rental buildings with about 4,000 apartments. "Our rents went through big fluctuations after Sept. 11," said Jamie LeFrak, the company's executive vice president. "It came down and then stabilized." 
Currently, studios in those Lefrak buildings are renting for $1,250 to $1,350. "At their peak, they were maybe 5 percent more," Mr. LeFrak said. One-bedrooms range from $1,500 to $1,850, and were "7 or 8 percent higher at their peak, during the summer before Sept. 11," he said. "And two-bedrooms sort of follow, $1,850 to $2,400, down from $2,000 to $2,600."
Putting it in perspective, Dr. Hughes at Rutgers said: "We're coming off rents that were propelled to artificial heights during the boom years. So, in that sense, they are returning to more realistic levels."

HEADLINE: THE SARS EPIDEMIC: ECONOMIC FALLOUT; 
Market for Chinese-American Delicacy Plummets

BYLINE:  By DEAN E. MURPHY 

DATELINE: MODESTO, Calif., May 17 

 BODY:
For many Chinese-Americans, no wedding banquet is complete without a serving of squab, a young pigeon that is slaughtered before it can fly. The tender meat symbolizes a lifetime of peace for the newlyweds and eating a bird represents being set free by their parents.
 For decades, sales have soared among squab farmers here in central California, home to the country's largest squab cooperative. Every week, the cooperative sends three refrigerator trucks to San Francisco's Chinatown, the biggest in the West. 
 "It is an expensive dish that when I was a child, we couldn't even afford," said David Deng, a chef in San Francisco.
But these days, the delivery trucks are rarely filled. More and more of the birds are packed away in cold storage at a processing plant here. The problem is not with the squabs, but with the empty restaurants in many Chinatowns across the West because of the fear of severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS.
California has had more cases of SARS than any other state, with 68 suspect or probable cases reported by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. 
"We have double the number of birds in the freezer today than we did a year ago," Bob Shipley, president of the cooperative, the Squab Producers of California, said in a telephone interview. "I have been involved for 23 years, and it is the most severe hit I have ever seen."
For nearly two months, all types of Chinatown businesses have reported big drops in foot traffic because of SARS. Much attention has focused on losses by establishments that cater to tourists, with busloads of out-of-town visitors skirting Chinatowns. 
But the specialty market in squab, a dish not always popular with tourists, has been among the hardest hit in places like San Francisco and Los Angeles. It seems many Chinese-Americans are avoiding Chinatowns and doing without the delicacy.
"Everything dropped," said Michael Lau, a salesman at the Sun Duck Market in San Francisco's Chinatown, which counts 30 restaurants among its customers. "Even vegetables dropped."
Mr. Shipley said the squab cooperative had been successfully courting new customers, especially some expensive specialty restaurants where the bird has become a popular novelty item.
Poultry shops outside traditional Chinatowns also seem less affected by the slump, apparently because of the missing specter of SARS. Some of the market has also been sustained by the Chinese belief that eating the bird, which is typically deep fried, roasted or boiled in soup, has health benefits, including helping women become pregnant. 
But so far there are still more squabs than buyers, Mr. Shipley said.
"We had customers who didn't miss a Wednesday delivery for 20 years," he said, adding that since SARS emerged, "at one point, we didn't even send out a truck because nobody ordered."
"Is it catastrophic?," he asked. "No. Am I concerned? Yes, if it continues."
Outside Ming Kee Game Birds, a butcher shop in San Francisco, the owner, Stella Gong, tried to drum up business by shouting at passers-by, "Squabs -- $12 for two!"
Her shop offers live birds as well as frozen ones, including some from the cooperative here in Modesto. "Because there are a lot fewer customers, I have to reduce prices and canvass for business," Ms. Gong said.
Before the SARS outbreak in China, Ms. Gong said she would typically take delivery of 300 squabs a week. She would then sell most of them to restaurants in Chinatown. But this week, she said, she ordered just 175. And in a recurring sign of the times, she received a telephone call asking if she would deliver some of the birds out of town, this time an hour's drive across San Francisco Bay.
"I ask them why don't they come themselves," Ms. Gong said. "They said that they are really scared to come to Chinatown."
Mr. Lau, the Sun Duck Market salesman, said Mother's Day was a good indication of how bad the downturn had been. The holiday, he said, is typically big for squab sales, as Chinese-American families take their mothers out for dinner or splurge for a special meal at home.
But Mr. Lau said his shop sold only 25 birds this Mother's Day weekend, compared with 75 to 100 in previous years. "I know restaurants are putting money out of their pockets just to get by," Mr. Lau said.
The squab's problems have come at a difficult time for the poultry industry in California. Bill Mattos, president of the California Poultry Federation, said squab had been one of the exports hardest hit by restrictions imposed by Canada on poultry from the state.
The Canadians imposed the restrictions because of an outbreak of exotic Newcastle disease among chickens in Southern California. The poultry federation is trying to get Canadian officials to accept poultry from other parts of the state, like Modesto, where there have been no reports of the disease.
"The squab producers have always had a shortage," Mr. Mattos said. "This is the first time they have more than needed. They will get it sold, they just have to find another home for it."
Mr. Shipley said that sales had been slowly picking up and that he suspected that the worst was over. "I am trying to stay as optimistic as I can," he said. 
Though he would not disclose sales information about the cooperative, the 77-member farms and their main competitor, the Palmetto Pigeon Plant in Sumter, S.C., are said to account for about half of the squabs sold in the United States. Annual estimates of squab sales are two million to three million.
Tony Barwick, president of the South Carolina company, said squab farmers on the East Coast were not experiencing the Modesto farmers' problems because most Chinatowns in the East had recovered from the initial SARS scare.
"Right now, we are selling every squab we produce," Mr. Barwick said by telephone. "The West Coast is different. You have all that Vancouver traffic coming down, and all that air traffic from Asia. They always feel it worse."
But like many things related to the SARS outbreak, squab sellers across the country worry about the voracious rumor mill. One bad rumor, many fear, could send the squab industry everywhere back to mid-April, when deliveries to some Chinatowns came to a near halt.
Though a scientist from Canada this weekend told a gathering of the World Health Organization in Geneva that there was no evidence that animals were spreading SARS, there had been unsubstantiated rumors that eating certain foods could expose people to the virus.
When the Chinese news media first reported that possibility, some seafood shops in San Francisco had to throw away rotting fish for lack of sales, Ms. Gong said.

HEADLINE: Study Says China Is Decades Behind U.S. in Military Power 

BYLINE:  By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
Despite its growing economic power, China is at least two decades behind the United States in military technology and ability, according to a report released yesterday by the Council on Foreign Relations.
 The report also says that China is far from becoming a global military power, and that the United States would ultimately prevail if a conflict over Taiwan broke out with China. 
 While China has the world's largest standing army and continues to acquire advanced weapons systems, the task force said China did not have enough advanced equipment to rival the United States. 
"There is a significant group of people out there who say that China is going to be a military super power and it will be an adversary to the United States. And it may well turn out that way, but not in the near future," said Harold Brown, who served as Secretary of Defense under President Jimmy Carter and was a member of the task force that drafted the report. Other members included John M. Deutch, a former director of central intelligence, and Thomas S. Foley, a former speaker of the House of Representatives.
In recent years, some military experts have warned that China poses an imminent threat to the sovereignty of Taiwan. Those experts fear that the United States is underestimating China's military strength and China's resolve to reunify Taiwan with mainland China, possibly through a surprise military attack.
The report took issue with those theories, saying that even though China has become a center for software and semiconductor research and its acquisition of advanced weapons systems should not be underestimated, the United States clearly has superior air, naval and technological power. It added that this military lead could last for decades.
The task force also said it was unlikely that China would attack Taiwan. The Chinese military buildup, the task force said, was more likely a way to coerce Taiwan into negotiating reunification.
Critics, however, denounced the report, saying that it underestimated how rapidly China was modernizing its military capabilities and positioning itself to dominate the South China Sea.
"It's sort of a feel-good report," says John Tkacik, a fellow at the Heritage Foundation in Washington. "It doesn't jibe with a Pentagon report last year. And it's a mistake to underestimate the Chinese ability to amass a high quality military force close to their shores."
Many military experts believe that China is seeking to dominate the region. They say China spends an estimated $60 billion a year on its military, second only to the United States.
Some experts want the United States to help strengthen Taiwan's military, and to be prepared for a defense or rescue mission.
Richard D. Fisher Jr., a visiting fellow at the Center for Security Policy in Washington, also said the report missed the point about Taiwan.
"The basic purpose of the report is to convey that there is not yet enough Chinese power to threaten American security interests at this time. But China doesn't need American-level military technology to beat us to the punch in Taiwan."
Members of the task force, however, said their findings were not cause for alarm, but for a more calm, judicious response, since China does not yet appear to be capable of matching American military might.

HEADLINE: House Passes Bill Extending Aid to Jobless By 13 Weeks 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 22 

 BODY:
The House overwhelmingly passed a bill tonight to extend jobless benefits by 13 weeks for workers who exhaust their state benefits this year. Those workers' benefits would have begun expiring next week under current law.
 The proposal would both help many of the nation's large number of long-term unemployed workers and could muffle Democratic attempts to use the issue for political advantage. After criticizing Republicans in recent weeks as eager to cut taxes for the affluent but reluctant to extend unemployment benefits, Democrats said today that the measure did not go far enough but that they would support it. 
 The Senate is expected to take up the measure on Friday, and President Bush supports it, Claire Buchan, a White House spokeswoman said. The bill passed the House 409 to 19 with only Republicans opposing it. 
At a $7.9 billion cost, the extension will affect the 2.1 million workers who will exhaust their state unemployment benefits, which typically last 26 weeks, from June 1 to the end of the year, according to a Congressional estimate. The government will recover about $1.4 billion in taxes paid on the benefits.
The bill does not extend benefits for workers who have already used up their state benefits and the federal benefits they have received as part of one of the two extensions enacted since last year.
"When you're experiencing job weakness, it's a time when you want to be temporarily generous," Representative Jennifer Dunn, Republican of Washington, said today, repeating a phrase used on Wednesday by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, in describing his view of the ideal unemployment-insurance system. "But you do not want to create a program where people lean on unemployment" insurance.
"You want people to go out and get jobs," she said.
Ms. Dunn, a sponsor of the bill, was among the moderate House Republicans who pushed for the extension, which had broader support in the Senate.
The nation is in its worst hiring slump in 20 years, with more than two million jobs lost since employment peaked in March 2001. At 6 percent, the jobless rate remains lower than it was during other recent downturns, but many of the job losers of the last two years have remained out of work for months. 
The portion of unemployment-insurance recipients who exhausted their state benefits recently reached 43 percent, its highest level on record, according to the Labor Department. 
The average benefit is now about $260 a week, according to the National Employment Law Project, which represents jobless workers. 
For unemployed workers in six states considered to be particularly hard hit by the economic slowdown, the bill would provide an extension of 26 weeks, rather than 13. The six states, designated under a complicated formula, are Alaska, Connecticut, Massachusetts, Oregon, Pennsylvania and Washington. 
Democrats criticized the formula, saying that it excludes workers in states with some of the highest unemployment rates in the country, like California, Michigan and Utah.
Some also said the extensions for all states should be longer than 13 weeks, as they were during the downturn of the early 1990's. In the House and Senate, Democrats have proposed a 26-week extension, saying it would help more than one million people who have already exhausted their federal benefits.
"They're really not dealing with a significant part of the problem," Representative Benjamin L. Cardin, Democrat of Maryland, said of Republicans. "People can't get jobs. It's not like they're not looking." 
Ms. Dunn said Congress would extend benefits again if the economy did not improve in the coming months. 
In his testimony on Wednesday before the Congressional Joint Economic Committee, Mr. Greenspan praised jobless benefits but said extensions should be kept brief to give people an incentive to find new jobs.
Under the most recent extension, which Mr. Bush signed in January, workers who exhausted their state benefits before May 31 were eligible for an additional 13 weeks of payments. The House bill would push the deadline to Dec. 31.

HEADLINE: There Is Enough Electricity For Summer Cooling, if . . . 

BYLINE:  By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
As people in and around New York City prepare to rev up their air-conditioners, the electricity industry says there will be enough power to keep all that cool air pumping all summer. Probably. Unless something happens. Like it gets really hot.
 A report released yesterday by the organization that operates the state's high-voltage power system said that the supply of electricity in the city should be "marginally adequate" if temperatures are normal. 
 But the organization, the New York Independent System Operator, warned of problems if there is "a repeat of the 2002 summer heat waves, or increased generation and/or transmission outages."
At a news conference yesterday, William J. Museler, the president of the system operator, said, "New York City does have what it needs, but it does not have any excess."
A similar warning was sounded earlier this month by the North American Electric Reliability Council, a related national electricity group. It said that while the rest of the country has enough power to meet its needs, that is not necessarily the case in southwestern Connecticut, New York City and Long Island.
In the metropolitan region, transmission systems cannot easily bring in all the power needed, and the amount of power generated within the area is also limited. So while local utilities try to develop long-term solutions, their spokesmen said in interviews, they are relying on various stopgap measures to squeak through the summer surge in demand for power.
The Long Island Power Authority, for example, is adding another small generating plant this summer, its fifth in two years, said Richard M. Kessel, the authority's chairman. It also has several programs to cut residential and business power use during peak times.
So while the situation on Long Island is better than it was a couple of years ago, he said, "the worry is that if you have an extremely hot summer and a major piece of equipment goes down, things are going to be extremely tight."
Little more than a year ago, some energy experts were saying that the city and surrounding areas had all the power they needed, and more. Those forecasts were based in part on the assumption that the softening economy would mute any increases in the demand for power.
It did not quite work out that way. Last summer, power use in New York City set a record of almost 17.5 million megawatt hours, an increase of almost 4 percent from the previous year, according to Consolidated Edison.
And demand is likely to continue to increase this year, said Michael Clendenin, a Con Ed spokesman. "Our load-growth forecast is 250 megawatts above last year's peak," he said, adding that the increase was being driven by a growing number of air-conditioners, an increase in housing units and population, and perhaps a decline in summer travel.
The company said it would meet its regulatory requirement to be able to provide 8,816 megawatts in the city, but only by using programs that induce big power consumers to cut back when necessary. The rest of the power the city needs -- at its all-time peak last July 3 it used 12,086 megawatts -- flows into the city from other areas over transmission lines.
While there were several blackouts in parts of the city last summer, Mr. Clendenin said those were not related to supply shortages, but were caused by equipment problems
The tight supply of power may also help drive up electricity prices, some industry experts said. "The entire state of Connecticut is seeing it," said Frank Poirot, a spokesman for Connecticut Light and Power. The price increases, he said, are coming from new "congestion charges," which penalize utilities -- and ultimately consumers -- for inadequate transmission capacity.
The company is adding two generators and installing new technology. But, Mr. Poirot added, "If one transmission line goes out on a hot day, if one power plant goes down, we could find ourselves in serious trouble."
