HEADLINE: Sports of The Times; 
As the 'Next Jordan,' Should James Try to Be Unlike Mike?

BYLINE:  By HARVEY ARATON 

 BODY:
ONE day after news of LeBron James's staggering Nike deal worth a reported $90 million, America's most famous consumer advocate was wondering what the "next Michael Jordan" was going to give back.
 "People say it's unfair to burden an 18-year-old with demands of social consciousness," Ralph Nader said yesterday from his office in Washington. "My answer is that he's not getting an 18-year-old's salary. This contract proves he has enormous bargaining power, a superstar's physical image." 
 When Nader and his sports consumer advocacy group, the League of Fans, wrote James and his agent, Aaron Goodwin, last month, it was a gentle prodding to bargain for third-world workers, to avoid becoming the next Michael Jordan. 
"You are on the verge of choosing to immerse yourself in the world of international commerce," Nader wrote of James's negotiations with the merchandising giants Nike, Reebok and Adidas, "which inevitably brings with it a wide array of complicated and difficult challenges and decisions."
Not surprisingly, Nader was widely accused of maladroitly mimicking the more private mailing, from Martha Burk to Hootie Johnson, on the issue of female membership at Augusta National Golf Club. Goodwin, the agent, did not respond to the letter, or to a phone call yesterday for comment on the fairness of publicly pressuring his prodigy, who has yet to play his first professional game.
Fairness, Nader argued, applies first and foremost to society's victims, not its victors. "We live in a celebrity culture," he said. "This is a strategy based on necessity. There has to be social pressure because the reality is that the people who work in these horrible conditions could come here and call a press conference and not get any of the attention that this kid gets for making $90 million."
After years of being pilloried, Nike has implemented some labor improvements without Jordan's ever risking a dollar. Frankly, I am of the mind that activism must ultimately be more of a calling than a commandment. But beyond the specifics of third-world labor, Nader may unwittingly be making a wider statement that an attitude adjustment by the super sports pitchmen would, in itself, be a wise personal investment. 
In his letter to James, Nader wrote that Jordan has chosen "not to support justice" for improved working conditions in third-world factories that produce products he has richly benefited from. This doesn't mean Jordan has had no positive impact on the sports and entertainment culture. He alone cast the mold that now produces the likes of James, the corporately leveraged soon-to-be Cleveland Cavalier, inside and outside the lines. 
Jordan just never found the motivation to wield his power for causes social or political. He played it safe, down the commercial center. As he said when a black Democratic candidate, Harvey Gantt, tried to unseat Senator Jesse Helms in Jordan's native North Carolina: "Republicans buy shoes, too."
This was no crime, just his choice. But in that context, the recent outcries of injustice -- the hint, even, of racism from Jordan's minions after his firing in Washington -- were downright comical, and cruel, given the charitable and social record of the Wizards' owner, Abe Pollin.
For once in Jordan's professional life, he did not have the leverage. At 40, five years beyond his last playoff heroism, the bottom line is that he was cut because he shot air balls from the front office.
If I were adviser to the reigning pitchman, Tiger Woods, or James, the new Nike pinup, I would be coming to the realization that Jordan's commercial strategy, while extraordinarily lucrative, has come with likability term limits. By comparison, who would have thought more than a decade ago when he retired from the Lakers after contracting the virus that causes AIDS that there would now be more magic in Earvin Johnson's public persona than in Jordan's? 
Johnson found a corporate calling, in the luring of companies to inner-city communities, creating commerce and jobs. Even factoring for inflation, Johnson and even Jordan never made the kind of money James will earn as a teenager. Given that scale, Nader is right. Most of these athletes play in luxurious taxpayer-financed arenas and reap every public benefit. James may be too young to feel the pain of others but he is not too innocent to be told how lucky he is and how he might help.
"As far as our monitoring of workplaces goes, Nike is not very high on the human rights list," Marisol Enyart, the California organizer for the United Students Against Sweatshops, said yesterday.
Blessed with the opportunity to play in Cleveland, a short drive from the poverty in which he was raised in Akron, James can expect Nader and the student group to stay on his case. "We're going to keep trying," Nader said. "I know they'll say, 'He needs to focus on basketball,' that he doesn't need the controversy, but this is not really a controversy anymore. Even Phil Knight admits that," he said, referring to Nike's chief executive. "It's just the right thing to do."
Based on the Jordan model, growing a social conscience, the sooner the better, may also be the smart thing to do, long term.

HEADLINE: Show Me the Money 

BYLINE:  By Lawrence S. Ritter; Lawrence S. Ritter, author of "The Glory of Their Times: The Story of the Early Days of Baseball Told by the Men Who Played It," is the John M. Schiff professor of finance emeritus at New York University.

 BODY:
 MAY THE BEST
TEAM WIN
Baseball Economics and Public Policy.
By Andrew Zimbalist.
198 pp. Washington:
Brookings Institution Press. $24.95.

MONEYBALL
The Art of Winning an Unfair Game.
By Michael Lewis.
288 pp. New York:
W. W. Norton & Company. $24.95.
 ON opening day last year, the payrolls of the Yankees and the Boston Red Sox, totaling $234 million, approximated the combined payrolls of Tampa Bay ($34 million), Montreal ($39 million), Oakland ($40 million), Minnesota ($40 million), San Diego ($41 million) and Florida ($42 million). The Yankees and Red Sox won a total of 196 games in 2002 while losing only 127. Not surprisingly, the six less affluent franchises won fewer than half of theirs.
The genesis of the sport's problems can be traced in part to baseball's infamous "reserve clause," so named because it permanently reserved a player's services to the first team that signed him unless he was traded or released. Players were not permitted to change teams or even to negotiate with other clubs on their own initiative. In 1922, Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr., speaking for a unanimous Supreme Court, ruled that because baseball was a game, not a business engaged in interstate commerce, it was uniquely exempt from the provisions of the antitrust laws; therefore the reserve clause was legal. Since then, the court has had numerous opportunities to reverse that decision but has chosen to let it stand.
In 1968, the club owners agreed to recognize the recently organized Major League Baseball Players Association as the "sole and exclusive bargaining agent" for all major-league players. Someone should have whispered the words "slippery slope" to them. In 1975, on petition from the association, a labor arbitrator, Peter Seitz, ruled that the reserve clause was nullified if a player played an entire year without signing his contract.
Now in the catbird seat, the Players Association offered an olive branch to the vexed owners. Instead of demanding a strict interpretation of the Seitz ruling, the union agreed to a modified version wherein a player had to be in the major leagues six years before attaining free agency. After six years, players are able to sign with the highest bidder. In the 1980's and 90's, the balance of power in baseball shifted from the club owners to what has become one of the nation's most intransigent trade unions. As the American union movement struggled to keep its head above water, the Players Association won strike after strike. In 1998, Congress passed and President Bill Clinton signed the Curt Flood Act, which repealed that part of the antitrust exemption dealing with labor relations. The repeal was more formal than real, of course, because for all practical purposes the players had already taken care of that little matter all by themselves.
Although they approach the subject from completely different angles, baseball's competitive inequities are the focus of both Andrew Zimbalist's "May the Best Team Win" and Michael Lewis's "Moneyball." Zimbalist offers a medley of free-market remedies designed to enhance competitive equity. On the other hand, Lewis apparently had such a good time monitoring the stratagems of the maverick general manager of the Oakland Athletics, Billy Beane, that he had neither the inclination nor the time to bother with much else. Nevertheless, Lewis's insights regarding the nuances of the market for athletic talent go a long way toward explaining Beane's impressive accomplishments. 
Zimbalist, the Robert A. Woods professor of economics at Smith College, toys with such far-out concepts as the abolition of all antitrust restrictions on baseball. Taken literally, without antitrust restrictions, ball clubs would presumably be free to locate wherever they wished. "If monopoly sports leagues did not artificially regulate the number and location of franchises," he writes, "then markets would be filled according to demand. A media market with seven million households, such as New York, would host a third or a fourth team before a market with 830,000 households, such as Milwaukee, would host its first franchise."
Tantalizing as the ideal of a free-market solution might be, especially to an economist, Zimbalist realizes there is little chance of Congress legislating divestiture (breaking up the monopoly into more than one firm) to create a truly competitive industry. However, he has other arrows in his quiver, including a worldwide player draft with picks in reverse order of league standings, elimination of some of the tax shelters that owners now enjoy and tighter governmental oversight over team movement and labor relations. 
On Aug. 30, 2002, the club owners and the Players Association reached a truce that promises labor peace through 2006. The accord includes revenue sharing and a competitive balance (or luxury) tax on payrolls -- two provisions intended to reduce the gap between the more and less prosperous clubs by transferring funds from the well-heeled to the needy. In principle, Zimbalist approves of both measures as steps in the right direction, although he is concerned that no minimum payroll is stipulated in the revenue-sharing formula; instead of using the funds to augment their payrolls, revenue-receiving clubs might simply pocket the money, which would defeat the whole reason for revenue sharing. 
The luxury tax on payrolls is a shabby excuse for a salary cap. A cap prevents a team from spending over a certain amount on player salaries, while a luxury tax, more permissive, allows payrolls above a certain level but imposes a penalty on offenders. Players dislike both, but the astronomical height of present-day salaries makes it virtually impossible for them to escape culpability. Also, Zimbalist warns, both salary caps and luxury taxes can be partly or wholly avoided by creative accounting, no stranger to either management or labor. 
"Moneyball" is a joy ride at the elbow of Billy Beane, general manager of the Athletics. Can Beane run a ball club? In 2002, with the third smallest payroll in the majors ($40 million), Oakland finished first in the American League West with 103 wins, tied for victories with the mighty Yankees (payroll $126 million), despite losing Jason Giambi, a winner of the American League Most Valuable Player award, to free agency. The A's had also won more than 100 games the previous year, and more than 90 games the year before that.
Beane's strength is that he is skeptical of truisms that pass for wisdom in the establishment -- including players, coaches, managers, scouts and front-office personnel. To him, received baseball doctrine (managing "by the book") amounts to little more than a cobweb of prejudices crying out for objective empirical and statistical validation. 
To explain Beane's success, Lewis, the author of "Liar's Poker," hijacks the concept of efficient markets from the world of finance. An efficient financial market is one in which the prices of securities accurately incorporate all available information. In Lewis's (and Beane's) view, the market for ballplayers is inefficient, largely because evaluation of talent is often distorted by baseball bromides.
There are few baseball maxims that escape Beane's magnifying glass. Can left-handed batters really hit right-handed pitchers better than lefties? How useful are bases on balls in winning ball games? What about stolen bases? Is batting average as good a measure as on-base percentage in evaluating hitting ability? Are high school athletes or college players more likely to make the grade? How to value a hard-hitting outfielder who circles under fly balls guessing where they might come down? Beane has unorthodox opinions on all of these topics, and a sackful more to boot.
Lewis trails after his subject doggedly. See Beane attempt to bluff rival general managers as they haggle over trade bait. See Beane lock horns with Oakland's old-time scouts over which high school and college players the A's should pick in the draft. When a game is under way, see him prowl restlessly, a pinch of smokeless tobacco stuck in his upper lip. See him try to manage games by remote control (front office personnel are barred from the dugout). And when carefully devised plans go awry, watch Beane morph into an enfant terrible and attack the office furniture.
Whether Billy Beane is a prophet or a flash in the pan remains to be seen. In either case, by playing Boswell to Beane's Samuel Johnson, Lewis has given us one of the most enjoyable baseball books in years.

HEADLINE: COVER STORY; 
A Portrait Of a Man Who Knew War's Face

BYLINE:  By Ted Loos 

 BODY:
FORTY-NINE years ago today, Robert Capa stepped on a land mine in Vietnam while covering that country's war against France, becoming the first American war correspondent to die there.
 Capa was only 40, but he had already become one of the world's top war photojournalists. His coverage of the Spanish Civil War produced "The Falling Soldier," the image of a Spanish Loyalist militiaman collapsing into death, which, despite debatable claims that it was staged, still ranks among the indelible images of the 20th century. 
 During World War II, Capa risked his life many times, even parachuting into the Rhine Valley with G.I.'s, and got close to the action with his lightweight Leica camera. He was the only photographer to capture the first wave of the Allied landing at Omaha Beach. 
 "Capa largely invented the way photojournalists look at war today," said Anne Makepeace, who wrote, produced and directed "Robert Capa: In Love and War," an "American Masters" documentary that is to have its premiere on Wednesday night at 9:30 on WNET and other PBS stations.
 "Before him war photography was about generals and the glory of battle," Ms. Makepeace said. "Capa really showed the human costs of war."
 For all of Capa's significance as an artist -- his Life magazine work is legendary -- his personal life was just as compelling.
 Handsome and dashing, he loved to gamble and party, and he spoke a multilanguage hybrid that a friend, the writer Irwin Shaw, called Capanese, the product of a Hungarian upbringing and many travels. 
 In the 1940's he had a romance with Ingrid Bergman, whom he photographed on the set of Alfred Hitchcock's "Notorious," and itis thought that Hitchcock based his 1954 film "Rear Window" on their affair. 
 Naturally filmmakers have been interested in Capa's story, but the rights are controlled by his brother, Cornell, who is dedicated to preserving Capa's legacy.
 "Ever since my brother died, I wanted to make a documentary," said Mr. Capa, 85. "But I did not want a Hollywood-style movie." 
 Mr. Capa had a distinguished photojournalism career of his own at Life and became the founding director of the International Center of Photography in 1974.
 "Cornell went with us because he wanted his brother's work to be the centerpiece, and he didn't want the life to overshadow it," said Susan Lacy, the executive producer of "American Masters."
 Once the rights were secured, Ms. Lacy tapped Ms. Makepeace, a longtime friend and collaborator whose first "American Masters" film, about the photographer Edward Curtis, was shown in 2001.
 "At the beginning I only knew what the average person did -- his war photographs -- but not his life," Ms. Makepeace said. "You cannot find a more amazing story than that of Robert Capa."
 Born Endre Friedmann to a family of Jewish tailors in Budapest, Capa was politically active from an early age, and at 17 left Hungary, where he had protested against the fascist dictatorship.
 Despite a life of bearing witness to violence, Capa always hated it. He once said, "A war photographer's most fervent wish is for unemployment."
 Although Ms. Makepeace called Capa "the first embedded photographer" for his close-up view of five wars, it was not his only beat. He took memorable photographs of movie stars like Humphrey Bogart, captured Picasso frolicking on the beach with Francoise Gilot and documented life in the postwar Soviet Union.
 Probably the most fantastical element of Capa's story is his name and persona change, which occurred in the 1930's, when he and his girlfriend, Gerda Taro, were living in Paris. 
 Taro posed as the agent for a famous photographer named Robert Capa (a name some say was inspired by the film director Frank Capra). The invented Capa was an American photographer too busy to meet with editors. When not out taking the pictures himself, Capa (then Friedmann) pretended to be the darkroom assistant.
 The ruse worked, and the pictures were good enough to get plum assignments. By the time someone figured it out, Capa's reputation was already established. And in 1946, when he became an American citizen, he legally changed his name. 
 "Within 10 years he had become exactly the description he created: a famous American photographer, always away on assignment taking these incredible pictures," Ms. Makepeace said.
 To make her 90-minute documentary, Ms. Makepeace filmed in seven countries, and moved from her home in Santa Barbara, Calif., to New York City, where she lived for more than a year while poring over many of the 70,000 Capa negatives housed at the International Center of Photography.
 "The hard part was, I had to deliver the film in a year," Ms. Makepeace said. "There was a massive amount of material."
 In looking through the images, about 500 of which were used in the film, Ms. Makepeace said that empathy was the common denominator.
 "If you look at the pictures in my film that he took of Nazi soldiers surrendering, they are full of humanity," she said. "The Nazis killed some of his relatives. He would have had every reason to make them look like monsters, but you see their suffering."
 To illuminate Capa's sensibility, both on the job and off, Ms. Makepeace wrangled some big-name interviews. Steven Spielberg appears in the film to talk about how he used Capa's photographs of D-Day for the opening sequence of "Saving Private Ryan." The actress Isabella Rossellini discusses Capa's famous charm and his relationship with her mother, Ingrid Bergman.
 The documentary also includes an interview with the 94-year-old French photographer Henri Cartier-Bresson, who founded Magnum, the photographers' agency, in 1947 with Capa and three other photographers. 
 "It's a real achievement for a filmmaker to tell the story when so few of the principals are around," said Cornell Capa, who appears in the film in an older interview since Parkinson's disease has made it difficult for him to talk on camera.
 Ms. Makepeace said, "Part of the urgency of getting the film done was that we wanted Cornell to be able to see it while he was still alive." 
 Mr. Capa, who took his brother's new name when he came to America, said he was pleased with the film, adding that it brought home to him the unlikely trajectory of his brother's life: a pacifist war photographer who dreamed up an impossibly successful life and then lived it for only a short time.
 "It was all imaginary," Mr. Capa said. "Except that it happened to be true."

ROBERT CAPA: IN LOVE AND WAR
Wednesday at 9:30 P.M. on WNET

On the cover: Robert Capa in 1936.

HEADLINE: Q. & A.; 
Cigarette Smoke From Co-op Below

 BODY:
 Q. I live in a small Manhattan co-op and have had a serious problem for years now with cigarette smoke coming through my floor from the apartment below. In addition to finding the odor distasteful, I am highly allergic and often get sinus headaches from the smoke. I know that co-ops have rules about noise infiltrating adjoining apartments. Are there any similar regulations for cigarette smoke? . . . Florence Bistecca, Manhattan.

A. Stuart M. Saft, a Manhattan co-op lawyer, said that most proprietary leases contain a provision that prohibits residents from allowing unreasonable noise and odors to escape from their apartment. Most leases also contain a provision giving residents the right to the "quiet enjoyment" of their apartments. And while either of those clauses could provide a basis for the letter writer to complain to the board, Mr. Saft said, it is unlikely that the amount of smoke entering her apartment would be considered unreasonable.
 "Unless the proprietary lease forbids smoking in apartments, the board cannot stop a lessee from smoking in his or her apartment," he said. "And it is virtually impossible to prevent the smoke from leaving one apartment and entering another."
Mr. Saft recently represented a co-op board, at 180 West End Avenue in Manhattan, that had considered requiring new buyers to agree not to smoke in their apartments. After many complaints, that effort was suspended, pending further review.

A Survivor's Right To Live in a Co-op

Q. My husband bought a co-op apartment in 1982 and lived alone in it as he was divorced at that time. In 1987, he refinanced and added his daughter and son as shareholders on the lease and stock certificate. In 1992, he and I married and have been living together in the apartment ever since, but we did not add my name as a shareholder. Now, he cannot add my name to the stock certificate because his daughter and son object to this solution. According to a letter I received from the co-op's lawyer, I will not be allowed to live in the apartment after my husband's death unless my name is added to the certificate. Can my husband assign me in his will the right to continue living in the apartment after his death? . . . Samira Wahba, Long Beach, N.Y.

A. Arthur I. Weinstein, a Manhattan co-op lawyer, said that most proprietary leases provide that occupancy of an apartment is limited to the shareholder "and" members of the shareholder's family. "Several court cases have held that the word 'and' means 'with,' " Mr. Weinstein said. "Therefore, under the terms of the proprietary lease, if the letter writer's husband passes away or permanently leaves the apartment, the letter writer would have no right to remain without the approval of the co-op."
Moreover, Mr. Weinstein said, even if the co-op was inclined to grant the letter writer permission to remain without the husband, she would still need the consent of the co-owners, the son and daughter. 
"When the husband transferred ownership of the shares of stock and the proprietary lease to himself and his children, he created ownership rights in the children," Mr. Weinstein said. "And he cannot now extinguish or change those legal rights on his own."
Mr. Weinstein said that if the husband bequeaths his interest in the apartment to the letter writer, that would give the letter writer only an economic interest in the apartment. "She would not automatically become a shareholder and proprietary lessee entitled to occupy the unit," Mr. Weinstein said. "And most co-ops would not consent to a transfer of an interest to a beneficiary of an estate over the objections of the other owners of the unit."

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE; 
Her Inventory Is on the Walls and on the Web

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH SPIERS; Elizabeth Spiers is the editor and sole writer of Gawker.com.

 BODY:
THE gallery owner Jen Bekman wants to make the process of putting art into the world as painless as possible, which may seem counterintuitive in an industry where melodrama, hyperbole and inflation both of egos and prices are everyday realities. Ms. Bekman certainly brings a fresh approach: before opening her own, she had never worked in a gallery. She didn't even have a fine-arts background. 
 What she does have is a photo log, a Web site that can be updated with photos and text frequently. And with that photo log, Ms. Bekman, 33 and a former dot-com executive, recruits new artists, solicits feedback on current work and exhibits exponentially more inventory than her closet-size gallery at 6 Spring Street in Manhattan can possibly hold. She's taking the traditional inaccessibility of the art world and tossing it out the Frank Lloyd Wright-designed window. (Her financial arrangements, however, are traditional: she takes art on consignment and splits the fees with the artists.) 
 Ms. Bekman uses her gallery's photo log -- www.fotolog.net/jenbekman -- to screen new pieces and display current inventory, allowing her to presell pieces before they're shown in the gallery. "The minute that I posted one of Luke Doherty's paintings, I started getting inquiries about buying his work," she said. The photo log also allows her to continue marketing artists who have previously exhibited. "Dana Miller and Mara Bodis-Wollner and Tema Stauffer, who were in the first show -- all their work from that show is still online, and there's still interest."
Ms. Bekman also said she found Tod Seelie through his photo log, www.fotolog .net/x_o. "He shoots film," she said, "but he had digitized so much of it, and he was working on his Web site and he wanted to put some images up."
Like Mr. Seelie, many of Ms. Bekman's recruits are not digital photographers. "I think there's definitely digital photography that fulfills the fine-art category," she said. "There are photographers on Fotolog.net who are just shooting digital and they're producing work that I think is on par with other fine-art photography. But I still see a lot of trepidation from people who come into the gallery."
Digital snobbery aside, Ms. Bekman's Internet scouting has produced results. She has found "maybe a quarter or a third" of her artists online, and casual traffic has yielded several buyer inquiries.
Ms. Bekman is aware of the inherent limitations of virtual exhibits, and she said most buyers know what anyone who has met an "intelligent, fit supermodel" through an online dating site or purchased an "authentic Chanel handbag" on E-bay can tell you: what you see on the Internet isn't necessarily what you get. "They understand that it's just a representation," she said. "They can't print out an image they see online and put it on their wall."
Finding emerging artists through photo logs may be a sexy use of the online medium, but Ms. Bekman said it's not the best. "I think that generally speaking, that's not its strength at all," she said. "What it's really about is creating a visual narrative for people's lives."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jen Bekman in her NoLIta gallery, beside photographs by Tema Stauffer. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: FILM; 
From Nightmare To Home Movie To the Multiplex

BYLINE:  By JULIE SALAMON 

 BODY:
SILLY BILLY may be the best-known children's party clown in New York City. So naturally Andrew Jarecki wanted to include him in the lighthearted documentary he was making about clowns. But as he began to interview David Friedman, who performs as Silly Billy, Mr. Jarecki's first reaction was: what makes this clown so angry?
 Before long, Mr. Jarecki was on the trail of the altogether different story, tragic not comic, that would become "Capturing the Friedmans," which won the Grand Jury Prize at the Sundance Film Festival in January and opens in New York on Friday and nationally in June. Simultaneously earnest and pulpy, raising as many questions as it answers, this riveting documentary re-examines the charges of child molestation that resulted in prison for David Friedman's father and youngest brother. 
 This may seem familiar, the routine stuff of television shows like "48 Hours" or HBO's "America Undercover" series. (Indeed, HBO has bought "Capturing the Friedmans" and plans to show it next year.) But the Friedman story is so juicy and is getting so much attention partly because it took place not in a trailer park but in Great Neck, N.Y., the affluent Long Island suburb usually associated with upwardly mobile stories of striving and achievement. The father, Arnold Friedman, was a Columbia University graduate, a longtime, prize-winning high school teacher. The brother, Jesse, was a high school student. Their accusers were boys who had taken after-school computer classes in the Friedmans' basement.
Call it "Dateline" filtered through David Lynch. Even the sprinkler systems maintaining Great Neck's pristine lawns become ominous in the camerawork of Aldolfo Doring. Yet Mr. Jarecki manages to convey sympathy for Arnold and Jesse Friedman, raising significant points that cast doubt on their guilty pleas without making claims for their innocence. At the same time, his film conveys the utter strangeness of this family, its fixation on documenting itself even at its worst -- especially at its worst.
The film is embroidered with vivid and sometimes alarming selections from the Friedmans' weirdly comprehensive home movies. There are the happy Friedmans at birthday parties and at the beach, images so familiar that they seem like stock footage from a collective memory bank. Then, after Arnold and Jesse are arrested, in 1987, come the screaming Friedmans, yelling at one another as the videotape rolls.
In one of those tapes, recorded a year after the arrests of his father and brother, David Friedman is seen sitting in a white T-shirt and boxers on his bed, clearly distraught, talking to the camera. "This is private, so if you're not me, you really shouldn't be watching this, because this is supposed to be a private situation between me and me," he says. "So turn it off, don't watch this."
Yet this private moment is now available to anyone for the price of a movie ticket. "Capturing the Friedmans" casts a spotlight on the most sensitive aspects of documentary filmmaking: what is the responsibility of filmmakers to their subjects, as they transform them from private to public figures? And what's the matter with us, that we can't take our eyes off the screen? Have we lost the ability to distinguish between public and private, or are we just living through a new variation on the old Hollywood dream, in which the fantasies and frailties that are made larger than life happen to be real? Or do we rationalize our prurience by saying that the Friedmans are fair game, having already lost their privacy to the criminal justice system and the reporters who cover it? These issues have become more critical as real-life stories have increasingly rivaled fictional ones in the public imagination.
What specifically changed the course of Mr. Jarecki's story was David Friedman's hostility toward his mother, Elaine. " 'My mother is an idiot,' that was a big theme with him," said Mr. Jarecki, discussing their early interviews. Mr. Friedman kept at it: " 'My mother is crazy, my mother is a lunatic.' " 
That angry outpouring convinced Mr. Jarecki that he needed to meet Elaine Friedman. At the time, he knew only that Silly Billy was an unusually cranky clown, and he wanted to know why. The mother was reticent during their first interview, which appears in the film. "I can't say too much about it," she says about the past, appearing flummoxed. "We were a family."
Mr. Jarecki told me that her use of the past tense broke his heart and sharpened his curiosity. "I didn't know why this family had ceased to be, but they clearly had," he said.
As the filmmaker continued his investigation, he found himself pulled in many directions. Elaine Friedman, who felt she had been unfairly reviled by her sons, became interested in revisiting the case, while a third son, Seth, who lives in California, wanted nothing to do with the project and does not appear in the film. Uncle Howard, Arnold Friedman's brother, a sentimental man in his 60's, agreed to participate simply to help shape a humane portrait of his brother and nephew. David Friedman would have been happy had the movie just gone away.
But it hadn't. Besides the family drama, the filmmaker was uncovering a police investigation that seemed to have been driven more by hysteria than by evidence. Students in the computer class that Arnold taught with Jesse's help had accused them of committing dozens and dozens of sexual acts and acts of physical brutality over a period of years. Parents had apparently noticed nothing untoward until a police investigation began. Yet even as Mr. Jarecki found evidence that the charges were dubious, he also learned about Arnold's pedophilia, which may or may not have been limited to trading sexual pictures of little boys, and about Jesse's assertion that his father had sexually molested him, which may or may not have been a ploy by Jesse's lawyer to obtain leniency.
Mr. Jarecki became overwhelmed. He wondered about his complicity in filming this ravaged family and the consequences of exposing its secrets. "I was tortured by that for awhile," he told me. But he also knew he had stumbled into a story that had lots of potential. He wanted to convince David Friedman -- and himself -- that pursuing the movie was a good thing to do.
So he visited Robert Coles, the child psychiatrist who is the James Agee Professor of Social Ethics at Harvard University as well as co-editor of DoubleTake magazine, published by the Center for Documentary Studies at Duke University. Dr. Coles remembers his initial reaction. "Hearing about some of this, I threw my hands up in the air and said, 'My Lord, What is going on?' " he told me in a telephone interview. "This is trouble enough, let alone trouble for a film. It's a fine line isn't it, between telling the truth and parading the truth?"
But as they talked further, Mr. Jarecki recalled, they found what he felt was a morally satisfying way to proceed with the movie he felt compelled to make. "One of the most interesting things about family secrets is that not everyone in the family wants them to be a secret," he said. "Usually I think it's better for the family for the secret to come out, or it becomes the element that destroys the family."
Filmmaker or shrink? The question becomes particularly pertinent for Mr. Jarecki, a director with only one previous credit, an 18-minute film called "Swimming," made in 1988. He is an unusual filmmaker from an unusual family. His father, Henry Jarecki, is an intimidating character who was for many years one of the world's leading gold traders. Henry is also a psychiatrist, yet his son never considered consulting him about his dilemma. ("He may be the only psychiatrist who doesn't believe in psychiatry," Andrew said coolly. "My father acted as though the talking treatment was touchy-feely and idiotic.") The family has its own private island in the British Virgin Islands. One of Andrew Jarecki's brothers, Eugene, made "The Trials of Henry Kissinger," a provocative 2002 documentary focusing on Christopher Hitchens's book of the same title, charging Mr. Kissinger with war crimes. A half-brother, Nicholas, wrote a show-business book called "Breaking In."
"I was drawn to a story about a father who behaves in ways that have an effect on his son, and he doesn't take responsibility," said Andrew Jarecki. His father had wanted him, the eldest son, to take over the family business. Instead, he chose an enterprise unrelated to either of his father's. In 1988, at 25, he became the co-founder of MovieFone. He and his partners sold the company 11 years later to America Online for stock valued at about $388 million.
So unlike most independent filmmakers, Mr. Jarecki didn't have to worry about the budget as he tried to unravel the Friedmans' convoluted tale. He could pay for lavish aerial shots of Great Neck, where they lived, and keep paying the editor he had hired for three months for almost three years. And he could meet reporters at the Regency Hotel on Park Avenue, not a regular hangout for neophyte documentary filmmakers.
From this varied and steamy psychological stew emerged a film that is impossible to watch without feeling squeamish and without wondering: why did the Friedman family record its own destruction? 
David Friedman, who bought the culpable video camera, said he wanted to record what was happening to the family after the charges were brought against his father and brother because things were moving too quickly to comprehend. He also needed a place to record his thoughts, like a diary. "It was like having a therapist, which I didn't have," he told me. "But it was never meant to be seen. None of the footage had been put into a VCR until Andrew told me he was making this movie."
So why did the Friedmans become convinced that airing family secrets was preferable to the alternative? Yes, there's the Jarecki argument, that the secrets become corrosive. Then there's the other school of thought, that the altered course dictated by revelation isn't necessarily better for everyone, and that some secrets can become the glue that holds families together.
But the Friedmans' secrets had already done their damage. This is why Jesse Friedman says he has no qualms about being in the film, although he was released from prison in late 2001 and is now, at 34, enrolled as an undergraduate at Hunter College, majoring in economics and political science.
"I didn't do anything wrong, and I always wanted to make that known," he said in a telephone interview, his voice still boyish. "I didn't have a problem with Andrew telling the story. My other family members don't feel the same way because they would rather not relive it. But for me, it never goes away. I'm on parole 24 hours a day, seven days a week, and that never changes. I have to register every 90 days as a level-three sexual predator for the rest of my life, unless something changes."
For David Friedman, now 42, appearing in the film is much more fraught. He has perhaps always been aware of the camera's powerful effect. His father recorded David's early magic tricks; he even appeared on "Candid Camera" as a child. He enjoyed the taste of celebrity (and gave his mother's phone number to Mr. Jarecki only after the filmmaker managed to supply him with a copy of that old "Candid Camera" show).
In 1994, by then established as Silly Billy, Mr. Friedman was the subject of a long, cheerful profile in The New Yorker (which he took to his interview with me), in which he told the writer, Susan Orlean: "I think that for a lot of people, having a clown at their kid's birthday party is really important. It's become part of the American dream, like owning a VCR."
Mr. Jarecki's clown film seemed like a good opportunity to Mr. Friedman, who had long been thinking about how to break into television. "An independent movie about me, Silly Billy, that could have been something special for my career," Mr. Friedman told me when we met.
He was devastated when Mr. Jarecki told him that the film had changed. "The movie went from being a film that would help my career to a film that could conceivably ruin my career," he wrote later in an e-mail message.
During our interview, his large dark eyes grew teary at points. He seemed fragile, quite different from the tense, abrasive man captured on film. "I hadn't told any of my friends in all these years about my brother and father because people hold children's entertainers to a standard different from any other career," he said. "When I socialize with my magic friends, even other magicians, and I curse, they all look at me and say, 'Wow, a children's magician cursed.' "
His friends may have been exaggerating the saintliness required for a children's clown. But, he added, "surely there would be a reaction of some of my clients to any suggestion that I come from a family where my father may have been a child molester."
Still, he said he felt he had no choice but to participate and to supply Mr. Jarecki with the family's home movies. His father had died in prison in 1995, but his brother was still in prison and continually being rejected for parole. "It was all about Jesse, about helping him," he said.
If only it were that simple.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 8, 2003

 CORRECTION:
An article on May 25 about the film "Capturing the Friedmans" misstated the title at DoubleTake magazine for Robert Coles, who advised the film's director, Andrew Jarecki, and misidentified the magazine's publisher. Mr. Coles is editor, not co-editor; the publisher is the DoubleTake Community Service Corporation, not the Center for Documentary Studies at Duke University. The magazine's affiliation with Duke ended in 1999.
Because of an editing error, the article also referred incorrectly to the title of a book by Christopher Hitchens that was the subject of "The Trials of Henry Kissinger," a film directed by Mr. Jarecki's brother Eugene. It was "The Trial of Henry Kissinger"; it was not the same as the title of the film.

HEADLINE: THEATER; 
The Sincerest Form Of Self-Flattery: An Allen Crib Sheet

BYLINE:  By ALEX ABRAMOVICH; Alex Abramovich writes frequently about culture and the arts for Slate and other magazines.

 BODY:
WRITER'S BLOCK" consists of two new Woody Allen one-acts ("Riverside Drive" and "Old Saybrook"), and its recent premiere at the Atlantic Theater in Chelsea marked the first time that Mr. Allen has directed his own original work for a live audience.
 How new, and how original? That's entirely open to interpretation: once upon a time, all you needed in order to enjoy his latest was a healthy sense of humor. These days, you need a crib sheet. 
 The plot of "Riverside Drive" is lifted boldly from Edward Albee's classic 1960 one-act, "The Zoo Story." (In his review of the play in The New York Times, Bruce Weber called it "Albee lite.") And what of it? With Broadway looking more and more like a homage to Hollywood, who could object to a great filmmaker's homage to the theater? Besides, Mr. Allen has a history of riffing on canonical works, from "War and Peace" ("Love and Death") to "Casablanca" ("Play It Again, Sam"). As long as those riffs were delightful, no one thought to complain -- Mr. Allen's jokes were original enough. 
But Mr. Allen stopped being delightful in 1992, when news of his own sexual indiscretions surfaced. He seemed to stop having new experiences, and began cannibalizing his own work with a vengeance: two of his films ("Sweet and Lowdown" and "Manhattan Murder Mystery") were dusted off after desk-drawer decades. He also began cannibalizing his own biography: "Bullets Over Broadway," "Mighty Aphrodite" and "Deconstructing Harry" (which one of his biographers dubbed the "Hooker-Fellatio Trilogy") were just three of his many self-lacerating rants about the many extra-societal privileges an artist's ego affords. 
Before the scandal, which revealed Mr. Allen's affair with Mia Farrow's adopted daughter Soon-Yi Previn, Mr. Allen was fond of existential jokes about the expanding universe. Afterward, his universe shrank to the size of his Upper East Side home: he grew solipsistic. His jokes turned stale and formulaic. Our laughter gave way to smirks of knowing recognition (which Mr. Allen seems to have interpreted as encouragement). His anarchic impulse used to be irrepressible -- even the serious, Bergman-influenced "Crimes and Misdemeanors" took time out to triangulate Alan Alda, Mussolini and Mr. Ed. Compare that juxtaposition to the following, from "Riverside Drive": "I, on the other hand, am a true original. Like Stravinsky. Or ketchup." 
Well, that's as good as Mr. Allen gets nowadays, but it's the same shtick he was peddling in the mid-60's, when deflationary takes on highbrow shibboleths seemed somehow subversive. Mr. Allen won that war -- it's thanks to him, in part, that we're all adrift in a sea of cultural signifiers -- but he seems never to have heard the news. Or any other news. Today, Mr. Allen's cultural reference points (which used to be all over the map) seem confined to within a three-block radius of Zabar's. He might as well have written: "Like Mahler. Or matzo-ball soup." We might as well have stayed home and played Mad Libs.
Which, in fact, is what Mr. Allen seems to have done with "Writer's Block," filling in the blanks with phrases, lines and entire swaths of dialogue drawn from his own films. Here, the crib sheet comes in handy: "Riverside Drive" and "Crimes and Misdemeanors" both describe a wealthy man's sexual indiscretion with a slightly unhinged woman. Both women turn out to be blackmailers and threaten to reveal the affair to the men's wives: 
"I want to speak to Miriam!" ("Crimes and Misdemeanors") 
"I want to talk to Lola!" ("Riverside Drive") 
"Just because you've decided I'm through in your life doesn't mean I'm going to roll over and die!" ("Crimes and Misdemeanors") 
"One thing for certain is I'm not some patsy who's going to roll over and play dead!" ("Riverside Drive") 
"She can be gotten rid of!" ("Crimes and Misdemeanors") 
"You have to get rid of her!" ("Riverside Drive") 
"He finds that he is plagued by deep-rooted guilt. Little sparks of his religious background, which he had rejected, are suddenly stirred up. He hears his father's voice. He imagines that God is watching his every move." ("Crimes and Misdemeanors") 
"A weak individual; a domestic crisis; a sexual impasse. . . . Then, one night, he sees his family and is overcome by a flood of memories. Guilt pervades his every pore." ("Riverside Drive") 
The night's second one-act, "Old Saybrook," is another homage (telling you what it's a homage to would ruin the surprise). It's also another cannibalization of Mr. Allen's own films and, like so many of his latter-day movies, it relies on the audience's knowledge of his own biography to flesh out what are often two-dimensional characters. "Art is different from life," one of those characters argues here. "Art is the mirror of life," another replies. "Art is Woody Allen's life," seems to be Mr. Allen's own position. 
AND so, in "Old Saybrook," Bebe Neuwirth finds incontrovertible photographic proof of her husband's affair with her own sister and Richard Portnow confesses to "having an affair with my wife's mother" (not to worry, she turns out to be his stepmother, so morally we're in the clear). Whether or not you will find this funny depends on how much you enjoyed the news of Mr. Allen's own affair (which Ms. Farrow uncovered by finding a stash of sexy Polaroids in Mr. Allen's apartment). It also depends on whether you got the point of all those semi-confessional films a clef ("Celebrity," "Mighty Aphrodite" and not a few others), which seemed to allude to the affair. Some of us got the point immediately. But as Mr. Allen says himself in "Riverside Drive," "a dog doesn't see its own tail."
What a strange thing for a comedian to say! After all, comedy -- especially Mr. Allen's own neurotically self-aware brand -- is rooted in doing just that. Mr. Allen, who spent almost four decades of his life as the consummate New York comedian, has ended up as just another New York curiosity -- the kind who holds his wounds out for our inspection and amusement. But those wounds are nothing we haven't seen before, and there's nothing amusing about them. The longer we keep laughing, the longer they'll take to heal.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Woody Allen giving direction to Jay Thomas and Bebe Neuwirth during a rehearsal of his play "Old Saybrook." (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CHOICE TABLES; 
Frogs' Legs to Conch Fritters in Miami

BYLINE:  By ERIC ASIMOV; ERIC ASIMOV writes the $25 and Under dining column for The Times.

 BODY:
WITH its beguiling reputation as a pastel playground, the little slice of sand, surf and Art Deco known as South Beach has come to dominate the public image of greater Miami.
 Yet Miami proper has its own significant strengths, not the least of which are serious, grown-up restaurants that present a stark contrast to the raucous combinations of party and theater that so often pass for restaurants in South Beach. These Miami restaurants, either in the heart of the city, in Coral Gables or Coconut Grove, or along the suburban edges, all have their own particular constituencies. 
 La Broche, a new sibling of a two-star Michelin establishment in Madrid, offers the latest in haute mad-scientist Spanish cuisine, at stratospheric prices. Diego's, in Coral Gables, offers traditional Spanish food to a largely Spanish-speaking clientele, at prices that are only a little bit lower, while Norman's in Coral Gables, where culinary pilgrims have busted their budgets for almost a decade, is still going strong. 
 In contrast to those sky-high prices, blue-collar restaurants like Captain's Tavern, in a plain shopping center, and Big Fish, right on the Miami River, offer simple food at reasonable cost.
 These were among the restaurants I visited with several Miami friends in mid-April.

La Broche
 In almost every way, La Broche is an astonishing place. The quiet, stark white dining room is beautiful in its simplicity, with comfortable chairs of butter-soft white leather and pedestals for the ubiquitous designer bags. Service is professional yet personable.
 The clear partition between the kitchen and dining room, the glass-walled wine room, even the big windows overlooking Biscayne Bay all connote nothing-to-hide. Yet the transformational food is full of secrets, jokes and surprises.
 The meal begins with a procession of snacks and tapas almost too numerous to recall: tiny anchovies embedded in bread crisps; cantaloupe gazpacho with trout eggs; a blue cheese cone filled with celery ice cream; madeleines studded with bits of sausage; even a sweet cocktail of chilled orange-lemon foam and brandy. Each intriguing combination is a sign of the excitement to come.
 The chef, Angel Palacios, favors odd, seemingly unrelated pairings, like a half-dozen tiny lollipops of fried frog leg, each with a gauzy little raviolo filled with herring eggs, a stirring contrast of flavors and textures. Or a fabulous earthy square of poached foie gras, served with delicate marinated eels and apple. Some dishes can be educational as well as delicious, like one billed as chickpea ravioli with mushrooms and duck sweetbreads in a light duck broth. "Of course, they're duck gizzards," our waiter told us. "Ducks don't have sweetbreads."
 The fascinating journey continues with main courses. Smoky little rounds of wood pigeon go beautifully with cubes of quince, alongside a crisp potato enveloped in warm poultry foam. Beef loin, cut in squares like an arrangement of sashimi, is paired with a bread crisp layered with tomato-and-water gelatin and cured, pressed tuna. For simpler desires, an assortment of fish and shellfish is grilled perfectly and served without fuss. Unlike the food, the eclectic wine list includes many conventional choices at not unreasonable prices, like a bottle of 2001 Albarino from Santiago Ruiz for $42. 
 Our meal hit a roadblock with desserts, which lack the dramatic contrasts of the other courses. One, called El Dracula, is a bloodless cola gelatin topped with strawberry foam and vanilla ice cream. Much better are the wonderful Willie Wonka-like petits fours, including cotton candy with a surprise dose of Pop Rocks in the middle that made us laugh.
 All told, a meal at La Broche is an exhilarating adventure. Not every experiment clicks, but taking part is a pleasure.

Diego's
 It's hard to imagine a greater contrast between the self-conscious artistry of La Broche and the old-school pleasures of Diego's. The dining room recalls countless movie sets, with stucco walls, timbered ceiling, phony grape arbors (but real flowers on the tables). The waiters, too, are from central casting, dignified in ties and jackets, expertly filleting fish or saucing the meat tableside as they flirt with the ladies.
 The dining room is almost entirely Spanish speaking, and the businessmen at one table are a sign of Miami's central role in the Gulf and Caribbean economy. Surprisingly, the food, served in enormous portions, is classic Spanish rather than Cuban or South American.
 Gazpacho has the force of a verdant garden, fresh and delicious; a tortilla, the Spanish omelet of potatoes and onions, is perfectly savory. Shrimp in garlic and parsley, enough to feed a soccer team, is exactly as it should be, though boquerones, fresh marinated anchovies, are firm and unyielding.
 You could make an entire meal of appetizers, but Diego's prides itself on certain main courses, like cochinillo, a huge wedge of suckling pig roasted in a wood oven, full of flavor and contrasting textures, from the tender meat glistening on the bone to the crisp, impossibly rich skin. I'm not much of a fan of veal chops, but I may never have had one as good as the one at Diego's, served with big langoustines, their heads still on, gripping the top of the meat. The restaurant's other specialty, sea bass encased in sea salt and baked, emerged from its salty crust dry and overcooked, although it gained from its sauce of aioli and capers. 
 Desserts, too, cover the classics. Torrijas is the Spanish version of the ideal French toast, soaked in milk and wine and dredged in sugar and cinnamon syrup. Rice pudding, also imbued with cinnamon, is a delight. 
 The largely Spanish wine list is full of collectors' items, like a magnum of Vega Sicilia Unico '73 for $1,505. But Diego's does well by the ordinary wine drinker, too, with estimable reds like a smooth and concentrated Ribera del Duero from Condado de Haza for $50.

Norman's
 With four cookbooks, a new restaurant set to open in Orlando in August, another in Los Angeles and yet another in a new Coral Gables mall, and a multitude of other entrepreneurial plans, it would be understandable if Norman Van Aken's attention had wandered from his flagship restaurant.
 Remarkably, Norman's remains at the top of its game. While Mr. Van Aken's signature melange of global influences and local products inspired other chefs in South Florida, too many ended up in the hackneyed realm of New World Cuisine, and Floribbean cooking. But Mr. Van Aken's approach remains as fresh as ever, creating unlikely combinations that are both soulful and stimulating.
 The bilevel 145-seat dining room, with big wood-burning ovens and an open kitchen, has a 1980's feel. Service is courteous and professional. 
 At La Broche, many combinations feel surreal. Here, they are just right. Shrimp as big as chicken drumsticks, crisp on the outside, are stuffed with mashed yucca, yet taste intensely shrimpy. A mojo sauce of sour orange and garlic adds fruit, while a tartar sauce spiked with habanero chili adds heat. It's a pleasure. Soft Vietnamese spring rolls come with a square of lush tuna tataki and a refreshing pawpaw slaw. 
 A main course like bright and garlicky roasted pork Havana, with an equally bright salsa of tiny black beans and a stack of grits, is a knowing take on lechon asado, the ubiquitous roasted pork dish of Cuban Miami. I was a little hesitant about a dish called tuna pad Thai, having experienced enough variations on this Thai noodle dish to know it's usually a synonym for deadly dull. But this version, with plenty of rare tuna with shimmering stir-fried shrimp, peanuts and egg noodles, proved a delicious combination of soft and crisp, crunchy and sumptuous.
 I hesitated again before a dessert description of a "warm chocolate melting cake," but Mr. Van Aken even manages to breathe new life into that hoary cliche, transforming it into a sundae by surrounding it with toasted-nut clusters, rich vanilla ice cream and hot fudge sauce. You can get tired just reading the lengthy description of banana mousse coated in milk chocolate, with toasted cashews and macadamia nut brittle ice cream, but the clarity and intensity of the flavors will wake you right up again.
 The wine list is exceptional, with a strong, intelligent selection of both Old and New World choices. You can find good, less expensive choices like a '97 Savennieres from Domaine des Baumard, with a touch of honey in each sip.A single misstep shows up at the bottom of the dessert menu. Mr. Van Aken offers his own line of "spice creams," a trademarked term that essentially means ice creams with savory spins, like chocolate ancho or vanilla escabeche. The combinations don't work for me.

Captain's Tavern
 Sometimes another plate of macadamia-encrusted snapper in fruit salsa is more than anyone should have to bear. Occasionally you just want a plain piece of fish. Captain's Tavern, hidden away in an unlovely shopping center deep in strip-mall territory, is the antidote.
 With its nautical decor of rough-hewn wood, rigging and mounted fish, Captain's Tavern looks like the template for any number of 1960's-era fish houses. At lunch red tablecloths under glass are set with paper napkins and placemats.
 What Captain's Tavern has to offer is a wide selection of pristinely fresh fish simply prepared at moderate prices. At lunch time it's packed with local people, many of whom choose the day's specials. Conch fritters, a South Florida standard, are among the best I've had, crisp outside and creamy within, just right with some ground pepper and a squeeze of lime. A whole pompano, served broiled, is moist, sweet and delicious. It comes with a steakhouse baked potato, in aluminum foil, and a nice little salad. 
 For dessert, rum cake would make any Cuban grandmother proud, simply soft yellow cake topped with nuts and saturated in rum. The wine list is surprisingly varied, with many good inexpensive choices.

Big Fish
 Like Captain's Tavern, Big Fish is a local institution well off the tourist track. It's perched on the shore of the Miami River, that other body of water, where the sights and sounds are of tugboats, container ships and drawbridges rather than the ocean's body surfers and sun worshipers. 
 While it offers a small covered area, the dining room is largely outdoors. At lunch, lawyers, real estate people and others do business in wicker chairs, sometimes lighting up cigars as they finished a bottle from the modest wine list. My business one afternoon was simply a fried yellowtail, a perfect piece of fish that was light and crisp on the outside, with enough moist, flavorful meat to keep me digging through the bones. 
 At the end of the meal, I wanted no dessert or coffee. I only wanted to remember the sound of the wind flapping the awning, and of course the taste of the yellowtail. It seemed as if I were a million miles from the smell of sunblock in South Beach.

Bill of fare
Prices are averages for dinner for two and include a modest bottle of wine or a couple of drinks, but not tax and tip.
 All these restaurants accept major credit cards. All allow smoking at the bar only except for Big Fish, where smoking is allowed in its open-air dining area. 
 La Broche, 1155 Brickell Bay Drive (11th Street), Miami; (305) 415-0070. Lunch and dinner are served Tuesday through Saturday. Closed Sunday and Monday. About $190.
 Diego's, 65 Alhambra Plaza (between Ponce de Leon Boulevard and South Douglas Road), Coral Gables; (305) 448-2498. Lunch and dinner daily. About $150. 
 Norman's, 21 Almeria Avenue (Douglas Road), Coral Gables; (305) 446-6767. Dinner Monday through Saturday. Closed Sunday. About $175. 
 Captain's Tavern, 9621 South Dixie Highway (98th Street), Pinecrest; (305) 666-5979. Lunch and dinner served Monday through Saturday. Dinner only on Sunday. About $100.
 Big Fish, 55 Southwest Miami Avenue Road, (off Brickell Avenue and Southwest Fifth Street), Miami; (305) 373-1770. Lunch and dinner daily. About $95.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT; 
French and Germans Woo American Tourists

BYLINE:  By JOHN TAGLIABUE

DATELINE: Paris 

 BODY:
JEAN-PHILIPPE PEROL tells his French compatriots to be more pleasant to Americans.
 Mr. Perol, the director general of Maison de la France, a travel trade organization, recently hauled 300 hotel directors and others into a vast hall under the Louvre to preach the benefits of, well, simply being nice. 
 "Attention, I told them," said Mr. Perol, lifting a hortatory finger as he recalled the session, "this year you have to be particularly nice to Americans." 
 In Berlin, several hundred miles east, Natascha Kompatzki is similarly sensitive.
 "I don't know of a single incident againstAmericans, not a single one," said Ms. Kompatzki, the spokeswoman for Berlin Tourism Marketing, the agency that promotes the German capital. "We think people make a clear distinction between Berlin as a tourist destination," she said, "and the policies of the German government."
 The war in Iraq is now for the most part over, yet gnawing concern persists among the French and Germans, whose governments opposed the war, that American animosity may contribute to curtailing the number of Americans who travel here.
 In France, Americans are the largest contingent of foreign visitors, totaling more than 4.5 million in 2001, the latest year for which figures are available. That was more than 7 percent of the total of foreign visitors. In Germany, with four million in 2002, or almost 11 percent of the total, Americans are the second-largest contingent, after the neighboring Dutch. What's more, Americans spend more -- in France, an average 328 euros a trip, or $372 (at 0.88 euros to the dollar) in 2001, as opposed to $150 for British tourists and $88 for Germans. Only the Japanese, at $740, spend more.
 Despite recent history, in both countries some in the tourism business still express optimism. In Berlin, Sabine Held, spokeswoman for the Adlon, the recently restored grand hotel near the Brandenburg Gate, said through an associate that the percentage of American guests has been constant, at 15 to 20 percent. Russian and Chinese tourists have recently taken up some slack. 
 At the George V, the luxury hotel off the Champs-Elysees in Paris, the share of Russians among the guests has risen so far this year to 7 percent, up from 1 percent a year ago, Didier Le Calvez, the director, said recently. Yet in the whole Ile-de-France region, an area around Paris that is slightly smaller than Connecticut, luxury hotels report a drop in occupancy of up to 20 percent in the first three months of this year. At the George V, the percentage of American guests for the same period dropped to 20 percent, from an average 45 percent.
 In Berlin, the number of American visitors had climbed back up in the first two months of this year, after plummeting in the aftermath of Sept. 11, only to drop again with the war in Iraq. 
 Such numbers account for the charm offensive vis-a-vis the United States by French and German travel industry officials. Of course, no one is really sure how much Americans are resisting travel to France. Mr. Perol argued that most Americans who choose to go to France as a destination are not likely to be susceptible to a boycott appeal. "They are largely of a high cultural level, they live in big cities, they tend to come from the East and West Coasts," he said. 
 French surveys suggest reasons for the American absence other than the wish to punish the French. "First, there is the economic situation, then there is the fear of being treated badly by the French," Mr. Perol said. Travel experts in Germany agree, citing fear of violence and terrorist attacks as factors along with the weak dollar.
 "People are generally staying closer to home," said Jurgen Scharrer, the editor of Touristik Report, a trade journal. Germany will launch a tourism offensive in the United States later this year that will concentrate on highbrow and closely defined groups presumably less likely to heed a boycott appeal.
 Berlin, for instance, has joined Hamburg, Munich and Cologne to promote tourism among American gays; for music lovers, 2004 has been designated the year of German music. Special tours are proposed for Jews and German-Americans in search of their roots.
 France, Mr. Perol said, has started a campaign called Bonjour to instill in travel employees the need to make Americans feel welcome. An ad campaign on American television will feature Americans who came and were warmly received. A special travel card, Club France, has been revived to offer Americans special prices and discounts at stores and museums.
 The stress on Paris hotels is evident at the Concorde La Fayette, out past the Arc de Triomphe along the Avenue de la Grande Armee, which is owned by the Societe du Louvre, which also owns the Crillon in Paris and the Martinez in Cannes. While the fighting in Iraq went on, about 20 percent fewer Americans stayed at the Concorde than usual, said Eliane Picard-Monier, the director of communications. But only very few absentees cited anti-French sentiment for staying away. "I think we got one card," she said. At the moment, the Concorde is experiencing an upswing in American bookings. 
 Over on the Left Bank in the Sixth Arrondissement, the Victoria Palace Hotel is offering the night of the Fourth of July free to Americans who come for the weekend. 
 Michael E. Erwin, the director of sales, was traveling in California with the owner, Philippe Schmitt, when the war started. "Some people said they would boycott France, others said they were afraid because the French would be unwelcoming," said Mr. Erwin, who is American.
 "How can I try and explain that the French make a big distinction between politics and day-to-day affairs? You're talking two centuries of friendship here." He would do anything, he said, to get his fellow Americans back to France: "I wish I could offer a barbecue as well."

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN; 
Montreal

BYLINE:  By CLIFFORD KRAUSS; CLIFFORD KRAUSS is the chief of the Canada bureau of The Times.

 BODY:
While Montreal is a beguiling place in any season, there is no better time to visit this bilingual city than summer. Rue St.-Denis becomes a joyous scene of dueling cafes, as diners temper the humidity with chilled vichyssoise and Chablis. Day lilies, lilacs and peonies brighten the Botanical Garden. The big bands are back to serenade visitors on the balcony of the Chalet du Mont-Royal. And one cultural festival after another makes Montreal night life sizzle with live music, dancing and avant-garde cinema.
 It is easy to think of Montreal, the second largest French-speaking city in the world, as European, although it is an easy drive from much of New York State or New England. The Old City in particular, with its narrow cobblestone streets, quaint galleries and 18th-century wooden houses, invites comparisons with France. 
 Montreal has been spared the affliction of SARS suffered by Toronto, 200 miles away, and has no reported cases. 
 The mood of the city is upbeat; the economy is strong and the rancorous debate over sovereignty has subsided. New luxury hotels are opening, old ones are refurbishing, and the fashionable shops on the Rue Ste.-Catherine are flourishing.

Events
 Le Grand Prix du Canada, June 13 to 15, www.grandprix.ca, (514) 350-0000, gets summer off to an exciting start with world-class Formula One racing. The Gilles-Villeneuve Circuit is on a lovely island on the St. Lawrence River, but the zooming of cars can be heard throughout the city, packed every year with over 300,000 racing fans. Tickets and packages, $53 for general admission to $292 for the gold grandstand, at 1.42 Canadian dollars to the United States dollar.
 Le Mondial SAQ, formerly known as the Montreal International Fireworks Competition, will be held June 21 to July 30, www.lemondialsaq .com, (514) 397-2000. Eight countries and Hong Kong compete on Saturdays and Wednesdays at 10 p.m., rain or shine. The display is magnificent along the St. Lawrence River, best viewed from balconies around the Old City.
 The Montreal International Jazz Festival, June 26 to July 6, www .montrealjazzfest.com, (514) 871-1881, is Montreal's answer to Mardi Gras and the highlight of the summer. Downtown becomes one big party, with food booths, street performers and craft sellers clogging traffic but creating a festive air. For nearly two weeks the Place des Arts becomes the scene of daily and nightly free concerts. The Ray Charles Big Band, Bobby McFerrin, Norah Jones, the Wayne Shorter Quartet and the Dave Holland Big Band are some of the headliners. Ticket prices range from $10.50 to $60. 
 Just for Laughs, July 10 to 20, www.hahaha.com, (514) 845-3155, is a showcase for comedic talent from around the world. There are free outdoor shows and street theater, plus indoor shows with tickets from $10.50 to $32. This year's stars will include Brad Garrett ("Everybody Loves Raymond"), Eric Bogosian, Kathy Griffin ("Suddenly Susan"), Tina Fey ("Saturday Night Live") and Emo Philips.
Rossini's "Italiana in Algeri," will be performed by L'Opera de Montreal at the Salle Wilfrid-Pelletier-Place des Arts, 260 Boulevard de Maisonneuve West, (514) 985-2258, www.operademontreal.com, on May 31, June 5, 7, 11 and 14. Tickets: $39.50 to $110.50.
 On July 2, the Montreal Symphony Orchestra, www.osm.ca, will perform Mozart's Overture to "La Clemenza di Tito" and Clarinet Concerto and Brahms's Symphony No. 3 at Notre-Dame Basilica, 110 Notre-Dame Street West, (514) 842-2925. Tickets: $16 to $37.

Sightseeing
 Summertime is walking time in Montreal. The pace of life, slower than in other big Canadian cities, invites ambling down Boulevard St. Laurent and Rue St.-Denis to take in the cafes, music shops, boutiques and restaurants. There are fine examples of Beaux-Arts and French Renaissance-style buildings around the Latin Quarter, particularly around Carre St.-Louis, a lovely little park with a modern sculpture garden.
The recreational heart of the city is Mount Royal Park, a leafy expanse designed by Frederick Law Olmsted that is an easy walk from downtown and has the best views in town. Before visiting the park, the best place to find picnic fare -- excellent and reasonably priced Quebecois cheese, cider and crusty bread -- is the Atwater Market, 138 Atwater, which is also a great place to take in the French core of daily life.
 The Montreal Botanical Garden, 4101 Sherbrooke East, (514) 872-1400, www2.ville.montreal.qc.ca/jardin/jardin.htm, is open all year, but its 30 thematic gardens are particularly glorious in summer. The Japanese Pavilion has an exhibition until Sept. 1 exploring the history of green tea. In the Chinese Garden, from July 16 to 20 and 23 to 27, on Wednesday through Sunday afternoons, there will be exhibitions of Chinese, Indian, Japanese, Iranian and Turkish song and dance. Open daily 9 a.m. to 4 p.m., to 6 from June 21 to Sept. 1. 
 The highlight of any walking tour is Old Montreal, which still has cobblestone streets and gas lamps, mansard roofs, fragments of stone walls from the French colonial era and grand bank buildings festooned with copper gargoyles and stone dragons. An alternative to walking is the horse-drawn cart, which costs $60 for an hour's ride. The drivers are bilingual, often funny and knowledgeable about local folklore. They can be found on the Place d'Armes, in front of the Notre-Dame Basilica.
 The Basilica, at 110 Notre-Dame Street West, (514) 842-2925, www .basilicanddm.org, is Montreal's most distinguished building, a fine example of Gothic Revival with soaring vaulting, gilded and carved wooden sculptures and fine stained-glass windows produced in Limoges, France. Admission is $2; a two-hour tour and lecture, by reservation, $7; open daily 8 a.m. to 5 p.m.
 The other highlight of the Old City is the Montreal Museum of Archaeology and History at Pointe-a-Calliere, 350 Place Royale, (514) 872-9150, www.musee-pointe-a-calliere.gc.ca, which is built around archaeological remains of colonial Montreal. An underground multimedia exposition of six centuries of history, it will present a special exhibit from June 17 to Nov. 2 in collaboration with the Israel Museum: "Archaeology and the Bible From King David to the Dead Sea Scrolls," including three important scrolls discovered on the shores of the Dead Sea. Admission $7. Closed Mondays until June 23.
 The Bonsecours Market, 350 St.-Paul Street East, (514) 872-7730, www.marchebonsecours.qc.ca, an imposing 19th-century market with a splendid silver dome, is home to fashionable boutiques and restaurants.

Where to Stay
 A growing number of boutique hotels have opened in Old Montreal in recent years. An excellent new addition is Hotel Nelligan, 106, rue St.-Paul Ouest, (514) 788-2040, fax (514) 788-2041, www.hotelnelligan.com. Its 35 rooms and 28 suites -- the latter with fireplaces and double Jacuzzi baths -- are furnished in a minimalist manner, but the brick walls give them a warm feeling. The Atrium bar is tasteful and inviting. Doubles begin at $158, including Continental breakfast.
 Auberge Bonaparte, 447, rue St.-Francois-Xavier, (514) 844-1448, fax (514) 844-0272, www.bonaparte.com, is a sweet inn with 31 rooms, two with terraces, and lovely views of the courtyard of the Notre-Dame Basilica. Classical music, Louis Philippe-style furniture and marble bathrooms lend a European feel. The French restaurant downstairs is also excellent. Doubles start at $109, with full breakfast.
 Downtown and convenient for shopping, the Fairmont Queen Elizabeth hotel, 900 Rene Levesque Boulevard West, (514) 861-3511, fax (514) 954-2256, www.fairmont.com, has been newly renovated. Its 1,039 rooms have lovely views of the Mary Queen of the World Basilica and a promenade leading to downtown. The bellhops are happy to show guests Suite 1742, where John Lennon and Yoko Ono stayed and composed "Give Peace a Chance." Doubles start at $161. 
 Budget: Auberge Les Passants du Sans Soucy, 171, rue St.-Paul Ouest, (514) 842-2634, fax 514-842-2912 www.lesanssoucy.com, is a former fur warehouse dating back to 1723, with one wall from a 1689 seminary. It has only nine rooms, rustic but elegant, with fireplaces and wooden ceiling beams, so reservations must be made at least one month in advance. The lobby doubles as an art gallery. Doubles begin at $88, including a generous buffet breakfast.
 Luxury: Hotel Le St.-James, 355, rue St.-Jacques, (514) 841-3111, fax (514) 841-1232, www.hotellestjames .com, is probably the most luxurious in Montreal. It has marble floors, crystal chandeliers, Persian rugs and 61 rooms and suites individually decorated with antiques from Asia and Europe. The spa has a stone wall from Montreal's original fortifications. Rooms range from $229 to $3,520 a night.

Where to Eat
 One of many great deals is Cafe Cherrier, 3635, rue St.-Denis, (514) 843-4308, an unpretentious bistro just north of the Latin Quarter with outdoor seating. Dinner and lunch are served every day, and an a la carte brunch is served on Saturdays and Sundays. Favorites include Toulouse sausages for $9.50 and steak tartare for $9.85. Dinner for two with wine costs around $40.
 One of the hottest restaurants in town is Toque! 3842, rue St.-Denis, (514) 499-2084, fax (514) 499-0292, www.restaurant-toque.com, where reservations must be made at least three weeks in advance. The decor is handsomely simple, but the details go into service. The chef, Normand Laprise, offers a "mystery menu" of six dishes that costs $55, $80 with three glasses of wine. An a la carte dinner with wine for two costs $127. Try the cauliflower soup with foie gras shavings ($11) and the roasted Maine scallops with Israeli couscous ($24). Open for dinner Tuesday through Saturday.
 Ferreira Cafe Trattoria, 1446, rue Peel, (514) 848-0988, fax 514- 848-9375, www.ferreiracafe.com, in the heart of downtown, is a Portuguese place that is one of Montreal's liveliest and most sophisticated restaurants. The tile fresco above the bar, collage of broken plates on the walls and large bouquets of fresh-cut flowers make for a pleasing atmosphere. A dinner that starts with cold gazpacho with chunks of lobster ($10) might go on to include roasted veal filet with a Madeira sauce ($25). Dinner for two with a modest wine from the extensive Portuguese list costs around $120. Closed Sundays; open for lunch and dinner Monday through Friday, dinner on Saturday.
 Schwartz's, 3895 boulevard St. Laurent, (514) 842-4813, is a Jewish deli that has been a fixture since its founding in 1930. Its smoked meat is Canada's answer to New York pastrami. A very hearty lunch or dinner with soft drink costs $5.60 and up a person. Open daily for lunch and dinner. 
 Chez l'Epicier, 11 St.-Paul East, (514) 878-2232, combines a restaurant with gourmet shop in the heart of Old Montreal. The casual, modern restaurant has delicious specialties, like pan-fried foie gras with sweet potato tempura ($13). Dinner for two with wine costs $63. Dinner nightly; lunch on weekdays; takeout till 10 p.m. every day.
