HEADLINE: Business; 
Appealing to Older Travelers' Wanderlust, and Wallets

BYLINE:  By HARRIET EDLESON 

 BODY:
IN the last three years, Donald A. Mankin, 60, once accustomed to backpacking in the Sierra Nevada on his vacations, has more often taken expensive trips to far-flung destinations.
 Like many people over 55, he prefers educational trips, like his eight-night, $14,000 sojourn to Antarctica in December, through Adventure Network International, owned by Grand Expeditions. "I travel every opportunity I can," said Mr. Mankin, a psychology professor at Alliant International University in Los Angeles. 
 Almost 60 million Americans, or about 28 percent of the adult population, are at least 55 years old, according to the Census Bureau. The Travel Industry Association of America, a trade group in Washington, estimates that this group accounts for $130 billion in travel spending and takes one-third of all trips, which the association defines as journeys of 50 miles or more, or at least one night away.
"There is vast potential," said Suzanne Cook, the association's senior vice president for research and technology. "Baby boomers have grown up to value and expect travel. They have that mentality -- wanting to retain their youth and vitality -- and that includes travel."
Travel spending declined 6 percent in 2001 and grew only about 2 percent in 2002. This year, the travel industry has been hurt by worries about SARS and conflict in Iraq, in addition to continuing concern about terrorism and the weak economy.
To rekindle growth, cruise lines, airlines and hotels are eager to woo older travelers. "Everybody is going after this market," said Hal Norvell, manager for cruise and vacation products at AARP Services, a subsidiary of AARP. "It's wide open."
Older working couples account for 80 percent of luxury travel, according to a report by the travel association.
"The name of the game for them is not $59 hotel rooms but $15,000 cruises," said Richard M. Copland, the president of the American Society of Travel Agents and owner of Hillside Travel in the Bronx.
All kinds of travel companies -- whether mass-market ones like Walt Disney or specialty businesses catering to various travel interests -- are developing programs and strategiesto tempt the older market.
The Far and Wide Travel Corporation, the parent of 21 travel companies, began trips called Passages, or "journeys of discovery," in February. The trips use small ships, riverboats and private trains to reach remote destinations like Sado Island, in the Sea of Japan, and St.-Pierre, a tiny French island off Newfoundland.
One Passages itinerary -- 13 days to Turkey and Greece aboard the Sea Cloud, the former private yacht of Marjorie Merriweather Post -- costs $7,500 to more than $13,000, depending on the accommodations.
"Today, 50- to 59-year-olds are more active, more health conscious, more activity driven, more independent, and want experiences that change them," said Scott Boone, the chief marketing officer of Far and Wide.
To focus on this market, some companies have changed their advertising, while others have offered higher commissions to travel agents, who sell more than 90 percent of all cruises.
Ten years ago, Carnival Cruise Lines made some changes with "an eye toward the graying of America," said its president and chief executive, Robert H. Dickinson. It added more and better wines, for example, and upgraded its cuisine.
More recently, it raised the target income of its prospective 50-plus passengers to $70,000 from $50,000 and started advertising in Wine Spectator magazine. "We wanted to reach out to a more sophisticated vacationer, and they tend to trend older," Mr. Dickinson said. "We had to change our messengers as well to make sure we were reaching baby boomers."
In 2003, close to a million of Carnival's three million passengers will be 50 or older.
Sandals Resorts International, which operates Sandals Resorts for couples only and Beaches Resorts -- some for families and some for adults only -- has begun featuring "more mature" models in its brochures and advertisements, said John D. Lynch, the executive vice president for worldwide sales. The goal is to appeal to travelers who are 50 and older; they make up 30 percent of its customers, twice the level of a decade ago.
Far and Wide, which has records on 11 million actual and prospective customers, pays to use e-mail lists to reach potential customers based on certain characteristics, including their travel histories. "Age is part of the driver," said Kenneth P. Lane, vice president for direct marketing. The average age of its customers is 55, he said.
The company also uses the Claritas Corporation's Prizm profile analysis, which assigns every American neighborhood to one of 62 clusters. If a customer has traveled to the Great Barrier Reef in Australia with Far and Wide, the company will make pitches to other people in the neighborhood, or in similar neighborhoods in other cities. "It's kind of a birds-of-a-feather approach," Mr. Lane said.
Some companies market directly to an older audience, while others are "gently pitching" to it, said Ken Dychtwald, president of Age Wave, a consulting company in San Francisco that helps businesses market to people 50 and over. They don't want to "taint their brand" by alienating other age groups, he said.
ResortQuest International, a company that manages vacation property, markets to the 50-plus group for the months just before and after the peak summer season -- periods when the weather is still good, crowds are thinner and prices are lower. In the last two years, the company, based in Memphis, has shifted 20 percent of its $15 million marketing budget to reach this market, said James S. Olin, ResortQuest's president and chief executive.
That has paid off to some degree. The company's gross lodging revenue in northwest Florida, for example, increased 4 percent for the three months ending last November from the period a year earlier.
Club Med North America, a division of Club Mediterranee, based in Paris, said it might join the trend by marketing one of its 11 North American clubs to people over 50, but it has no specific plans. Up to 26 percent of people staying at some Club Med villages are 55 and older, said Valerie Bihet, a spokeswoman.

HEADLINE: ON THE JOB; 
Am I Busy? Let Me Count the Hats

BYLINE:  By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
People used to say they were busy, busy, busy. Now they say they're multitasking. In the Olympics, the decathlon is a sport. In the office, trying to do 10 things at once is a trial.
Multitasking is the only task Jenny McKinney of San Francisco knows. 
 On Sept. 3, she and her husband, Bruce, working with a staff of six people spread across seven states and working out of their homes, established a database Web site of bibliographies, historical and current book auction records, and prominent book dealer catalogs. 
 Mr. McKinney's concept was to help dealers of rare books become more efficient by giving them quick access to titles and prices -- and to help book collectors by making them aware of titles on the market and price history. Libraries that have rare-book collections would also benefit. "My husband's motivation to start this business was that this was an extremely smart and logical concept," Mrs. McKinney writes. "Everyone ought to embrace it.
"After the launch, not only did dealers not like it; libraries were indifferent to it, and collectors are nowhere in sight." Within a month, three staff members quit.
Mrs. McKinney writes: "I am on the job with the following multitasks: in charge of bookkeeping, payroll, coding articles published monthly on our Web site, updating database, maintaining an e-mailing list, designing promotional material and making date entries when I have free time.
"Additionally, our Web site is going through many phases of software additions and modifications."
Mrs. McKinney is responsible for ensuring that results are logical, functional and otherwise user-friendly.
During her free time, she manages an investment portfolio for her sister and herself and is the mother of a 16-year-old daughter and a 17-year-old son.
"My office is in the corner of our kitchen," she says. "Who do you think is doing the cooking, laundry, grocery shopping, etc.?
"Can I tell anyone that I am only one person? So far no one has lent me his or her ears. I hope you do." 
"Every day I find myself doing something like checking e-mail while talking on my office phone while unjamming the fax machines while trying to pick up the ringing cellphone," Susan Hay Cramer writes from Missoula, Mont., where she is a consultant on management and governance for local and national nonprofit organizations. "For me, the biggest challenge in terms of job performance is balancing the time I spend marketing myself and my services with the time I spend doing the actual work for which organizations hire me."
She says: "My biggest reality check was realizing that about 50 percent of my time is unbillable. No one pays me to buy office supplies or execute a dynamite marketing presentation or update my Web site (or unjam the fax machine)."
But she adds, "I may be someone who thrives on multitasking."
So how does she handle it all? "I write down (others would use a Palm Pilot, I'm sure) absolutely everywhere I have to be, everything I have to do and everyone I need to call, because I've learned the hard way that if I don't write it down, it doesn't get done.
"I carry a calendar both on my laptop (my constant companion) and a hard-copy version in my purse. And I've learned (also the hard way) to compose all e-mail to clients and prospects offline and then send it, to avoid erroneous (or embarrassing) transmissions."
Ms. Cramer says: "I'd write more, but I have a conference call with a client, during which time I will also be sorting laundry and packing for a trip out of town."
Henry Dubroff had a dream. In 1999 he was a business journalist, working as the editor of The Denver Business Journal. His dream was to own a newspaper company. So he quit his job and moved to Santa Barbara, Calif., with a start-up kit: a leased Saab, a checkbook and a business plan.
Today he is the chairman, chief executive, principal owner, president, publisher and editor of Pacific Coast Business Times, which he describes as "a thriving business journal that serves Santa Barbara, Ventura and San Luis Obispo Counties."
One of his first lessons, he writes, "was that our company's success depended very heavily on my ability to multitask."
"I have negotiated leases in the morning and edited real estate stories in the afternoon," Mr. Dubroff says. "I have sold ads over breakfast and written columns in the dead of night. I have delivered newspapers and met the payroll. And when the ad crunch hit in 2001, we had to let 6 of our 16 people go in order to keep the company afloat. That was hard. 
"Things are better now, and my multitasking has evolved. These days, my most important job is to keep our team of 10 people happy and motivated. Job No. 2 is to operate the company more or less within our budget -- but I have learned to make it fun.
"Recently, I took the company credit card to one of Santa Barbara's many thrift stores and for less than $25, I brought back 28 CorningWare plates and a mixed collection of stainless steel dinnerware that more or less serves 12. The result was a triple win. 
First, we will never again use paper plates at our semiregular company 'festivals.' Second, the new dishwasher that the landlord installed in the kitchen (see lease negotiations above) is being put to good use. Third, the long-term quality of life around the office has been kicked up a couple of notches. 
"For thousands of small-business owners like me, multitasking isn't just about doing e-mail and voice mail at the same time. That's the easy stuff. The hard stuff is doing whatever needs to be done to make the business go." 
Years ago, when Robin A. Kroft was looking for her first job after college in Toronto, a friend's mother looked her squarely in the eye and said: "Whatever you do, never admit you know how to type. As a woman, you will always have more earning power." 
That encounter, says Dr. Kroft, who now lives in Baltimore and whose expertise is in philanthropic studies, occurred before "keyboarding" at a computer made acceptable the notion that brains and typing could go hand in hand.
Dr. Kroft writes: "Recently, after the economy claimed a major donor, it became necessary to downsize the research foundation where I am a vice president. Faced with the challenge of running a grant program without secretarial support, I was pushed to call upon my closely held typing skills."
She said she had managed to teach herself how to create a special type of computerized letter that only the most revered support staff members had mastered.
"I wanted to celebrate by taking myself out to lunch on Secretary's Day," she said, "except I didn't have time."

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
Adjusting the Rules of Thumb on Refinancing

BYLINE:  By GREG RETSINAS 

 BODY:
DEBBIE BURNS didn't hesitate when she decided last week to refinance the mortgage on her one-story brick home in Cushing, Okla. She had already refinanced once, five years ago, but because of a continued decline in interest rates, doing it again seemed smart.
 But who would get her business? As the branch manager of a small, family-owned bank in Cushing, Ms. Burns, 53, said she was aware of the very attractive rates and terms offered by the larger banks in Oklahoma and in Internet offers and mail solicitations. 
 As good as they looked, she went back to the lender that had handled her loans in the past. Yes, she knew the firm and, yes, the service and good relationship were nice, but she was also determined to save money. 
"Their reputation is based on word of mouth, so they have to be competitive; I know I'll get the best deal out there," said Ms. Burns, who is refinancing a 30-year mortgage, which now carries a 7 percent rate. She said she was reviewing several options and, as of Thursday, had not decided on loan terms or rates.
Her lender, Mortgage Source of Stillwater, Okla., which offered a better deal than even the bank she works for, prides itself on repeat business. A'kos Kovach, the president and owner, says he often puts together "no cost" refinancings, in which he absorbs the closing costs except for a loan origination fee, just to keep the business.
"Most people don't like to talk about three things: sex, religion and their money," he said. "When they start talking about their finances, that's a very personal arena. The reason they do come back to me is they do have confidence their information is kept confidential."
The relationship between Mr. Kovach and Ms. Burns is just a snapshot from what has been the longest and strongest refinancing boom in more than four decades.
Going back to your lender, though, can mean different things. While small-town lenders like Mr. Kovach boast of working with repeat customers to bring their costs and rates down, larger companies say true savings are achieved only through them, because their high volume drives down prices. 
Some mortgage experts say the best approach may sound simplistic -- going back to your original lender and urging it to make a deal for your business. That can mean trying to persuade the lender to drop the interest rate of your original loan rather than writing a new one. But that approach can be impossible if your original lender sold your loan to a third party.
And the refinancing marketplace has changed as much as every other financial arena. LendingTree.com, a Web site that matches consumers with lenders, says that about 20 percent of its loan requests are repeat business. Given that the loans handled through the site are farmed out to different lenders, the chances of being paired up repeatedly with the same one are extremely remote.
Consolidation in the mortgage industry means that large companies are controlling more of the marketplace. Last year, for instance, five corporations handled more than 40 percent of all mortgage applications, although that may not be clear to the consumer because those corporations do business through hundreds of smaller firms.
Returning to your previous lender may provide a high comfort level, but the savings may not add up to much. The appraisal will often be waived, for example, saving a few hundred dollars, and the application fee, sometimes called the loan processing fee, may be bargained downward. Both may be accomplished with a new lender as well, though you may have to negotiate harder.
"My experience has found that sometimes you're able to get preferential deals, but sometimes you don't," said Kevin Iverson, president of Reed Mortgage in Denver. "I'm not so sure if you go back to your current lender that you're going to get a better deal, but at least it might be an easier process."
In any event, refinancings keep rolling along. Last year, there were 8.5 million refinancing applications, a record, for about $1.4 trillion in loans. The Mortgage Bankers Association of America estimates that there will be far more this year -- about 11.5 million refinancing applications representing nearly $2 trillion in loan value.
According to Freddie Mac, formerly the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, the average rate for a 30-year fixed mortgage was 5.34 percent last week, versus 6.81 percent a year ago. The average for a 15-year mortgage was 4.73 percent, down from 6.28 percent, and a one-year adjustable note was 3.61 percent, down from 4.85 percent.
The new lows have caused various forecasters to revise their industry projections. The mortgage bankers group predicts that refinancings will start to slow down this fall. Last week, three of every four mortgage applications were for refinancings; two weeks ago, it was two of every three.
"Things won't significantly slow until the fourth quarter," said Phil Colling, an economist at the Mortgage Bankers Association.
The National Association of Realtors expects the rate for 30-year loans to rise to 6.3 percent by the end of the year and then up to 6.6 percent next year.
A year ago, more people were refinancing mortgages mainly to gain more cash, by extending terms or loan amounts, thus increasing their personal debt. Now homeowners who are refinancing are generally doing so to take advantage of lower rates or to shift to 15-year or even 10-year loans, which can result in substantial interest savings, even though monthly payments are higher. 
The increase in 10-year mortgages, said Leonard Zumpano, executive director of the Real Estate Research and Education Center at the University of Alabama, reflects both lender creativity in persuading borrowers to keep refinancing and the thirst of consumers for better deals.
"The fact there has been such massive refinancings has forced lenders to look to new types of products that have a different appeal to borrowers," said Mr. Zumpano, who has refinanced twice in the last three years and now has a 30-year mortgage at 5.625 percent. "The lenders are thinking so many people have refinanced, that there's not much market left for them," he said.
The Banknorth Group, which provides loans in five New England states and upstate New York, sells about two-thirds of its loans to other companies. For those it keeps, bank officials say, it will often make an interest rate adjustment to an existing loan or waive certain fees to keep a customer's business.
This year, refinancings are about 70 percent of Banknorth's business, slightly below the industry level. David Stimpson, an executive vice president who runs the bank's mortgage division, said one obstacle to more refinancings is the time involved, given the backlog at appraisal companies, title firms and elsewhere in the loan process. The average Banknorth refinancing loan is approved within a week but then takes nearly two months to close, typical for the industry.
Richard Green, a Freddie Mac economist, said the growth of the market for 10- and 15-year loans showed the power of tumbling rates. The average age of a loan being refinanced is now just under two years, according to the latest Freddie Mac survey.
"Six months ago, we figured we'd burned through the refinancers," Mr. Green said. "But rates have fallen so much lower, we're seeing people again refinancing who just did three or four months ago. Each cycle, people get smarter. It's a lot harder to not know what's going on. If you have a Hotmail account, you're getting refinance e-mails."
Economists say refinancers should think of a mortgage as a service, not as a commodity. While the price of a commodity, like a sack of potatoes, is set by fairly straightforward market conditions, the interest rate on a refinanced mortgage is just part of the overall cost of that new loan. The total cost includes many fees, which can reach up to 2 percent of the value of the loan. Only some of those are negotiable, so customers often consider other factors, like service, convenience or speed, in choosing the lender.
THE old rule of thumb was to refinance only if the interest rate had dropped at least two percentage points from the original rate. But that guideline did not always take into account length of residency, existing household financial needs or other factors.
"That's bogus," Mr. Zumpano said of the rule. Some homeowners can benefit with even smaller rate cuts, although it depends on their circumstances, he said.
Yet a two-point drop may not be worthwhile. "Some borrowers really don't know the true costs of these refinancings -- not just the fees, but the cost of borrowing," he said.
He cited a long list of fees that may be added to a transaction, some more apparent than others. They include fees for legal and notary services, for getting a credit report and even for locking in an interest rate. Many borrowers may assume that another title search is unnecessary, but most lenders are still likely to ask for one.
In Oklahoma, Ms. Burns said she was hopeful that her lender had clearly laid out both the costs and the benefits of another refinancing.
"It's really important to me that I trust who I'm dealing with," she said.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH; 
The Rules on Bosses' Pay Seem Written With Pencil

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
OF all the big lies out there, the one that corporate executives' pay is linked to the performance of their companies takes the prize. No matter how much of the shareholders' wealth goes down the drain, the hired hands in the executive suite keep pocketing preposterous pay and insisting that it is based on results. 
 They have a reason for keeping the myth alive. If an executive's pay exceeds $1 million, companies receive a tax deduction only if the pay is performance-based. 
 So how do executives take home big packages even if their stock lags and they don't achieve the performance goals necessary for their pay to be considered results-oriented by the I.R.S.? Stroll through recent proxy statements and count the ways. 
One is to lower the bar on the performance hurdles that executives must clear to get bonuses or stock grants. Among the pioneers was AT&T Wireless, which stated in its proxy that factors "including slower-than-anticipated subscriber and revenue growth for the wireless industry, a challenging economy, the earlier-than-expected completion of a significant acquisition, other changes in the industry, and certain strategic decisions during the first half of 2002 resulted in the original targets no longer providing meaningful incentives." So the company's compensation committee reset the performance measures. Nice.
The State Street Corporation, a manager of financial assets, announced on May 6 that it was lowering the 18 percent rate at which return on equity had to grow before bonuses could be earned. Now it is 13 to 15 percent. 
Then there are the companies like the Bio-Technology General Corporation, in East Brunswick, N.J., which blather on about how compensation is based on performance but quietly note that executives can get bonuses when targets are not met if the compensation committee concludes that it's "in the best interests of the company."
Dave & Buster's Inc., a restaurant operator, said that while its compensation committee recognized that the company had not met its target for financial performance, its executives received incentive compensation awards based on "leadership skills, planning initiatives and employee development." Although the chief executive's bonus fell 40 percent last year, his salary and bonus together gave him a 7.5 percent raise.
"For top levels of senior management in companies such as this, at least 90 percent of any bonus should be based on hard financial targets," said Paul Hodgson, a senior research associate at the Corporate Library, a research group. "And if they are set at the beginning of the year and those targets are not reached, there is absolutely no excuse for the company to adjust targets downward in order to ensure compensation for executives."
Representatives of companies who returned calls said their actions were not only fair, but also needed to keep talented executives. At least the change at AT&T Wireless applied to half of its employees, not just top management. 
The softness in performance targets may explain why executives at so many laggards received pay raises last year. Equilar Inc., a compensation analysis firm in San Mateo, Calif., compared pay at the nation's 450 largest companies with returns in their stocks. Dividing the universe into quartiles, the firm found that while the median market value of companies in the third quartile fell 20.1 percent, their bosses made 4.9 percent more. More amazing, executives at the worst performers received the biggest option grants -- a median $4.52 million worth. 
Shareholders typically can vote on executive compensation only every five years. That makes it even more crucial to be vigilant about stopping the transfer of wealth from owners to executives that corporate compensation has come to represent.

HEADLINE: City Unions' Leadership 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"When Labor Bosses Were Boss" (news article, May 18) suggests that the leaders of New York City's large public-worker unions have failed to offer leadership in the current financial crisis. 
 Public-sector unions played the crucial role in mobilizing support for the Legislature's passage of a historic revenue package. 
 I also disagree with the comparison drawn between the city's current labor leadership and union leaders who faced the 1970's fiscal crisis.
We revere the accomplishments of our predecessors. Yet concessions made in the 70's have had permanent and negative consequences. One example is New York City's four-tiered pension system, in which city employees working side by side in identical jobs draw different benefits.
You seem to argue that the only way labor leaders can be statesmanlike is to agree to draconian cuts or otherwise compromise our members' interests. We chose a different route this time, asking first for increased revenue from those New Yorkers most able to pay.
This solution is in the best tradition of our movement.

CARL HAYNES
President, Teamster Local 237
New York, May 20, 2003

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2003 Kia Sorento; 
Why Kia Is No Longer a Punchline

BYLINE:  By NORMAN MAYERSOHN

 BODY:
IT used to be easy to ignore Kia, or laugh it off as the bottom-feeder of the auto market -- South Korea's answer to Yugo. When Kia began establishing American dealers in the mid-1990's, it mainly attracted buyers -- usually young, on a tight budget, or both -- in need of few-frills starter cars. For about the price of a used late-model vehicle, these shallow-pocket customers could drive away with a factory warranty and that new-car smell.
 That's all changing. Sure, Kia still claims the lowest-priced sedan sold in America, the $9,995 Rio, but with the introduction in 2001 of the midsize Optima, followed a year later by the Sedona minivan, Kia is gamely bootstrapping itself out of the basement -- even a full-size family sedan, the Amanti, is on the way. But Kia's best shot at breaking into the big leagues may be the 2003 Sorento, a midsize sport utility that extends Kia's reputation for creating vehicles that deliver a lot of equipment for relatively little money. 
 The Sorento is not just a collection of bells and whistles stuffed into the S.U.V. equivalent of an ill-fitting bargain-basement suit. Kia's new sport utility is an attractive package, contemporary in almost every way, with styling that appears to have borrowed a few licks from the Lexus RX or Mercedes-Benz M-Class, particularly around the angled roof pillar behind the back doors. And while the Sorento is well equipped -- all versions are powered by a modern 3.5-liter V-6 and are fitted with four-wheel disc brakes -- it lacks any single attribute that elevates it to must-have status.
That is, until you get to the window sticker: the rear-drive Sorento LX starts at $19,995, including the destination charge; the EX is $24,595 with part-time four-wheel drive and can be equipped with antilock brakes ($520) and a luxury package that includes leather upholstery and an automatic slip-sensing four-wheel-drive system, as well as a handful of other extra-cost items.
By Kia's estimates, the Sorento's price is $5,000 to $7,000 below comparably equipped S.U.V.'s of similar size -- a group that includes the Jeep Grand Cherokee, Nissan Pathfinder and Toyota Highlander. Sorento's 107 cubic feet of passenger room outdistances those three similar-size, five-passenger competitors, though the Kia falls short in cargo capacity, partly because the raked rear hatch intrudes on the rear compartment.
Put another way, Kia has delivered a midsize S.U.V. for the price of a compact cute-ute like the Honda CR-V, Ford Escape or Jeep Liberty.
A bit of background: Kia entered the American market under its own name in 1994 -- in the late 1980's it had built the forgettable Festiva for Ford -- and it joined the S.U.V. fray a year later with its small and rather crude Sportage. As the 90's closed, Kia found itself swept up in Korea's economic crisis, eventually becoming part of the large Hyundai Automotive Group through a stock acquisition. The American franchise has grown from a modest 12,163 sales in 1994 to 237,345 in 2002, and this year it is outselling long-established brands like Mazda and Mercury.
Students of the modern S.U.V. might logically presume that the Sorento is some toughened-up derivative of the Sedona minivan, in the way that the Acura MDX and Honda Pilot were conceived from the Honda Odyssey's gene pool. Not so. The Sorento's architecture is purely truck gear, and its body is bolted to a ladder-type frame with nine cross braces that was developed primarily for the American market.
Like many truck-based S.U.V.'s, four-wheel-drive models have a part-time transfer case, manually actuated with a dashboard knob, unless the buyer opts for the automatic torque-on-demand system. A rigid rear axle, like the Grand Cherokee's, promises off-road ruggedness.
The Sorento shares no chassis structure with the Hyundai Santa Fe, though it does borrow Hyundai's 192-horsepower 24-valve V-6 engine, which Kia has adapted to fit lengthwise in the engine compartment.
In my driveway, face to face with the Sorento EX for the first time, I was impressed by the roster of features and the quality of materials for a sticker price of $24,495. The design cannot be called a breakthrough, but the fit and finish of the panels were at least to class standards, the paint was excellent and the full roster of safety considerations included side-curtain air bags.
Thoughtful touches abound: the hood is held open by gas struts rather than a flimsy prop rod; the spare tire, tucked under the rear, is full-size and mounted on a matching alloy wheel. A clean layout and tasteful execution of the interior colors and textures assure that an owner won't develop an inferiority funk unless the neighbor rolls up in something that costs twice as much.
Still, there's room for improvement, even at this price. Losing the imitation wood on the dashboard, making antilock brakes standard and raising the wimpy 3,500-pound towing capacity would be a start. The fuel economy (an estimated 15 m.p.g. in town) could be a lot better.
While it's true that favorable labor costs and efficient factories explain part of Kia's price advantage, they don't cover all of it. Some of the difference results from the simplified option choices. Limiting the selection streamlines manufacturing, and without technology-intensive amenities like navigation and electronic antiskid systems, development costs can be constrained.
But the Sorento's occupants can feel it, too, in the lower level of refinement. The engine is willing, but doesn't break into a jubilant harmony when prodded; the suspension does a competent job of soaking up bumps, though without the polished, precise feel of more developed competitors. You get what you pay for and then some, but for the most part, the rule about free lunches still holds.
There's no question that the Sorento furthers Kia's position as a value leader. The list of standard equipment -- including air-conditioning, power windows and door locks, cruise control and an eight-speaker audio system with compact disc player -- clinches that. Buyers with doubts about Kia's durability will be comforted by a 5-year, or 60,000-mile, bumper-to-bumper warranty (including roadside assistance and some loaner car provisions) and the 10-year, or 100,000-mile, powertrain coverage that has already drawn many shoppers to showrooms.
The Sorento is too new to offer long-term reliability data. And while Kia remains the bottom-ranked automaker in the Initial Quality Survey by J. D. Power & Associates, it has shown steady gains. Brian Walters, director of product research at J. D. Power, said Kia's defects had dropped 36 percent over four years. "Kia's quality improvements are far outpacing the industry," he said, "and they are closing the gap" with mainstream competitors.
By most standards of judgment short of actually owning the Sorento for a while, Kia's S.U.V. seems to offer a tempting value proposition. It does not look cheap or drive cheaply -- quite the contrary -- and equals almost every attraction offered by its competitors, including a $1,000 rebate and interest-free financing.
For a lot less money, it delivers the comforts required of a midsize S.U.V., but without the leading edge in electronic controls and driver aids: antiskid technology, navigation systems, rear-seat video screens.
So while the Sorento may be a half-step behind the pack in techno-gadgetry -- the EX's altimeter and barometer notwithstanding -- drivers primarily concerned with high-value transportation may find that's no drawback at all.

INSIDE TRACK: Brand-name fashion at a generic-label price.

HEADLINE: Investing; 
For Many College Savings Plans, aYear of Lost Savings

BYLINE:  By JOHN KIMELMAN 

 BODY:
MOST investors in state-sponsored college savings plans have found that the performance of their portfolios bears much resemblance to the returns of the overall stock and bond markets.
 Portfolios tied to the stock market have generally fallen sharply in the last year, while those with substantial bond holdings have generally performed well. 
 Named for a section of the tax code, the 529 savings plans allow Americans to save for their children's college education without incurring federal taxes, and some states provide other tax benefits. Investors have poured money into the plans, which had $29 billion in assets as of March 31, with about 3.5 million children listed as beneficiaries, said Joseph F. Hurley, founder and chief executive of Savingforcollege.com, a Web site that provides information on the plans. 
The 529 plans were established in 1996 and gained popularity in January 2002 after a change in federal law making withdrawals exempt from income taxes. 
In the 12 months through March, the most recent returns available, investors lost money in every portfolio focused on the stock market, according to data from Morningstar Inc. The average 529 stock portfolio lost 25.8 percent in that period, underperforming the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index by one percentage point. (Many 529 plans may be faring better in the second quarter this year, given the 10 percent gain in the S.& P. 500 since March 31.)
Age-based portfolios, the most popular choice for investors across the country, also lost money in the 12 months through March. These portfolios contain a blend of stocks and bonds. They are heavily weighted in stocks when a beneficiary is a young child, then gradually accumulate bonds as she approaches college age. The average portfolio appropriate for a 5-year-old, for example, lost 17.8 percent in the 12 months. 
By contrast, fixed-income portfolios had a gain of 8.24 percent, on average, in the period, and were up 2.18 percent in the first quarter this year, Morningstar said. 
In addition, nearly half the states offer guaranteed fixed-income portfolios that use insurance policies to safeguard principal. These portfolios generally promise a return of 3 or 4 percent a year -- a modest amount that still compares favorably with most investments in the stock market over the last three years. (Some states offer prepaid tuition plans that are exempt from federal taxes under Section 529 of the tax code.)
The returns of the various college savings portfolios roughly parallel those of similar investments in mutual funds, Mr. Hurley said. "These return results are in line with the results that an investor would get outside of a college savings planif you followed the same allocation formula," he said. 
While investors are free to choose among many plans approved by the 50 states and the District of Columbia, many states provide tax breaks for investors who choose their home state's plan. New York, for example, allows state residents to deduct up to $5,000 annually from their taxable income for investments in the New York State plan, which is run by TIAA-CREF; the deduction jumps to $10,000 for a married couple. 
But tax benefits may be of little use to investors with money-losing portfolios. Among the worst performers have been specialized technology and growth portfolios run by companies like Alliance Capital, which manages Rhode Island's plan, and Pacific Life, which manages one of Montana's. These investments lost more than 40 percent over the 12 months through March and were down slightly in the first quarter, Morningstar said.
There were wide variations in the returns of age-based plans. For example, a number of aggressively managed age-based portfolios intended for a 5-year-olds lost 23 percent or more in the 12 months through March. An aggressive, age-based plan run for South Carolina by Banc of America Advisors lost 25 percent, Morningstar said. 
More conservative age-based plans, with a smaller weighting of stocks, have had smaller losses. A conservative portfolio intended for a 5-year-old and managed by Van Kampen Investments for Alabama's state plan lost 0.5 percent in the 12 months.
Federal rules allow Americans to switch investment options in a 529 plan once a year. Financial advisers and marketers of the plans say investors should be careful when they choose their portfolios.
"We let them know in the literature that there are no guarantees with this kind of investing," said Dale A. Hatch, deputy executive director of the Utah Educational Savings Plan, which has attracted many out-of-state investors because it uses low-cost index funds from the Vanguard Group. 
Investors in bond portfolios have had little to complain about. The best-performing fixed-income funds returned 14 percent in the year through March, and the worst performers lost only a few percentage points. 
Still, Neil G. Carousso, a financial planner in Whitestone, Queens, said fixed-income portfolios should be used only by investors who are trying to preserve capital, either because they are risk averse or because they are saving for someone who will be entering college soon. "Remember that bonds over the long term won't keep up with the general stock market," he said. "And with almost four years of down markets, I would lean toward advising investors to have a more aggressive asset allocation."
MOST financial advisers are generally reluctant to steer investors toward narrowly focused college saving portfolios like those focused on technology stocks, unless they are part of a well-considered asset allocation strategy. 
Richard A. Davies, an executive at Alliance Capital who oversees the nationwide marketing campaign for Rhode Island's 529 plan, for example, said investors shouldn't bet too heavily on his firm's tech fund or on its other specialized portfolios.
"We offer these individual funds, but it's our recommendation that people invest in age-based portfolios" or in broad-based stock portfolios, he said. 
TIAA-CREF, the asset management firm that oversees college savings programs in 13 states, including New York, California and Connecticut, has avoided offering portfolios that emphasize specific sectors of the stock or bond markets. "We want to spread the risk of owning stocks and bonds," said Timothy E. Lane, TIAA-CREF's vice president for tuition financing. 
Advocates of 529 plans say the programs continue to make investment sense, despite the disappointing results for many investors. "When you factor in the potential tax savings," Mr. Hurley of Savingforcollege .com said, "they are doing well enough in enough cases to show that the whole idea is a good one."

CORRECTION-DATE: June 1, 2003

 CORRECTION:
A table last Sunday with an article about the performance of the college savings plans known as 529's referred incompletely to the return data calculated by Morningstar Inc. When mutual funds underlying the plans' portfolios were older than the portfolios themselves, Morningstar based the longer-term returns on the portfolios' current allocation of mutual funds. The portfolio returns assumed reinvestment of dividends and capital gains and included portfolio expenses, but excluded sales charges, enrollment fees and taxes.

HEADLINE: Defending the Right Not to Have a Nice Day 

BYLINE:  By WARREN ST. JOHN 

 BODY:
ON a rainy morning last week at his office at the West 57th Street headquarters of CBS News, Andy Rooney, the nation's curmudgeon in chief, took a few minutes to talk about the virtues of complaining. He sat in his familiar spot behind the walnut desk he made himself, and in front of a bookshelf full of titles that seemed to say something about their owner: there was lots of H. L. Mencken, a copy of Bertrand Russell's "Sceptical Essays" and a book called "The Worst of Everything."
 "The only way to correct what's wrong is to talk about it," Mr. Rooney said. "A restaurant needs complaints or it's never going to fix what's not going right." 
 He leaned forward in his chair, scrunched his bushy eyebrows together and adopted that quizzically philosophical tone he uses in his Sunday night broadcasts. 
"I don't know why we're so evasive," he said. "People are not honest about what they say. Part of it passes for good manners, and part of it is wanting to be liked by not being negative about things. Negative does not have a good reputation as compared with affirmative."
Indeed, these are tough times for America's cranks, complainers and curmudgeons. Maybe because there's so much that is genuinely wrong -- with threats of terrorism and a rotten economy -- Americans just aren't in the mood for pessimism. And anyway, in a culture dominated by the relentlessly cheery ethos of the self-help movement, grumps and contrarians are frequently dismissed as mildly delusional, or worse, viewed as malignancies that must be isolated and cut out.
If there were any doubt that cranks are under siege, consider that on Wednesday a group calling itself Smile Mania is putting on a national event called the Great American Grump Out, which aims to do for cantankerousness what the Great American Smoke-Out did for tobacco addiction. Janice Hathy, a 55-year-old stress management consultant from Venice, Fla., has been promoting the Grump Out with a series of happiness exercises; she recently headed a "drive-by smiling" in which she and some local students stood at an intersection and flashed cardboard smiley-faces at passing motorists. On the big day, she said, she and a "grump patrol" will don clown-noses, blow bubbles and hand out bananas. ("When you look at them sideways, they look like smiles," she explained.) They plan to establish "no grumping zones" in her hometown and to urge their fellow citizens toward positivity and optimism. 
Ms. Hathy likens negativity to a plague. "It makes us sick and keeps us sick," she said.
Barbara S. Held, a psychology professor at Bowdoin College and the author of "Stop Smiling, Start Kvetching," a book about the virtues of curmudgeonliness, said the Grump Out is part of what she calls "the tyranny of the positive attitude in America."
"It's telling people there's one way to be -- smile, be positive," she said. "First you feel bad, then you're told you're defective for not being cheerful about it." Ms. Held added that the pervasive feeling that iconoclastic ideas are unhealthy may be depriving younger Americans of what she called "the right nutrients to grow a curmudgeonly attitude."
Indeed, America might be facing a curmudgeon shortage. The country's best-known cranks are aging -- Mr. Rooney is 84, Gore Vidal is 77, Art Buchwald is 77, Jimmy Breslin is 73 and even Fran Lebowitz, 52, is getting up there -- or else they're imported, like Christopher Hitchens, Andrew Sullivan and Simon Cowell, the grouchy judge on American Idol. It's enough to make one feel pessimistic about pessimism.
So how many curmudgeons are there? It's hard to get a tally, in part because few curmudgeons will cop to their curmudgeonliness. Mr. Rooney, for example, said he never cared for the term and doesn't know why it's applied to him. Ms. Lebowitz said she preferred the term "realist." Bill Maher, the former host of "Politically Incorrect" on ABC, who lost his job after he angered network executives with comments about Sept. 11, said he wasn't one, and that he wasn't a contrarian either.
"When people hear contrarian they think that you're trying to be contrary," he said. "No, we are just of the opinion that the rest of you are crazy. I really do think religion is bad and drugs are good," he added, "and I really am for mad cow disease."
Mr. Maher said he has long felt like an outsider. "When Ronald Reagan used to say 'It's morning in America,' I always thought to myself, 'But I'm not a morning person,' " he said.
Jon Winokur, the author of "The Portable Curmudgeon" and a self-described connoisseur of curmudgeons, said the term suggested "a crust of misanthropy," and added that most curmudgeons are characterized by an ability to "combine malice with wit." George Carlin, Dennis Miller, Mr. Vidal and Mr. Breslin make his list of favorite cranks. Mr. Winokur said he knew of only one genuinely young American curmudgeon, 31-year-old Geoff Shackelford, a golf writer who makes a living writing cantankerous reviews of golf courses. Mr. Shackelford said he's been on a curmudgeon's apprenticeship of sorts, reading lots of Mencken. But he said it's not easy being a young grouch. 
"Look at comedy now; that says it all," he said. "Much of it has gravitated towards slapstick, like Jackass, instead of a Mel Brooks, Carl Reiner 'Let's have fun with stereotypes.' "
"It's the death of being able to make a joke about something," he said. 
So what does it matter if there are fewer cranks? Julie K. Norem, a professor of psychology at Wellesley College and the author of "The Positive Power of Negative Thinking," said curmudgeons actually serve an important cultural role. "They help us as a society to avoid complacency," she said. "Most people would rather avoid the negative."
Ms. Norem said most curmudgeons are what she calls "defensive pessimists," people who think about what could go wrong, rather than what could go right. She called the trait "the opposite of denial," and said it could have a positive effect. By thinking of negative outcomes, defensive pessimists prepare themselves practically and psychologically for unpleasant outcomes. 
Alan Zweig, an admitted crank and a filmmaker currently at work on a documentary called "I, Curmudgeon," takes a predictably dimmer view. Mr. Zweig said that in his experience the only people who benefit from encountering curmudgeons are other curmudgeons. He gave an example. Suppose you're in a bar, he said, and Celine Dion is blaring on the juke box. "You look around and everybody is saying, 'This is so great -- I want to play this at my wedding,' " he said. "Then somebody comes along and says, 'Hey, turn this garbage off.' That's a great moment," he said. "You needed that."
"If you're the least bit negative or suspicious you can go crazy if you don't hear the odd person saying something you think too," he said. 
But being the lone voice of reason, he said, can have a social cost. Mr. Zweig was at a party a few years ago when a Nike commercial featuring the late writer and heroin appreciator William S. Burroughs appeared on the television. Offended by the idea of an addict selling sneakers to kids, he launched into a curmudgeonly rant. "Everybody looked at me like, 'Ooo, that guy, he gets all worked up over a sneaker commercial. That's kind of sad, that guy with his lonely opinion,' " he said.
"There is a level of self-destructiveness to it," he said. "Curmudgeons don't pick their battles, they fight every battle."
The isolation of curmudgeons in America may be rooted in our country's heritage. Ms. Held, the Bowdoin psychologist, pointed out that Alexis de Tocqueville wrote in 1840 that America was built on the profoundly uncurmudgeonly idea of "the indefinite perfectibility of man."
"By virtue of being conceived in a democratic country we are by nature optimistic," she said.
Even so, Ms. Norem said that according to her research, between 25 and 30 percent of Americans are defensive pessimists, and therefore have the foundations of a curmudgeonly attitude. (In France, she said, the number is closer to 50 percent.) 
In laboratory studies, she said, she has found that defensive pessimists can do better at everything from puzzles to throwing darts if they are allowed to engage in anxious worrying beforehand. Show the pessimists a nice relaxing nature video before the tasks, and they do worse. The lesson, Ms. Norem said, is not that everyone should be negative, but rather, that pessimists and curmudgeons should get in touch with their inner negativity and embrace it.
On Grump Out day, Fran Lebowitz said, she plans to do just that. "In order to be cheery, you have to be unconscious," she said. "And anything that has the word 'out' in it, I don't like -- except 'Get out.' "

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH/Steven C. Leuthold; 
Leuthold Core Investment Fund

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
STEVEN C. LEUTHOLD, lead manager of the $160 million Leuthold Core Investment fund, is extremely bullish about the stock market.
 Since the fall, the price-to-earnings ratio of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index has pointed to a big market rebound, he said. "In October, stock prices reached their median valuation levels from 1957 through 2003," he said from his office in Minneapolis. "Our work shows that half of all bear markets have stopped at that point." 
 The fund now has a 70 percent stake in stocks, as high as it typically goes, and nearly double the allocation 12 months ago. 
"Corporate bonds and Treasuries seem terrifically overvalued now," he said. "We can't find anything to buy that looks attractive except high-yield bonds." These bonds account for 15 percent of the fund's assets, the most permitted. The remainder of the assets are in cash, 10 percent, and real estate investment trusts, 5 percent.
The fund returned 3 percent a year, on average, for the three years through Thursday, placing among the top 13 percent of all domestic hybrid funds, which own a mix of stocks and bonds. That category lost 2.3 percent and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was down 11.4 percent, both annualized, during that time, according to Morningstar Inc. The fund gained 1.3 percent in the last 12 months, compared with declines of 4.4 percent for its group and 12.6 percent for the index.
Mr. Leuthold, 65, is chairman and chief executive of Leuthold Weeden Capital Management, the fund's investment adviser. James E. Floyd, 56, is a managing director of the adviser and co-manager of the fund. Andrew J. Engel, 43, the fund's other co-manager, is vice president of the adviser.
Mr. Leuthold and Mr. Engel allocate the fund's assets by using a proprietary computer model that is run weekly and has more than 170 variables. "We've got all the bases covered," Mr. Engel said. "We try to quantify and take the emotions out of our investment decisions."
To measure fundamental value, the model uses variables like ratios of price to earnings and price to cash flow. To gauge investor sentiment, it checks consumer confidence indexes, for example, and cash flows into mutual funds.
The model also looks at insider-trading patterns, the volume of new issues, and other measures of investor supply and demand. Among its technical measures are stock price movements and trading volume. Finally, the model considers economic indicators by reviewing interest rates and inflation, among other things.
Each variable receives a weighting based on reliability, Mr. Leuthold said, and the results are compiled into a single ratio. When that ratio is more than 1.05, he said, the managers are very bullish on the stock market. When it falls to less than 0.95, he said, the managers become cautious.
The ratio is now at about 1.3, explaining their exuberance about equities.
"We think that there is more potential and probably not much more risk in stocks than in U.S. Treasuries right now," Mr. Leuthold said. 
Bond analysis, he said, is not his firm's strength, so he invests the fund's 15 percent stake in junk bonds in three no-load junk-bond funds: T. Rowe Price High Yield, Strong High Yield Bond and Northeast Investors.
IN February, the fund began buying shares of Nextel Communications, the wireless communications company. The managers paid $12.50, on average, for the entire position; the stock is now at $14.88. "Nextel is part of our telecom survivors thesis," Mr. Floyd said. "We believe the severe three-year telecom shake-out has taken down the good companies along with the poor ones."
As the economy improves, he added, the managers expect that telecommunications products and services will rebound and that stronger names, like Nextel, will gain market share from weaker companies. He projects that its earnings-per-share growth will average about 15 percent annually over the next three to five years.
The managers also own shares of Biosite, a company in San Diego that develops tests to improve doctors' ability to diagnose disease. Mr. Floyd said Biosite was in position to benefit from moves to lower health care costs; he expects the company's earnings to grow 30 percent a year, on average, over the next three to five years. The fund bought shares in February, paying $35.50, on average; the stock is now at $44.76.
Another holding is Foundry Networks, a company in San Jose, Calif., that designs, makes and sells computer networking products. "As profits continue to improve, we expect business to increase its capital spending," Mr. Floyd said. "One beneficiary of this trend will be technology stocks, and networking stocks in particular." He projects a long-term earnings growth rate for the company averaging 15 to 20 percent a year.
The fund began buying shares in August, paying $7.80, on average. The stock now trades at $13.93

HEADLINE: Business; 
Where Greed Is Good, A Mob Opportunity

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM J. HOLSTEIN 

 BODY:
GARY WEISS, the author of "Born to Steal: When the Mafia Hit Wall Street," argues that mob-related brokerage firms, including one that employed the subject of his book, a small-time crook from Staten Island named Louis Pasciuto, have been able to steal millions of dollars in securities frauds. 
 The ease with which they recently have done so suggests there is a basic problem in how Wall Street is regulated. Following are excerpts from an interview.
 WILLIAM J. HOLSTEIN

Q. Did the mob's involvement in unscrupulous brokerage firms, or chop houses, and similar kinds of fraud help set the stage for the abuses that occurred during the Internet bubble?

A. I think they did. What you had was a certain mind-set on Wall Street. Greed is the only thing that matters. The making of money by any means necessary is life itself. It's this credo that the chop houses had and that became the credo of Wall Street.
After he started cooperating with authorities, Louis was reading about these dot-com criminals and these analysts who were lying to people. He had always wanted to be in the legitimate Wall Street. But he realized he had been in the real Wall Street all along. The chop house Wall Street and the real Wall Street were the same phenomenon.

Q. Was financial fraud a major moneymaker for the mob, or just a sideline?

A. You can never be 100 percent certain. They don't publish financial statements. But as best as organized-crime experts can ascertain, Wall Street and brokerage firms by the late 90's were a major moneymaker. They used to have the numbers racket in Harlem. They used to have the Fulton Fish Market. They used to have garbage. They went seamlessly into Wall Street.

Q. Many were arrested. Is the mob still there?

A. Yes. They'll never be gone. You're talking about a subculture of people in certain neighborhoods of New York City and throughout the country.
Organized crime is a subculture, a lifestyle. It endures because the lifestyle is enviable. People like to get books written about them. They like to become famous. They like for TV series to get done about them. They're pursuing the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow. You could put the bosses in jail forever, and it's not going to affect what's going on on the street.

Q. Exactly what game are they playing now?

A. Frankly, I don't have up-to-the-minute sources. I was able to find out what the mob was doing on the Street after the fact because people were willing to talk about it. Anybody who tells you they know what the mob is doing today is lying. You just don't know. They're involved in unions, they're involved in gambling, and they're involved in loan sharking. But have they found something new and innovative? Is there some guy sitting at a social club saying, "I've got an angle?" There's no way to know.

Q. What role did the leaders of the NASD play in allowing these abuses to occur?

A. They had a tendency to look the other way. They did not do a good job of combating the Mafia. They didn't do a good job of combating stock fraud. I think they simply were not interested in going after the chop houses. A little bit like the French army in 1940, they were prepared to fight the First World War, not the Second. The NASD was ready to fight the scamsters of 1983 or 1985.

Q. How much of the stock market bust can we blame on the mob?

A. That's an impossible task. Nobody really knows. But I'd say we're talking about billions, well into billions. If you compared the amount of money lost by stock fraud and defined it broadly to include analysts lying to their customers, stuff going on in big firms and improper accounting, if you look at that as one entity, we're talking billions and billions. How much of that would be mob-related?
It would be a small percentage. You have to look at the mob stuff as an example of the character of Wall Street run amok. I don't think that anyone would say stock fraud is Mafia-dominated.
The gangsters were able to latch on to this great American phenomenon of stock fraud. What is there about Wall Street that, without blinking an eye, the Mafia can come in. Doesn't that tell you something? It tells you something about the morality of Wall Street and the regulation of Wall Street.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gary Weiss says the mob's ability to move into Wall Street demonstrates the flaws in regulation. (Warner Books)

HEADLINE: No Power, No Rebirth In IraqiBusiness 

BYLINE:  By NEELA BANERJEE 

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq 

 BODY:
LAST Tuesday, like most days since the war, there were no customers in Rahim Dhiyakh's butcher shop. The heavy sides of beef and lamb hanging from wall hooks shone dark and glassy, spoiling in the heat.
 Before the war and Iraq's troubled peace, Mr. Dhiyakh's shop would stay open until midnight, but now, with most of his business gone, it closes at around 4 p.m. The shop gets only a couple of hours of electricity a day, far too little to keep the freezer running. His customers, mostly women, are too frightened to venture out during the evening on Baghdad's dark and often lawless streets. 
 "Electricity is the main problem," Mr. Dhiyakh said, as one of his employees washed a large tree stump used as a butcher block. "Electricity means safety, work. It's the chain of life." 
In the most palpable of ways, the American promise of a new Iraq is floundering on the inability of the American occupiers to provide basic services, particularly electricity, in Baghdad, a city with five million residents, about the size of metropolitan Houston, and the country's economic heart. On the priority list of places where power must be restored here in the capital, business and industry are last, after hospitals, water and sewage treatment plants and residential areas. The logic to the list is that homes account for 80 percent of electricity demand in the city, while business and industry consume 4 to 8 percent, said Dr. Karim W. Hassan, the interim head of the national electricity commission. 
But businesspeople here warn that the the slow pace of power restoration to industry and commerce could devastate what's left of an economy already weakened by 12 years of sanctions.
"The impact of this is a ripple effect," said Maazen Baaghet, co-owner of al-Shumuz, which makes plastic shopping bags in a factory in the capital's industrial Jamila district. "If I can't operate 24 hours a day, then my workers can't get the salaries they used to, and that affects the buying power of the household. That spreads through the state and the country. And if this keeps up, it will lead to the economic deterioration of the country."
From Mr. Dhiyakh's butcher shop to Mr. Baaghet's factory to large chemical plants to the refineries that make the gasoline and cooking gas now in shortage here, businesses, even those with their own power generators, have sharply scaled back production. Without electricity, people do not go to work or have work to go to. And without street lights, the city faces an even higher crime rate, residents say. Amid such privations, one of the few things that thrives now in Baghdad, at least, is a deepening distrust and anger toward the United States. 
"We were hoping that the Americans would rescue us," said Ameen al-Haj, 57, co-owner of the Is'Haki Dairy Farm Company, one of Baghdad's oldest and largest dairy plants. "I still have that hope, but now I'm not so certain. In the last one and a half months, things have just gotten worse."
BUSINESSPEOPLE here are especially frustrated because most of Iraq's power plants were unscathed by the war and much of the country actually has more power than it did before the fighting. But Baghdad is the choke point. Shooting and bombing badly damaged the high-voltage power lines that move electricity into and around the city. Iraqi engineers, with the help of the United States Army Corps of Engineers and the Bechtel Group, the primary American contractor for rebuilding here, are working frantically to repair hundreds of severed high-voltage lines.
The American administration here says that the power shortage is easing and that people in Baghdad get about eight hours of electricity a day. Dr. Hassan estimated significant improvement by the end of June. But the distribution of electricity is very uneven in the city, and Iraqi engineers in charge of repairing the grid say that most of Baghdad gets far less -- and at erratic times. The power sometimes vanishes for days.
"Sometimes people get three hours, four, five," said Shaker Karim, chief engineer of the middle region network of the electricity commission, who oversees 40 crews that repair power lines around the city. "If you get six, you are very, very, very lucky."
Baghdad will need less electricity this summer than it did last year because industry will not be running at full strength, said Peter Gibson, the senior American adviser to Iraq's electricity commission and a civilian employee of the Corps of Engineers. But that trend is already clear to Bagdad's businesses.
Outside Mr. Haj's dairy plant, on a street in central Baghdad, the air still smells sweetly milky. But because the plant receives just two hours of electricity a day, it is running nowhere near full strength. Just after the fall of Baghdad, he said, the plant got about four hours. As a result, the plant's production has dwindled to 20 metric tons of products daily, compared with 100 metric tons before the war. Customers are buying less now, he said, because they do not have the electricity to refrigerate the products. Once able to turn a healthy profit, Is'Haki now barely breaks even, Mr. Haj said.
Is'Haki's production has been aided by its two generators. But they sometimes malfunction, forcing the plant to throw out entire batches of food. The generators cannot run round the clock, and neither does the plant anymore. At 2 p.m. on a recent day, workers in rubber boots and white coats were hosing down the floors of the plant and moving some products into a cooler to close the plant for the day. All the employees at that hour were men, the women having been sent home earlier because of long travel times and fear of the crime that could come with nightfall. Mr. Haj is trying not to cut any jobs.
"I have a staff of 250 here," he said. "If I close my factory now, what would they live on?"
The Iraqi electricity grid was frail even before this latest war, said Mohammed al-Atif, chief engineer for Baghdad's electrical distribution system, which includes the lower-voltage power lines that deliver power into homes. He said the grid's condition reflected the accumulated damage and neglect from the Iran-Iraq War, the Persian Gulf war of 1991 and then the sanctions imposed by the United Nations, which were rescinded only last week. 
At full production, Iraqi power plants can generate around 5,500 megawatts, said Haitham al-Yassein, head of the Iraqi transmission network's technical office. (One megawatt is enough for about 1,000 homes.) But the country needs about 6,800 megawatts at peak times, Mr. Yassein said. 
To make up for the difference, electricity had been rationed around the country, with Baghdad, as the seat of power, receiving a disproportionately large share and the rest of the country losing out. For example, the northern city of Mosul got only four hours of electricity a day in previous summers, but Baghdad routinely received nearly 20 hours a day by importing it from regions deemed less important. 
Several times a week, Iraqi electricity industry officials meet with Americans in one of Saddam Hussein's palaces to discuss repair progress. On Thursday, the Iraqis and Americans worried aloud about how regions that were once compelled to export power to Baghdad are now so flush with a sense of freedom that they are rebelling. 
"It's a good sign of democracy," Dr. Hassan said to the other men around the table, "but these other power stations are making trouble at the wrong time."
Whenever a new issue seems to be resolved in the repair of the grid, another flares. The meeting often begins with the chairman, Maj. Gen. Steven Hawkins of the Army Corps of Engineers, receiving a quick report about how many cars belonging to Iraqi engineers were stolen in the preceding few days. At another meeting recently, the Iraqis told him that two cars had been stolen, including one containing a hydraulic compressor needed to refasten severed power lines.
The repair effort may be getting a boost now that power-grid specialists from Bechtel have arrived in the city. The company received a contract worth up to $680 million from the United States Agency for International Development to repair nearly all of Iraq's infrastructure, except for the oil and telecommunications industries. 
For now, Bechtel is taking a decidedly low-profile approach to working in Iraq, portraying its function as more of a handmaiden's than a leader's. "We understand the impatience" among the Iraqis to have their electricity restored, said Thomas Wheelock, the international development agency's infrastructure team leader, who is working with Bechtel here. "We want to enable the Iraqi management. We feel like we're in a supporting role to the Iraqis."
Bechtel has about 120 people in Kuwait who are gradually arriving in Iraq to work on all the infrastructure projects; at least 15 are already in the country working on electricity, said Michael Robinson, Bechtel's power sector manager for the Iraqi reconstruction. The Bechtel electricity specialists are now visiting Iraqi power plants to assess what is most needed to improve electricity output in the short run before sitting down to detailed discussions with the Iraqis about longer-term work, Mr. Robinson said.
BECHTEL'S quick appointment to rebuild Iraq has been a contentious issue in the United States, where critics say it won the contract in bidding that was limited to a few American companies because of political connections. Still, the company's presence here appears to be addressing the pent-up needs of Iraqi power engineers, who have been handing Bechtel representatives a wish list of the many parts and types of equipment they have needed for years. The company is already providing chemicals to power plants and equipment to repair the high-voltage lines. 
But Iraqi engineers and technicians are doing almost all the back-breaking work of splicing power lines and digging down to cables in 110-degree heat. On a recent morning, Mr. Karim, the chief engineer, visited a crew repairing downed power lines that have run through the dusty yards of High Voltage Street, a procession of high towers through the Ghazalia district of western Baghdad. "The work," Mr. Karim said, standing in a garbage heap on the side of the road where his employees were working, "is primitive, very primitive."
With hard hats their only protection, the half-dozen men used a truck with a winch to drag together two pieces of a fat aluminum cable severed during the war. Schoolchildren pestered them like flies, asking them to turn on the electricity again. The workers cut the frayed ends off the cables and clamped them together, leaving the section of cable looking as segmented as a finger and not terribly reliable.
So far, it is the best the Iraqis can do until they get more equipment from the Americans, Mr. Karim and other engineers said. Warehouses filled with spare parts and equipment were looted. Mr. Karim's own storage room is shuttered and bricked in, a hole in a broken window to the room serving as a portal onto the hills of ash left after it was burned.
Looting has continued, though maybe in a more organized form. Mr. Atif of the distribution system said thieves with cranes cut overhead lines at night to pilfer the copper and the insulation material, which they sell as scrap to neighboring countries. 
Mr. Baaghet's plastic-bag factory is in an industrial zone surrounded by smelters that he and his partner know melt the stolen copper. One day, he said, a truck rattled past the neighborhood carrying electric cable insulation material that clearly had been used.
The factory, al-Shumuz, is getting the same two to three hours of electricity it received immediately after the war and is working at less than 40 percent of capacity. Of the dozens of factories in Baghdad that made such simple shopping bags before the war, only three to five are working now, Mr. Baaghet said, and none at full strength.
"We can't go on much longer like this," he said. "Perhaps another four months, and then we'll have to shut down."
One of his suppliers, Makki al-Jenabi, sat watching his 4-year-old son, Mohammed Makki, buzz around Mr. Baaghet's desk. Reckoning that there would be some instability after the war, Mr. Jenabi, 38, had socked away about 20 tons of raw material for plastic bags to sell to his clients. But he is running out and unable to produce more because, unlike Mr. Baaghet, he has no generator.
"I figured that after a month, everything would be all right," Mr. Jenabi said. "But out of six employees, I only have two now. When I let the other four ago, I had to apologize for how things are."
