HEADLINE: Motor City 

BYLINE:  By FIELD MALONEY; Field Maloney is on the editorial staff of The New Yorker.

 BODY:
AMONG the attractions of Hunts Point, that patch of the South Bronx that juts out into the East River like a clenched asphalt fist, are a juvenile prison; ominously shuttered drinking establishments with names like Al's Mr. Wedge; informal, and illegal, late-night drag races on the weekends; and the world's largest wholesale fruit and vegetable market. Since the 1940's, the Point, as natives call it, has also been a grease monkey mecca, with almost 200 junkyards, garages and used auto parts shops packed into a couple of square miles. 
 Dead cars from all over the city and country, thousands and thousands of them, enter the automotive afterlife here. Pilgrims in search of the city's cheapest used crankshafts and U-joints and carburetors follow right behind. What doesn't get dismantled to reappear as someone's bumper or radiator or door, gets crushed, shredded, baled and loaded onto a container ship full of scrap metal headed to Asia, where it is melted down into low-grade steel. 
 People who work in junkyards tend toward blithe pessimism. And for the last decade or so, everyone on the Hunts Point auto strip has had extra reason to be dour. Local proprietors say that historically, the fortunes of the city's junkyards, like those of the bond market, have dwindled in boom times and flourished in busts. In the last decade, business was generally slow. A booming city didn't have much need for bargain parts. But with the economy faltering,the scavengers are returning to Hunts Point.
 They come from all over the Bronx, from the other boroughs, from Long Island and New Jersey. Rarely do these hunters and gatherers come alone. Foraging for car parts tends to be a social activity -- for the technical counsel, for support in heavy negotiations, for the pleasure of a sunny day's drive up to the Bronx with company. They come in pairs: fathers and sons, neighborhood buddies, young couples; or in threesomes. Sometimes even a "Cheaper by the Dozen"-type family entourage pulls up, chasing down, say, a carburetor for a 1989 Dodge minivan. Customers confer among themselves in the many dialects of the language Car: from Hindi to Korean, from Haitian French to Turkish.
 Customers like Derrick Johnson and his cousin Mike, who live on the same block of the Grand Concourse in the Bronx and were looking for a driver's-side door to Derrick's '94 Toyota. He pointed to his old door -- it looked as if it had come in second in a demolition derby -- and shook his head sadly.
 "Got took out by a plow on the first snowstorm," he said. "Didn't slow the plow down much."
 For Paul Song, from Fort Lee, N.J., going to Hunts Point was a kind of homecoming. Mr. Song, a spiky-haired skateboarder in an Army surplus parka, wore like a badge the streetwise manner and hip-hop inflection that he'd absorbed as a kid growing up in the Bronx. He had driven out from Fort Lee with his father, a courtly silver-haired man, who rode shotgun. The elder Mr. Song sat in the car while his son haggled over the price of a grill for their Mazda. Every now and then his son leaned in the window to brief him, formally, in Korean, on the course of the negotiations. The elder Mr. Song made a few strategic nods, but said nothing. 
 Then there was the Bronx-Italian mother and daughter team in search of a bumper, and the young Latino couple who, while waiting for a driver's-side headlight to be mounted, strolled through the junkyards. They held hands as they stepped around discarded tires and oil-slick potholes.
 HUNTS POINT isn't the city's only hub of car culture. Like mushrooms around a stump, blocks devoted to automotive commerce spring up on the margins in all five boroughs: under highway overpasses, in failing warehouse districts; places where land comes cheap, and residents, if there are any, don't have enough clout to make a fuss about the piles of rusting steel littering the landscape, the dust and the noise. 
 Places like the section of Corona, Queens, behind Shea Stadium (which, in aerial photos, has the dazzling, eerie look of a virus seen under a color microscope: a giant, garish mass of scrap metal slowly colonizing the entire borough). Or where Jerome Avenue runs over the Cross Bronx Expressway, and under the elevated No. 4 tracks. (Thirty auto glass shops are squeezed together on a single block there: employees carry signs on the streets to lure passing drivers. This particular strip has its unique conveniences -- at one spot, you can get an "oven baked factory paint job" for your car, and then pick out a live chicken next door, to be slaughtered and dressed while you're waiting).
 All these areas have their merits, car-wise: Jerome Avenue is known for repairs, the strip behind Shea for its sheer size and variety. But Hunts Point has a reputation as the place to find a part, any part under the sun, for as cheap as it gets, as long as you are willing to pick through enough junkyards.
 These yards are mostly old-fashioned mom-and-pop affairs. The Point has not been infiltrated yet by the new breed of postmodern junkyards that belong to corporate chains, and look like showrooms, with sparkling white floors and computerized inventories, where security cameras and motion detectors take the place of the mangy Doberman chained out front. 
 Most of the yards and used-parts shops are cash and carry only. Though the auto crimes unit of the state's Department of Motor Vehicles makes frequent surprise visits up and down the strip, and conspiracy theories about the city's trying to shut down the junkyards are floated with gusto here, Dina Improtad, a spokeswoman for the city's Department of Consumer Affairs, says very few complaints have been reported in Hunts Point over the past few years. (Still, she urges consumers to patronize only used auto-parts shops that can show a secondhand-auto dealer's license and salvage yards that can show a green-and-white dismantler's license.)
 UP and down Hunts Point Avenue, on a recent Saturday, people were draped over windshields, huddled under hoods, snaked under car bodies, perched on tires. Headlights and mirrors hung in dense braids from shop fences and walls. At Abad Auto Glass, salsa played over a set of speakers jury-rigged atop a stack of rims. The owner's mother-in-law had wheeled a hot dog cart out to the street, and was doing a brisk business. A weight bench had been set out in the yard of the auto glass shop next door, and a bare-chested man hoisted a barbell, attended by two men and a bored pit bull. Springtime in the Point.
 A few blocks down, on East Bay Avenue, a woman lounged in a white plastic chair in front of a walled, concrete compound that was open to the sky. Inside, there were a couple of storage trailers, three wrecked cars, scattered piles of radiators, other assorted car parts and a Puerto Rican flag. There wasn't an inch of ground that wasn't covered. A handful of grizzled-looking men with soot-caked hands and faces were gathered around the woman like courtiers. On a sign behind her, in big yellow-and-blue letters, were the words "Radiator Woman."
 "That's my line, radiators," she said. She waved her hands in the air. "Radiators, radiators." Her hands were coated with grime, but her fingernails were shiny pink. "At radiators I am the best," she went on. "I see a car, I say, what radiator, what year, what is the problem?"
 Radiator Woman, who is in her late 40's and whose Christian name is Iluminada Castro -- she also goes by Tita -- is a licensed welder, and the only female used auto parts proprietor on her street, most likely the only one in Hunts Point and, quite possibly, in all five boroughs. She is surely the only female radiator specialist. 
 In every way she lives out the dualism suggested by the name of her business: radiator woman. The feminine merged mysteriously with the automotive. She paints her lips cherry red, and shiny gold hoops, big as engine gaskets, dangle from her ears. She is compact, like an economy sedan. 
 If she were a car, she'd be stick shift, not an automatic, to accommodate the dizzying pace at which she changes gears, going in a moment from a furious shower of Spanish invective, punctuated by fist-shaking and enthusiastic spitting on the dirt, to bright cackling, to ruminative melancholy as she sits in her plastic chair reflecting on life and contemplating the view: 1 2 3 Auto Wreckers across the street, where Manny is always screaming something at Manny Jr., who is always up on the roof searching through skyward stacks of parts, and can never hear him. 
 "You want a '94 Ford Explorer grill?" Manny Jr. will say. "No, you moron, I said an '89 Mercury bumper," Manny Sr. will shout back. 
 Whenever Manny Jr. comes down from the roof, he wheels around on a forklift very fast, several car bodies stacked on the tines like a pile of dirty dishes. The other day, it was sunny, and in a mood of mellow reminiscence, Radiator Woman told her story.
 Radiator Woman was born in Puerto Rico, and came to the Bronx with her family as a child. She married here, but soon after her husband left her and their young son. She went to work in a textile factory, but began to fix cars on the side. She was 28. 
 "I buy an old car, I practice fixing in the street," she said. "I take a radiator out, put it back in. I break it, I fix it, I put it back in. I go to the junkyards, and if the radiator no good they give it to me for five dollars and I practice. Nobody taught me." 
 Pulling out a Newport, she went over to a propane tank almost as big as she was. She picked up a torch attached to the tank and flicked. There was a whooshing hiss of flame, and she lighted her cigarette. Then she dropped the torch, and went on: 
 "The first car I fixed was a '78 Mustang. The engine was too big for the radiator and blew up. So I buy a three-line radiator, put it in car, problem fixed, my brother sell it. Ford LTD was the second car I fix. It wasn't easy working in the street. When I made a few dollar, I buy a van. I put on the side of the van, 'Radiator Woman.' People were surprised to see a woman fixing radiators. They tell me: 'I want to bring my wife up to see you."'
 A young man with a mop of slicked-back hair, and sunglasses with small rectangular green lenses, entered the yard. "Do you have an engine fan for a Mitsubishi Diamante?" he asked in Spanish.
 Radiator Woman marched into the back of her shop, realized he wasn't following, turned and yelled at him in Spanish. He jumped, and hustled after her. She began peeling apart a pile of parts, tossing them aside as she dug down, a flurry of hubcaps and bumpers, fan belts and old coffee cups. Then she shouted and triumphantly lifted up a Mitsubishi fan. 
 "I'll give you 20?" the young man said.
 Radiator Woman frowned. "Thirty."
 The man shook his head. "Twenty." He held out a bill. "It's all I have."
 Radiator Woman shook the fan at him, raising her voice. "You need this. I don't need it, papi. I tell you the truth."
 Finally, the man yanked a five from his wallet. "Twenty-five," he said.
 Radiator Woman considered, and then silently, petulantly, stuck out an open hand. 
 Farther up the block, an older black man leaned against the hood of his car, basking. He was lanky, had a rough-cropped, salt-and-pepper beard, and wore green work clothes. His name was Larry Creeo, and he demolishes boilers here for a living; his father had demolished cars here before him. Both had left high school to work on the Point. 
 "Back in the 70's, prostitutes were all up and down the streets here -- all day," Mr. Creeo said. "People burned and cut abandoned cars out on the street. Set them on fire to cut the gas tanks off. It was a madhouse. The city cleaned the place up. There's always been junkyards here ever since I can remember. And before the junkyards it was all goat farms." 
 He got quiet, stared off into the distance, apparently caught up in a vision of all those billy goats milling around where Luxury Auto Salvage and Millennium Auto and Truck Salvage now stood. "All goat farms," he said, shaking his head. 
 A COUPLE of blocks over, on Bryant Avenue, Mike Jones was out on the street in front of his house, changing the gas line of a black '85 Cadillac Fleetwood. The Cadillac belonged to Mr. Jones, and he had laminated "Nothing but Love," in large pink block letters, on the top of his windshield. 
 Mr. Jones, who said he operates forklifts for the Hunts Point Market, owns six Cadillacs -- Coupe de Villes and Eldorados and Fleetwoods -- from the 70's and 80's, which he has painted in shiny canary yellows and powder blues. He refers to these Cadillacs in the feminine pronoun, and treats them with a husband's mixture of tenderness and henpecked resignation. He drives them all, taking turns, so that none of the cars get jealous. There is no question of who wears the pants in Mr. Jones's relationships with his Caddies. 
 "I go all over," he said. "Wherever she wants to go. Wherever she take me. I let her lead the way. I got to." 
 Mr. Jones said his Cadillacs play a big role in his romantic life. He has as many girlfriends as he has cars, and he makes sure to always take the same girl out in the same car.
 He moved with his mother and younger brother from Soundview, in the Bronx, to Hunts Point a year ago. For Mr. Jones -- a man who likes to say, "No better car than an old car" -- the Point is agreeable. Allied Used Auto Parts and Salvage sits around the corner, and he goes to see Nick, his man there, at least twice a week. 
 Mr. Jones enjoys renown in the neighborhood -- "Everyone, they see all these old cars and this young guy," he says -- especially because of his sky-blue '79 Coupe de Ville, which he calls the Monster. He replaced its muffler with four chrome pipes, which make a sound similar to the launching of a space shuttle. ("Lets the car breathe better," Mr. Jones says. "Don't want her to be choking.") He plans to put hydraulics in next. ("Then you can do the bunny hop! Make the car bounce up and down, side to side.") 
 Mr. Jones took a break from the Fleetwood's gas line, leaned against the car's hood and gazed up and down the street approvingly, all his Cadillacs gleaming in the sun. 
 "It's all right, Hunts Point," he said. "More space to park cars."

HEADLINE: Doctors Seek to Cut Malpractice Awards 

BYLINE:  By DAVID WINZELBERG 

 BODY:
HUNDREDS of lab-coated doctors rallied on Long Island on Tuesday to protest high liability insurance rates and call for a cap on pain-and-suffering awards in malpractice cases.
 Physicians and medical staff carried signs and listened to speeches from colleagues in specialties like radiology, obstetrics and neurosurgery who talked about risk, rising costs and diminishing rewards to a smattering of applause. The demonstrations, held simultaneously at Eisenhower Park in East Meadow and Hecksher Park in Huntington, were part of a statewide protest organized by the Medical Society of the State of New York. 
 "Doctors in New York State are paying the highest medical liability rates in the nation," said Thomas Donoghue, director of communications for the medical society, headquartered in Lake Success. Mr. Donoghue said the liability insurance issue "goes far beyond doctors" to effect people in all walks of life. "All this is ultimately passed on to the consumer," he said. 
As payments from health management organizations for certain procedures have gone down, insurance rates and the risk to the caregiver have increased, doctors complained, making it difficult for some high-risk specialists to stay profitable. Eventually, several doctors said, Long Island patients will go looking for an obstetrician or a neurosurgeon and not find one.
Already, people seeking mammograms on the Island have a four- to six-month wait, because many radiologists refuse to do the screening for fear of being sued if something is missed. "Mammography is reimbursed at a lower rate than the cost of providing it," said Dr. Steven Palter, 36, an obstetrician-gynecologist in Syosset. Dr. Palter, an infertility specialist, moved his practice to Long Island 18 months ago from Yale University Hospital. "My malpractice insurance here is three times what it was in Connecticut. People told me that I was crazy to practice medicine here. Everyone is leaving New York."
Many doctors said their homes are in the names of their wives or other family members because when their insurance coverage limit is reached, their personal property becomes fair game in malpractice suits. Dr. John Cafaro, 45, an obstetrician-gynecologist who practices in Garden City, said some doctors are paying $130,000 for only $1 million worth of protection. "But we are getting sued for $85 and $90 million at a time," he said. "You do the math. Every time I walk into an operating room I put my family's life savings on the line."
Besides doctors in high-risk specialties, hospitals are also affected by rising insurance costs. Joseph Quagliata, president of South Nassau Community Hospital in Oceanside, said the malpractice crisis is making it tougher on hospitals to stay in the black. "It is compromising the ability of the provider community to continue to deliver proper care," he said.
One of the biggest reasons for high insurance rates is the risk of a huge lawsuit and subsequent award if something goes wrong. Many of the doctors said they blame lawyers and the current tort system for generating unreasonably large settlements and judgments. 
"We find it unfair all the droves and droves of TV commercials for lawyers looking to sue us," said Dr. James Ferguson, 47, who practices family medicine in East Islip and attended the Huntington rally. "They are giving out $30 million awards. My whole neighborhood in a lifetime won't earn $30 million. How can they give these numbers?"
Some states, like California, have adopted caps on awards for non-economic damages. Last month, the House of Representatives approved a bill that would set a limit of $250,000 for those awards, although states could set that number higher. Here in New York, however, attempts to get an awards cap have failed.
"It passed in the Senate, but Sheldon Silver, the speaker of the Assembly, controls the agenda," said Dr. Vincent Geraci, 57, an internist who practices in Garden City and is president of the Nassau County Medical Society. Dr. Geraci said Mr. Silver was a member of Weitz and Luxenberg, a law firm which specializes in medical malpractice and asbestos cases. Last month, Mr. Silver denied that this association was a conflict of interest.
John Bracken, 65, a partner in Bracken, Margolin and Gouvis in Islandia, said doctors have been making the same complaint since the early 1980's, but a cap on awards would be "inherently unfair." Mr. Bracken, who co-chairs the New York State Bar Association task force on the tort system, said: "If a patient loses a leg because of malpractice he would get $250,000. And if the patient lost two legs, it's the same value?"
Although doctors complain about their insurance burden, Mr. Bracken said they won't give you what percentage of their incomes it amounts to. "I don't see any doctors filing for bankruptcy because they can't make a living," he said. "They may be making less, but then lawyers are making less too."
Putting a cap on awards would also discourage lawyers from taking malpractice cases, said Mr. Bracken, because the time and effort involved wouldn't be worth it. Doctors are saying the same thing about practicing high-risk medicine.
Dr. Robert Weiss, an obstetrician-gynecologist who practices in Bethpage, said patients will soon go wanting. "One day you will come to my office and there will be a sign on the door that says 'Go see them,"' Dr. Weiss said. "Then you will see a sign on their door that says 'Go see them.' Maybe then you'll get a trial lawyer to deliver the baby."

HEADLINE: . . . And Fortitude for the Job Hunt 

BYLINE:  By BETH KRESSEL; Beth Kressel, an English major pursuing a career in journalism, lives in Highland Park.

 BODY:
AT Rutgers University commencement on Thursday, I gave the valedictory address for Rutgers College on behalf of myself and 16 other valedictorians -- a record number, all with perfect 4.0 grade averages. I spoke before some 2,500 fellow graduates and our friends and families. The next day, I joined the ranks of the unemployed. 
 Many would consider this a tremendous letdown, especially given the current economy and the national unemployment rate of 6 percent. The news media, in countless articles about graduates entering the job market, express more sympathy to us than a seven-day stream of shiva callers. Thank you for the pity. But, like Mark Twain, we say the reports of our demise are greatly exaggerated. And here's why: 
 My classmates and I are the masters of technology and networking, two qualities that are crucial to seeking and finding a job. Thomas Friedman, the New York Times columnist, writes in his book "The Lexus and the Olive Tree" that, thanks to globalization, everyone -- from the street peddler in Thailand to the lobbyist in Washington -- is a "super-empowered individual" who can reach around the globe "farther, faster, deeper and cheaper than ever before."
 We college grads have multiple e-mail addresses, instant messenger buddy-lists and cellphones. You might call us the top tier of the super-empowered.
 Whoever said that college life was fun and games? The word "student" doesn't cover the half of it. We are also interns, community service workers and part-time employees. Much of what we do is "volunteer," and when we do get a salary, it's often in pennies. All of us know the meaning of tight budget, and we are surprisingly resourceful.
 Faxing, photocopying, filing, and mailing. No job is too small or too tedious for us. And no one knows how to reduce, enlarge, collate or staple better. We are well educated but will also perform tasks that others sneer at. This makes us marketable.
 We are used to multitasking (see above). After graduation, we will focus solely on finding a job. And our efforts will not be diverted by 2.5 children, our 401(k) plan or house mortgage payments.
 We relish the role of underdog. Youth sports have taught us well. I am a slender 5-foot-10. As a high school basketball player, I played the position of center, banged against taller, wider bodies and still grabbed my share of the rebounds. Entering the job market at its lowest point doesn't faze me. If it doesn't kill me, it will make me stronger.
 I recognize that finding employment -- or even a position in graduate school, the Peace Corps or Teach for America -- is tougher than ever. But I also see the tremendous potential of the Class of 2003. Let's all say amen to that, even as we grant a moment of silence for our joblessness.

HEADLINE: BULLETIN BOARD; 
Prices That Are All Over the Map

BYLINE:  By VIVIAN MARINO 

 BODY:
Travelers heading to domestic destinations this summer can find some good deals, especially in the nation's heartland, according to a survey of vacation costs by the leisure travel organization AAA.
 Its annual survey, released this month, found that lodging and dining costs have risen 2 percent over all during the last year. 
A family of four can expect to pay, on average, $244 a day for food and lodging this summer. Lodging rates are expected to average $132 a night, up $5 from last year, while meals are expected to cost an average of $112, unchanged. 
 The most expensive and least expensive destinations were the same as in 2002. Atop the list was Hawaii, where food and lodging cost a family of four $533 a day on average. The least expensive was North Dakota, at $175. VIVIAN MARINO

HEADLINE: Private Sector; 
For the Web, the Party Really Is Over

BYLINE:  By Karen Alexander 

 BODY:
As if vanishing paper fortunes, unemployment, bankruptcy and mocking books and magazine articles were not enough, dot-com pioneers are coming in for an extra measure of humility these days.
 The Webby Awards -- which its sponsors promoted as the Oscars of the Internet just two years ago, when the ceremony drew more than 3,000 people to the War Memorial Opera House in San Francisco -- will be scaled back to a virtual event this year. 
 The need for the opera house vanished along with most of the dot-coms that once crowded into the city's trendy South of Market neighborhood. Now, even plans for a modest party for 300 people -- in a tent not far from the opera house on June 5 -- have been scrapped. Not enough people expressed an interest in attending, not even many of the 150 nominees.
Instead, the awards, given by the International Academy of Digital Arts and Sciences, will be announced on the Internet, at www.webbyawards.com.
One nominee, Kenn R. Louis, creative director of www.spongi.com, which features short films, said he had planned to fly to San Francisco for the event. "I would like to have gone," said Mr. Louis, who is proud that his site is the first Webby nominee from Cleveland. Instead, he will throw a Webby party at a bar, in Cleveland. Karen Alexander

HEADLINE: The World; 
For the Euro, the Worst Time for the Best of Times

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT 

 BODY:
IT is a measure of the hard feelings on both sides of the Atlantic that when John W. Snow, the United States treasury secretary, signaled last weekend that the Bush administration would tolerate a weaker dollar, people here muttered darkly that the White House had finally found a way to stick it to France and Germany for having opposed the war in Iraq.
 A falling dollar translates directly into a rising euro, which makes German-built cars and French wine more expensive in the United States. Just as a weak dollar could help revive the American economy, a surging euro could hobble the exports Europe needs for growth. 
 Few Europeans genuinely believe that American policy is motivated by revenge rather than self-interest. But the conspiracy theories lay bare a deeper frustration: Europe, already bruised by Washington's unbridled use of military power, now feels elbowed by its economic muscle-flexing as well. 
The euro was supposed to right the economic imbalance. By uniting 300 million Europeans under a common currency, with a single monetary policy and tightly coordinated fiscal policies, the architects of the new Europe believed they could create a counterweight to American economic might -- a stable, thriving bloc stretching from Dublin to Athens.
It has taken just three years of wobbly economic growth, and a shift in American dollar policy, to call that into question. "This is an unprecedented experiment," said Niall C. Ferguson, an expert on economic history and a senior research fellow at Oxford. "I don't think it can be proclaimed a success yet, and indeed I would argue it has been a slow failure."
To a currency trader or an American tourist visiting Europe this summer, such a verdict might seem bizarre. The euro, after all, is trading at the highest levels since it was introduced in 1999. It has recouped all the value it lost against the dollar in the last four years, and then some. The euro is becoming a preferred asset for international investors, who are unnerved by the yawning deficits in the United States.
The trouble is, "euro power" is coming at exactly the wrong moment in Europe's economic fortunes. Germany, Italy and the Netherlands are on the brink of recession; it would be their second in two years. A hard blow to exports could be enough to tip these countries into the trough.
In this regard, Europe and the United States are in similar straits. The difference is that Washington is tackling its problems with ruthless pragmatism, typified by its decision to soft-pedal the strong-dollar mantra that was first articulated in the mid-1990's.
Europe's central bank, by contrast, is wedded to core principles that go back considerably further than the Clinton administration. Derived from Germany's Bundesbank, they reflect its obsession with inflation, rooted in the hyperinflation of the Weimar Republic.
The quickest way to slow the rise of the euro would be to lower interest rates, something the Federal Reserve has done time and again in the United States. The European Central Bank, however, has held the line, saying the need to curb inflation still outweighs the benefits of lubricating the economy.
"American policy makers are not dogmatic," said David Mackie, the chief European economist at J. P. Morgan Chase. "They buy into ideas for a season, and they discard them when it is time to move on. European policy makers are far more stuck on dogma, through thick and thin."
To be fair, the European central bankers are expected to lower rates in June at their next meeting. The question is whether the remedy will be too little, too late for European industry. Volkswagen and DaimlerChrysler have already reported eroding profits; while both have other problems, and operate huge assembly plants in the United States, they say the euro is partly to blame.
THE debate over interest rates is just part of a broader debate over whether the European monetary union is too rule-bound. The union's fiscal restraints are set out in its Stability and Growth Pact, which requires its 12 members to keep budget deficits to less than 3 percent of total output.
Germany, France, Italy and Portugal have all breached that ceiling. Given the restorative effects of government spending on a sickly economy, many economists say they were right to do it. For Germany, however, thumbing its nose does not come naturally. Chancellor Gerhard Schroder has pledged to push the deficit, now 3.8 percent of gross domestic product, back under the cap with tax increases and spending cuts.
Once again, the timing could not be worse. With zero growth, anemic consumer demand and historically low business confidence, the German economy, Europe's largest, needs a bracing tonic, not a dose of castor oil.
The White House, meanwhile, is pushing the federal budget deficit well above Europe's 3 percent mark, with a $350 billion program of tax cuts and state aid that the administration insists will revive the economy.
Not all of Europe's problems are rooted in the dogmatism of Brussels. Broader economic reforms in Germany and France have been hurt by a familiar mix of political backsliding, vested interests and the enduring appeal of social responsibility as a European ideal.
In France, public workers nearly shut down the country two weeks ago to protest efforts to rein in the pension system. In Germany, Chancellor Schroder is watering down his plans to relax entrenched labor laws in response to a rebellion by the unions and other leftist elements within his own Social Democratic Party.
Summarizing the state of affairs, the German weekly newsmagazine Der Spiegel said on its cover last week, "The Hour of Truth in a Land of Lies."
As Europe faces this hour of truth, some here believe the United States should be a model. Norbert Walter, Deutsche Bank's chief economist, said Europeans could start by drawing the right lesson from Mr. Snow's recent remarks. "The U.S. has always had the philosophy, 'the dollar is our currency, and your problem,' " he said. "We have to come to grips with that."

HEADLINE: The World: Long Haul; 
A Sickly Economy, With No Cure in Sight

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
FOR much of the last month, the people responsible for the health of the sputtering economy have been performing a series of emergency procedures.
 With the economy showing new signs of weakness, the House and Senate overcame sharp differences last week to pass a $320 billion tax cut intended in part to increase stock prices and give households additional money to spend. Alan Greenspan has been assuring investors that the Federal Reserve will act aggressively to prevent deflation, an unlikely but dangerous possibility. 
 And Treasury Secretary John W. Snow, by speaking without concern about the dollar's recent decline, has helped push it down further versus the euro, aiding American manufacturers by effectively cutting the price of their products relative to those of foreign rivals. 
Few policy makers or economists question the need for action, even if some are unhappy with the particulars. After roughly three years of falling stocks and rising unemployment, another downturn could create a whole new class of problems. The already big pool of the long-term unemployed could swell. Inflation -- now near its lowest level in decades -- might turn into deflation, a sustained decline in prices that can set off a vicious cycle of wage cuts and unmanageable debt. 
But even if tax cuts and carefully chosen words represent a sensible form of insurance, they seem unlikely to accomplish what everybody agrees is the ultimate goal: the creation of a truly healthy economy, one in which stocks, wages and company payrolls are rising, without an enormous financial bubble as a main cause. 
On balance, in fact, the steps being taken to pull the economy back from the precipice may delay the arrival of one able to stand on its own. "What we're doing now is trying to create a cyclical pop with a massive policy response," said James W. Paulsen, one of the few forecasters to predict the 2001 downturn and the chief investment strategist at Wells Capital Management in Minneapolis. "That may well succeed -- I think it will. But very little of it will solve the problems that got us into this situation."
Instead, those problems -- consumers who remain financially stretched, a corporate sector that has not yet won back the trust of many investors and a government living well beyond its means -- will weigh on the underlying strengths of the American economy. 
Those strengths are not small, as continuing increases in productivity and the even slower growth of Europe and Japan have made clear. 
"We have in place probably the best economic infrastructure" in the world, said Douglas J. Holtz-Eakin, the director of the Congressional Budget Office. "We actually get rid of nonperforming assets."
None of that is new, however, and the economy's problems have existed long enough to raise the questions of whether slow growth is the new reality, and whether good times like the boom of the late 1990's can exist without the help of a bubble.
In Washington, the problems start with a budget deficit that is expanding more quickly than it was even a week ago. Then there are ticking fiscal time bombs like the retirement of baby boomers (which will lower the government's income tax revenues, while threatening to bankrupt Social Security) and the alternative minimum tax, a once-obscure provision that is raising the taxes of a new set of households each year. 
In future years, the upshot of these trends is likely to be a politically painful choice between higher taxes and lower government benefits.
Last week's stimulus bill added to the list of tough decisions to be made another day. To hold down the cost of the plan, Congress created tax cuts and tax credits -- for married couples, parents and stockholders -- that expire after a few years, leaving tomorrow's lawmakers to increase the deficit further or to anger voters by allowing the benefits to lapse.
Economists overwhelmingly agree on the wisdom of running deficits during downturns, particularly one that has raised fears of deflation. "The deflation scenario is so dangerous," said J. Bradford DeLong, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley, "we want to take every step we can to avoid it."
What makes the slump of the last three years unusual is that spending by consumers stayed strong, which means they will be less likely to supplant the government as the main engine of growth once taxes increase or federal spending falls in future years. 
Consumers have typically emerged from past recessions with a pent-up desire for houses, cars and other big-ticket items they avoided buying during tough times. This time, an aggressive series of interest rate reductions by the Fed has helped make many of those items affordable even as wage gains have all but stopped, after inflation is taken into account.
In trumpeting the Fed's vigilance against deflation in recent weeks, Mr. Greenspan has ensured continued low interest rates. Bond traders now believe that short-term rates, which the Fed controls, will remain low for months, and they have reacted by lowering long-term rates. Thus, last week, mortgage rates plunged to record lows, making it more likely that the refinancing boom will continue. 
"This is obviously not going to go on forever," said Jan Hatzius, a senior economist at Goldman Sachs. The recent growth of consumer spending, he added, "is sustainable as long as households are able to take more and more equity from their homes."
THE one recent attempt at resuscitation that economists say is likely to bring future benefits is the dollar's decline, which has accelerated since Mr. Snow suggested he was not bothered by it. By contrast, the Clinton administration occasionally bought dollars in the currency market to bolster their value, hold down the price of imports and keep inflation low when the economy was growing rapidly.
Now, however, a little inflation does not look so bad. 
Even before the dollar's recent fall, the corporate sector was the only big part of the economy that has used the slowdown to bring its debts better into line with its assets. While the market's fall brought down the net worth of consumers by 10 percent from the start of 2000 to the end of last year, the net worth of nonfinancial companies rose almost 5 percent, according to the Fed.
Pointing to benefits from the dollar's fall, many economists say they expect corporate executives will soon end their cost-cutting ways of the last three years and decide that they can profitably use new factories and new technology.
That is a reason to think the economy will improve before the year ends, as almost every forecaster is predicting. By itself, however, it might not be enough to restore the economy to full health.

HEADLINE: Tide of Humanity Alters Long Island Sound 

BYLINE:  By KIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: GROTON, Conn. 

 BODY:
Forty years ago in the summer of 1963, a writer for The New Yorker named Morton M. Hunt spent two weeks circumnavigating Long Island Sound in a little sailboat. 
 When he sat down to write, he mourned. A way of life was disappearing. The old culture of the Sound -- a still wild mix of scruffy boatyards, Gold Coast snobs and fishermen, all set against the vast mirror of nature -- would surely be homogenized and pushed to the brink by the pell-mell rush of suburbanization and the mass market, Mr. Hunt wrote. 
 But then there was a plot twist that he could not have foreseen. In the years that followed Mr. Hunt's trip, people gradually began to realize that the Sound -- by the power of history and population and the environmental damage inflicted upon it -- had in a very real way become a human creation. The impact of civilization was complete, the idea of a return to wild nature only a fantasy. 
The ancient estuary, extending 110 miles northeast from New York City to Rhode Island through the densest population corridor in the nation -- loved and loathed as a breadbasket, playground and dump -- would have to be managed for its own sake, and for the region's. 
And that realization produced another voyage -- of discovery and confounding mystery, triumph and setback -- as people came to understand the complexity of what they had undertaken to do.
In economics, politics, culture and science, people took action, and nature responded. A tiny sea plant called eelgrass, and a group of families here in Groton who unintentionally triggered its resurgence, play a part in that story.
"We're learning for the first time where the Sound's heartbeat is, where the pulse is," said Robert B. Whitlatch, a professor of marine sciences at the University of Connecticut. 
The management of nature, loosely called environmental stewardship, is being applied in many places around the world. In the North Sea, marine managers have compiled an exhaustive database about the aquatic food chain -- a kind of who eats whom of the fish world.
In the United States, managers are remaking the bottom of Tampa Bay with the sea grasses of its past.
But on the Sound there is much more going on than mere ecology. How people connect with the Sound, for instance, or how they don't -- and thus how much political clout the Sound's advocates can wield in Albany or Hartford or Washington -- is part of the new management equation as well, as politicians and environmentalists try to increase access to the water with new parks and beaches.
Unlike the Adirondacks or the Hudson River, the Sound never stole the region's heart. It was always too close to New York City, too taken for granted, too practical in its uses -- as a fishery, a transportation artery or a trash can. There was no wolf baying at the moon to shiver the spine, no sense of a lost wilderness to touch the soul.
What the Sound had, first and foremost, was people -- a bustling, grasping, dreaming, teeming population. It was America's first urban sea, a kitchen sink for the industrial revolution, and an ecological witness to the rise of the suburbs after World War II. Now, in the age of management, scientists and politicians say, the huge force and clout of that population -- one in 10 Americans within an hour's drive -- has once again made the Sound a kind of vanguard and sentinel. Where the nation's other great tidal estuaries might go, as demographic patterns and economies change around Chesapeake Bay or Puget Sound or San Francisco Bay, the Sound has already arrived.
"It's the first 21st-century estuary," said Glenn R. Lopez, a professor of marine sciences at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, on Long Island. "Its issues are all about human habitation."
Profound philosophical questions have emerged from this. If the Sound cannot be restored to what it was in the pre-European past -- and no one thinks that is remotely possible -- then what should it be? What is the optimum natural state in a system that has been overwhelmingly and permanently transformed by human presence? Should the Sound be managed for the sake of nature and biological diversity, or for the human pocketbook, to maximize the species people want to extract and attract the most tourists?
But perhaps the biggest question is whether people are smart enough to chart the course at all. Nature, for every push that people impose, has pushed right back.
Local and state governments have committed billions of dollars, for example, to reduce nitrogen from sewage treatment plants. But even as that process goes forward, evidence has mounted that climate change and warmer water temperatures may be altering the ecosystem as fast as humans can fix it.
Efforts to restore lobster populations have been undercut, some scientists believe, by programs to bring back other species like striped bass, which have soared in number in recent years under wildlife management. Stripers adore finger-sized larval lobsters and eat them with great gulps whenever they can.
Or consider the air itself. Wind moves differently over the built-up expanses of New York City and its suburbs than it did in centuries past, climate researchers say, and different winds make for different rates of mixing in the Sound's water column. Different mixing rates, in turn, can compound the problem of low oxygen that kills the animals that local governments are working to save through nitrogen reduction.
And on and on it goes. The ecosystem has been put in motion and no one knows where it will stop.
At a recent daylong conference on the Sound, Arthur Glowka voiced those anxieties. Mr. Glowka, a fisherman and retired pilot who had the lean and windblown look of a life lived on the water, thundered that the Sound's new managers were messing with things beyond the human ability to control, and that the piper would have to be paid.
"We're playing God," Mr. Glowka said. "And when you start to play God, you don't know what's going to happen."
When he finished, the director of the Environmental Protection Agency's Long Island Sound office, Mark A. Tedesco, rose to respond.
"I would submit that we've been playing God on the Sound for the last 300 years," Mr. Tedesco said. "Now we're just trying to do it responsibly."

The Human Hand
Politics and Lawyers Help the Grass Grow
A willowy, jade-green sea plant called eelgrass grows on the bottom of Mumford Cove, and for marine biologists and fishermen -- not to mention baby scallops, which hide from predators amid its waving fronds -- this qualifies as very big news. Eelgrass is disappearing all over the East Coast and across most of the rest of Long Island Sound, but here in an obscure little inlet on Groton's east end, it has been growing for the last decade in resplendent and thickening abundance.
The tale of Mumford's eelgrass is only partly about nature, however. And that is why it says so much about the new rhythms of the Sound. It is also about the mysteries of the human heart, and small-town politics and shrewd lawyers.
A Mumford Cove Christmas party figures prominently into the story. And so does Herman E. Sheets, a widower and retired engineer who met and fell in love with a New York civil prosecutor, then named Paulann M. Caplovitz, and brought her to live with him on the cove in 1983.
But perhaps the most important thing to know is that nothing to do with eelgrass was ever remotely intended by anybody. People, acting on their own messy and complicated agendas, changed the cove's waters, and nature, literally out of the deep blue sea, responded.
"Mumford Cove is a poster child," said R. Scott Warren, a professor of botany at Connecticut College in New London. "The hypothesis says that where you take action, nature can recover, and on Mumford Cove, you can actually test that."
What makes the cove such an ideal laboratory for the human-wild connection, Professor Warren and other experts say, is that the trajectory of its decline and rebirth was so stark and so well documented.
Mr. Sheets, who is now 94, remembers diving off the dock with his children almost every summer night in the 1950's and 1960's after coming home from work at the Electric Boat submarine yard a few miles away, where he designed boats for the Navy.
But then, beginning in the mid-1970's, it all changed. The volume of wastewater from the local sewage treatment plant, which then drained into the cove from an upland creek, began increasing as more and more people moved to the shore.
Giant mats of sea lettuce -- a thick and glutinous plant that thrives in nitrogen-rich waters -- began to take over. By 1980, the cove had stopped even hiring lifeguards because no one was swimming. And what was worse, residents were told again and again that nothing could be done. Lawyers said it would be impossible to prove in court that the sewage or the slimy lettuce were causing "irreparable harm," which was the legal standard they said would be needed to force the town to move the pipe somewhere else.
That is when the former Ms. Caplovitz, now Mrs. Sheets, strode into the picture. She had been an assistant attorney general in New York (where she had met her future husband when he testified as an expert witness in one of her cases) and she felt certain that there was another way to fight. So at her first Mumford Cove Christmas party, in 1983, she said she had an idea.
"We'd given up until Paulann came," said Robert Boggs, who has lived on the cove since the 1960's and was at the party that night. "She was the catalyst."
With the backing of Mumford residents, Mrs. Sheets arranged for a new law firm to look at the cove, and the lawyers there found exactly what she hoped they would. Years earlier, Groton had been instructed by the state to move the sewer pipe across town to drain into the Thames River, but the town never got around to it.
For purposes of a lawsuit, the cove's pollution was secondary. All the residents needed to do was prove that the town had violated a state order.
The resulting fight split Groton down the middle, sparking anger and passions that in some corners of town have still yet to cool, and it all revolved around a couple of nagging questions:
If the cove's residents didn't want the sewer outflow, why should anybody else?
Were Mumford residents better than the people who lived near the Thames, where the alternative pipe would drain?
"There wasn't really a scientific or environmental argument," said Mark R. Oefinger, the Groton town manager, who butted heads with Mrs. Sheets many times during those years.
Mr. Oefinger added, "It was all about, 'If this stuff is bad for you, why is it good for us?' "
But the Mumford argument, however narrow and technical it seemed to some, prevailed. In 1986, a Federal District Court judge ordered the town to comply with the old state order.
The cove's days as a dump were over.
And a great experiment had begun.

Webs and Consequences
Warning: Beware Of the Mute Swans
So the eelgrass bloomed, and the naturalists swooned. But people were not alone in noticing the change. 
Min Huang, the waterfowl coordinator for the Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection, took a helicopter flight over southeastern Connecticut this spring and saw three pairs of mute swans nesting in Mumford Cove -- the first time any had been observed there in the state's annual bird surveys.
The arrival of swans, Mr. Huang and other experts say, suggests that another cycle of human-influenced nature may be under way here. Mute swans, a non-native species that escaped from a private preserve on Long Island around World War I, are notoriously destructive and voracious feeders who love, perhaps more than anything else -- you guessed it -- eelgrass.
An adult mute swan weighing 30 pounds can eat 8 pounds of grass a day, and destroy 12 more pounds in rooting around for the choice morsels it wants. And to make the twisted cycle of nature complete, swans -- who can live 20 years or more and tend to stay permanently in their nesting areas once they've moved in -- are also officially protected by the full power of state law. The Connecticut General Assembly granted the birds protected status in the 1950's. 
Like a nursery rhyme turned on its head, the logical links tumble like dominoes: It's a crime to harm the mute swans that eat the eelgrass that shelter the scallops that the Sound's managers would love to restore if they could. A formal study of the bird's impact on sea grass, focused in part on Mumford Cove, will begin later this year.
"We do know that our decline of eelgrass has to do with water quality in many areas, but are mute swans inhibiting the recovery as well? That's what we'll be looking at," Mr. Huang said. "One hypothesis is that the places we have eelgrass are the places the birds haven't discovered yet."
And so the ripple of implications from the Mumford Cove sewer pipe fight continues to expand. Are mute swans, searching for the foods they like, a natural phenomenon, or a perverse consequence? 
What, in the end, is natural at all in a place like the Sound? That's a question that James N. Kremer wrestles with all the time.
Dr. Kremer, a professor of marine sciences at the University of Connecticut, has been studying Mumford Cove for nearly a decade, since he moved into the neighborhood just a few blocks from the beach in the mid-1990's. And on a recent foggy morning, he was doing what has by now become a monthly ritual -- testing the water, checking the growth of the eelgrass, and trying, most of all, to put the pieces of the puzzle together.
Leaning over the rail of his school's research boat about 50 yards offshore, he pushed a metal pole with a cage down into the cove's mud. Up came a green clutch of eelgrass -- short, perhaps a bit stunted from the cold winter -- but alive and well.
Dr. Kremer's goal goes far beyond merely understanding the botany. He is trying to construct what might be called a social-biological history of the cove -- a kind of management manual that mayors and wetlands commissioners all over the Sound, and perhaps the world, might be able to use in managing their local waters. The model will be stocked with all the variables about water quality and clarity -- a key factor for eelgrass photosynthesis -- along with as much of the human story that he can gather about what people did to alter that chemistry.
"We want to make it useful to town planners and managers who deal with these issues every day, so they can see where they are on the spectrum and be able to say, well, if I do something different in the future, how will it look?" he said.
This is increasingly how science works on the Sound, especially now as grant money has become tighter. In writing proposals, practical applications have become a hook, Dr. Kremer and others say. And so in a kind of feedback loop of its own, research reinforces the management systems that in turn pay for the science that justifies more management.

Relationships Revealed
A Feeling of Being In Your Backyard
Peter J. Bartinik Sr., a lawyer in Groton, remembers being dispatched as a boy to Mumford Cove by his grandmother in the 1950's to collect clams and blue crabs for dinner. He would jump in the family's boat -- not much more than a rowboat, he said, with a little outboard motor -- and gather crabs by the bucketful, jacklighting them with a flashlight beam that would stun the crustaceans in their tracks, ready for the plucking.
No one lived on the cove then. There was no beach (that was created much later by a real estate developer, using sand dredged from the cove's bottom). People would just camp out in places like Mumford, pull up in their boats, throw out a tent and spend the night, or the summer.
"We'll never get back to that feeling that the Sound is your backyard," said Mr. Bartinik, 60, who lives on the cove. "But in a way, that's good -- thinking of it as your backyard means you can do with it as you please."
That old casual relationship with nature, fading even in Mr. Bartinik's youth, is over now. Rules, regulations, protections and licenses -- for human and environmental protection -- are part of the new net. But in other ways, places like Mumford signal the beginning of a new relationship -- a new voyage to a place that is both deeply familiar, and yet also strangely undiscovered.
Some people fear that management will make the Sound into a kind of park -- pleasant and safe to be in, but no more than an extension of the built environment. Other people say the very opposite has been revealed by the management efforts so far -- how truly wild, or at least unpredictable, the Sound still is. Opportunistic species -- whether eelgrass or swans or stripers -- aggressively expand to fill the niches that arise. In such a place and time, hope and loss are intertwined.
"Long Island Sound shrugs," said James O'Donnell, a professor of marine sciences at the University of Connecticut. "These systems are more robust than anybody imagined."
And yet for all the vast machinery and energy of management that has been unleashed, perhaps the ultimate lesson of Mumford Cove is that a handful of people, thinking in new ways about the old backyard, made a difference.
Mrs. Sheets, 62, who still practices law part time -- mostly environmental cases -- said it was really a simple thing that happened. "I had two young children," she said. "I had to do something. Herman's children had swum and boated in the cove, but now it was unswimmable. I couldn't live on the shore of such a beautiful place that was so degraded."
Mr. Sheets nodded. A simple thing indeed, he said, in an interview in his living room with its a sweeping view of the cove. When he brought his new wife home here, a little more than a decade after the death of his first wife, Norma, healing began.
"After I married Paulann, everything changed," he said. "Mumford Cove started to live again."

Human Nature
Over many years of settlement, Long Island Sound has been a breadbasket and a dumping ground, a private playground for the wealthy and a symbol of environmental despair.
But when people reached for a new definition -- a repaired, restored, managed Sound -- nature did not respond according to the rulebook.
For every push to achieve a certain end, the whorls of the ecosystem have pushed right back, often in unexpected ways.
This is the first of a summer-long series of articles on the evolving nature of Long Island Sound. The second article will look at the fading world of the boatyards. Many are sinking fast as the old ways of the Sound ebb, while others hang on -- the last of the old salt survivors.
Additional materials, including a preview of the remainder of the series, can be found on the Web at nytimes.com/lisound.

The Press of PopulationMany of the Sound's ecological problems derive from the vast number of people that populate the area.The region around the Sound is among the most densely populated in the nation. Water Quality ProblemsNitrogen -- from waste treatment plants, storm runoff and the atmosphere -- causes algae to bloom, then die and sink to the bottom. Their decay draws oxygen out of the bottom water. The resulting hypoxia can have devastating consequences for fish and shellfish. The Legacy of GeologyConnecticut is full of ridges, remnants of a collision between Africa and North America 500 million years ago that formed the Appalachians.Long Island, on the opposite shore, is flatter and far younger, created by runoff from the glaciers that advanced as far south as the Sound's northern shore. These geographical differences have influenced everything from the power of local governments to the need for harbor dredging. Busiest MarinaBrewer's Pilots Point Marina in Westbrook has the most boat slips. Most Exclusive PlaceGardiners Island is the nation's largest privately owned island, held by the same family since 1639. HEADLINE: For Food Pantries, Cupboard Isn't Bare But It's Coming Close 

BYLINE:  By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: RICHMOND, Va. 

 BODY:
Hunger starts in many ways for the clients of the Lamb's Basket food pantry. Deborah Williams, 47, a home health care aide, runs out of her government food stamps in two weeks. William Hines, 40, arrives on a bicycle with a duffle bag for food on his back. A landscaper, he said, "I get jobs here and there, but my luck hasn't been that good."
 Jennifer Spurgeon, 30, has two sons, ages 11 and 12. A year ago, Ms. Spurgeon's husband left. She collects $45 a month in food stamps, $500 a month in child support and had been clearing $800 a month working in the kitchen of a Friendly's restaurant until her hours were cut to 12 a week from 30. 
 Food pantries, soup kitchens and shelters have rarely seen such demand. "I am not aware of any food bank in the country that's saying they are seeing fewer people," said Douglas O'Brien, vice president for public policy and research at America's Second Harvest in Chicago, which coordinates food distribution to 212 food bank warehouses where 80 percent of the nation's pantries pick up most of their food. Second Harvest says it is seeing three times more clients than it saw in the days before Sept. 11, 2001, when the surge began. 
In the face of the demand, some pantries are rationing food by putting less in the bags they distribute, asking clients to wait longer for bags or setting limits on the number of clients they serve. 
"The food is going out faster than it's coming in," said Rachel Bristol, executive director of the Oregon Food Bank, which distributes food to agencies, mostly pantries, throughout the state. "Some of our agencies have cut back from serving families six times a year to two." The 75-church Urban Ministries pantry of Raleigh, N.C., serves an average of 30 families a day. But 30 more a day need food, David Reese, the agency's resource director, said. "We turn folks away every day," Mr. Reese said. 
Meals served by the Salvation Army climbed from 51 million three years ago to 57 million in 2001 to 61 million last year, "and my sense is the need is still increasing," said Col. Tom Jones, a spokesman. While demand varies from city to city, the United States Conference of Mayors reported in December that in a survey of 25 cities, the number of requests for free food last year exceeded the 2001 average by 19 percent.
To help meet the demand through a program that provides about 25 percent of the food that Second Harvest manages, the United States Department of Agriculture says it spent $380 million in the 2002 fiscal year, about $200 million more than in the 2000 fiscal year. But the other sources of food are not keeping pace with the demand. 
One reason is the slow economy. Donations to pantries of private money from foundations, businesses and individuals have stalled. "People still give to us," Virginia White, president of the Kansas Foodbank Warehouse in Wichita, said. "People who used to give $100 are giving $10, $20." 
But there are other reasons beyond shifts in the economy. The 1996 overhaul of the welfare system and the law's tighter eligibility standards for food stamps are one. In moving more than half of the 12 million recipients off the rolls and into jobs, advocates of the poor say many former recipients still fail to earn enough to cover basic needs. 
Another is changes in the food industry. Supermarkets and food processing companies are using technology to control their inventories better. Many are also using better handling technology to cut down on the dented cans and scratched cartons that they give pantries. More stores and companies also sell excess and damaged supplies to a growing secondary market of discount stores rather than give them away.
The Central Virginia Foodbank in Richmond, a Second Harvest affiliate, supplies Lamb's Basket and 594 other pantries, shelters and soup kitchens in 31 Virginia counties from a 60,000-square-foot former tobacco warehouse. "We have never had more need for food," Fay Lohr, the executive director, said.
This year, Ms. Lohr said, 14 foundations have committed to a total of $48,000 in contributions to the food bank. Last year, 33 foundations gave $138,000. Two years ago, the food bank distributed 7.1 million pounds of food. With intense, door-to-door food drives to meet the rising demand, it distributed 11.4 million pounds last year.
"We're getting more U.S.D.A. product than we've ever gotten," she said. And yet, she said, "for the first time, we're having to ration food from the U.S.D.A." 
A growing industry of scavengers and volunteers feeds the supply line. Churches, which sponsor 70 percent of the Richmond food bank's pantries, ask parishioners to bring food to Sunday services. On some weeks, the Boy Scouts, the letter carriers' union or a bank organizes a food drive.
Pantry staffs are almost entirely volunteers, mostly retirees. About 100 volunteers take turns at Lamb's Basket ferrying in food from stores and the food bank, interviewing clients and packing bags and boxes. The pantries are cheerful, trusting, fast-moving places with little of the delay and paper-shuffling scrutiny of the welfare office.
Recently, two women lingered on concrete steps outside the Ephesus Seventh-Day Adventist Church on Richmond's South Side, waiting for the pantry in the cellar to open. They come once a month, they say.
"I come because I'm disabled," Phyllis Williams, 51, said. "My husband, he's disabled. He had a heart attack in January." The Williamses have two daughters and two grandchildren at home. Ms. Williams said their income was about $1,100 a month, mostly from food stamps and disability checks.
Sheila Russell, 46, a disabled and divorced mother of a 15-year-old boy, said: "It's better than Social Services because they don't degrade you. They don't make you feel like they're giving you something of theirs."
Both have worked, they said, but major companies in Richmond have been contracting and consolidating. "Let's be real," Ms. Russell said. "Look at all the money to fight that war. That's money that could have gone in people's kitchens."
Norma Foster, a volunteer, has managed the Ephesus pantry for five years. "When I started we were seeing 25 or 30 households a month," Ms. Foster said. "Now we're seeing 100 households with 200, 250 people a month. We can't take everybody." 
To receive food supplied by the Agriculture Department, a single person's income may not exceed $1,108 a month, a two-person family's, $1,493, a three-person family's, $1,878. People already eligible for disability payments, food stamps or Medicaid because of low incomes automatically qualify.
Food from the Agriculture Department, provided free to the pantry, is stored in one room. A year ago its shelves were full. Now, they are one-third full, with cans of beans and pears, boxes of powdered milk, and bags of shelled walnuts and trail mix.
"Spaghetti, juices, prunes, plums, mashed potatoes, noodles, they just don't have it now," Ms. Foster said.
At Lamb's Basket, bigger and better stocked, a can of black olives and a jar of clam juice linger on a shelf. But outdated Mother's Day cakes are moving fast. So are pasta, tuna, frozen chicken, Thomas's bagels and English muffins, and canned meals like ravioli in tomato sauce and franks and beans that a child home from school can open and heat.
"A family of five gets about five bags a month," said Betty Shumaker, the manager. In March, the last month for which she has compiled figures, the pantry served 330 households, including 447 children. In February, 229 households were served, and last June, 150.
"Jesus said, 'Feed my sheep,' " Ms. Shumaker said. "That's why we're Lamb's Basket. We'll give it out until it's gone."

HEADLINE: As Indonesia Battles Rebels, Its Civilians Bear the Burden 

BYLINE:  By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, May 24 

 BODY:
The Indonesian military said today that food and fuel were running short in the northern province of Aceh, where the government began a major military offensive against separatist rebels this week. 
 The United Nations Children's Fund, or Unicef, warned of an impending crisis for the civilian population with the collapse of already weak health services, and reported arson to more than 200 schools in the last five days. 
 The increasing difficulties for civilians came after the Indonesian government pledged that the offensive, which is intended to suppress the rebels within six months, would be different from those in the past. 
This time, the government said, the military action would strive to spare civilians the brutalities of past campaigns, especially those conducted in the last decade of the rule of President Suharto, who was ousted in 1998. 
The current leader, President Megawati Sukarnoputri, said last weekend, "I hope this action will be understood and supported by all the Indonesian people, including those groups working for democracy and human rights." 
Despite the government's pledge, the chief of the armed forces, Gen. Endriatono Sutarto, told his forces last weekend to fight the rebels "until your last drop of blood." 
"You are trained to kill, so wipe them out," he said.
The new effort, headed by an army known for its poor human rights record, is referred to by the Indonesian military as a "hunt and crush" operation. 
The Indonesian Army has battled the Free Aceh Movement for nearly 30 years. In the 1990's, the army fought a secret war in the province that included torture and summary executions of Acehnese civilians. The military's brutality added to the grievances in the province, which is rich in natural resources.
Exxon Mobil operates a major plantthat exports liquid natural gas from Aceh to Japan and South Korea. The plant, near the city of Lhoksomawe, has been a target of the rebels and is now heavily guarded by the Indonesian military. The rebels complain that Aceh has never received a fair share of revenues from the central government in Jakarta. 
The current military action began last Monday after peace talks brokered by the United States, Japan and the World Bank fell apart in Tokyo. Washington has said it supports the Indonesian government's insistence on the country's territorial integrity. But the State Department said it believed that both the rebels and the government could have done more to bridge their differences in Tokyo. 
The government has an estimated 40,000 soldiers and paramilitary police officers whose goal is to push the rebel fighters out of the province's population centers and deep into the jungle. The rebels include about 5,000 armed fighters who have managed to replenish their weapons in the last several months, Western diplomats said. 
In trying to differentiate the new offensive from those in the past, Mrs. Megawati's government has talked of a "humanitarian war" that blends tough action against the rebels with protection of civilians. To that end, the government has said it has plans to provide aid to up to 100,000 people who might be displaced by the fighting. 
But human rights workers assert that money set aside for assistance is likely to be stolen before it reaches those who need it. Moreover, they say, plans by the Indonesian military for a so-called strategic hamlet program in Aceh will harm civilians more than help them.
The army has told Western diplomats that if they do not make early headway against the rebels they will forcibly move villagers into secure compounds. That would be done in an effort to starve guerrilla fighters into submission, according to the plan. 
The rebels and the government gave conflicting accounts of the number of civilians killed in the first week of the new conflict. But there seemed little doubt that a group of perhaps as many as 12 civilians were killed on Wednesday morning in a village near the rebel stronghold of Bireun. According to accounts in the Indonesian press, among those killed was a 12-year-old boy who was accused by the military of being a spy for the rebels. 
A spokesman for the Indonesian military in Aceh, Lt. Col. Firdaus Komarno, said the army was looking into those reports. 
"If our investigation shows soldiers are indeed responsible," he said, "then we will hand down punishments we promised at the beginning of the operation." 
The spokesman was referring to an order by General Endriatono to his commanders: If their troops committed human rights abuses, the general said, the commanders should "just shoot them in the head."

HEADLINE: WOMEN'S BASKETBALL; 
For Its Seventh Season, the W.N.B.A. Undergoes a Significant Makeover

BYLINE:  By LENA WILLIAMS 

 BODY:
When the Women's National Basketball Association opened its seventh season last Thursday, it did so as a league transformed by time, circumstance, and business and economic reality.
 The makeover was substantive as well as cosmetic. While the W.N.B.A. made major changes, including its contract with the players, business model, attitude toward outside investors and schedule, it also redesigned the players' uniforms and the game ball. 
 The players, although not completely happy with their new contract, now have free agency, higher salaries and an opportunity to expand their market value. The league now has a salary cap, and with it, a new television deal with five networks and labor peace for five years. The fans have two more games a team for their money and, maybe, one of the most competitive seasons ever, thanks to a dispersal draft. 
"The changes in the model will better position the league to grow and, more importantly, will allow us to consider non-N.B.A. markets as home for W.N.B.A. teams," the league's president, Val Ackerman, said. "The collective bargaining agreement gives us long-term stability, and the league and the players can both benefit from movement afforded by free agency."
But the more things have changed in the W.N.B.A., the more things have remained the same:
*The two-time defending champions, the Los Angeles Sparks, remain the team to beat. 
*The road to the Eastern Conference title will again most likely go through New York, where the Liberty keeps winning with defense despite having one of the smallest frontcourts in the league. 
*The All-Star Game is back in New York.
*Teresa Edwards, 38, the five-time Olympian and one of the most revered players, makes her W.N.B.A. debut with the Minnesota Lynx, and Cynthia Cooper, a two-time league and four-time playoff most valuable player, is back playing for the Houston Comets after two seasons coaching the Phoenix Mercury.
But the new wrinkles are significant. The league opened two days earlier to accommodate the expanded schedule. Each team will play 34 games, and the regular season will be two weeks longer, extending to Aug. 25.
The postseason, which traditionally ended on Labor Day weekend, concludes on Sept. 14.
For the past six years, the league had the financial weight of the National Basketball Association behind it. But last November, the N.B.A. Board of Governors voted to change the W.N.B.A. business model from a single-entity structure to individual team ownership. The Portland Fire, the Miami Sol and the Orlando Magic folded. The Utah Starzz relocated to San Antonio.
But out of the ashes, the league got its first outside investor in a non-N.B.A. city when the Magic was acquired by the Mohegan tribe that owns and operates the Mohegan Sun Casino in Uncasville, Conn. The Connecticut Sun will play in the casino's 10,000-seat arena. And the dispersal draft for players from the Fire and the Sol has undoubtedly strengthened some franchises.
"This year promises to be tremendously competitive," Ackerman said. "I think the fact that we had a dispersal draft was another important mechanism for teams to get themselves more competitive. Players like Ruth Riley, Sheri Sam, Betty Lennox and others are going to make immediate contributions to their respective rosters."
Riley, the Sol center, landed in Detroit. Sam, her former teammate, will be playing in Minnesota. Lennox, the guard who was the W.N.B.A. rookie of the year in 2000, moves to Cleveland. Forward Elena Baranova, also from Miami, brings her 6-foot-5 outside presence to New York. 
The league has four new coaches: Mike Thibault in Connecticut; Suzie McConnell Serio in Minnesota; Candi Harvey in San Antonio; and John Shumate in Phoenix. Anne Donovan, who twice led the Charlotte Sting to the playoffs, is the new coach of the Seattle Storm.
The W.N.B.A. is gambling that all the changes will pay off. But questions remain.
Will the salary cap hurt teams like the Sparks, Liberty, Comets and Washington Mystics with the money to spend on franchise players? Will free agency spark a movement of players around the league and bidding wars for star players? How will fans react to a W.N.B.A. team playing its home games in a casino? Will more teams fold under the pressure of taking on operating costs once borne by the N.B.A.?
The answers to those questions may ultimately shape the future of the W.N.B.A.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Among the W.N.B.A.'s top players are, from left, Cynthia Cooper of the Houston Comets; Teresa Edwards, a five-time Olympian, of the Minnesota Lynx; and Lisa Leslie of the defending champion Los Angeles Sparks. (Photographs by Associated Press)
