HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: POLITICS; 
Returning to Iraq, Few Kurds Want to Be Part of It

BYLINE:  By SABRINA TAVERNISE 

DATELINE: KIRKUK, Iraq, May 24 

 BODY:
Khasro Goran, a Kurd who is the new deputy governor of the northern city of Mosul, thumbed through a book of maps in his office there recently, tracing with his finger what he calls the true border of Kurdistan.
 The old border used to cramp Kurds in the northeast of Iraq. But since the war, Kurds have begun streaming back to the valleys and villages farther south from which they were driven in a series of ethnic cleansing campaigns that began in the 1960's. 
 Now Kurdish territory includes a plump new swath of land. In one southern province alone, Erbil, about 400 villages have been reclaimed, according to Nechirvan Barzani, the regional governor. For Mr. Goran, as for most Kurds, it is sweet victory. 
"Now we are back in Mosul," he said, pointing to the dot on the map. "We control Senjar and Mosul Provinces. We want to add the other parts of Kurdistan. We have the same economy, language and future. For the rest of Iraq, it's up to them, but for our part, we will govern ourselves."
After decades of deportations, mass killings and other miseries, Kurds are starting to feel for the first time in recent history that it is safe to return their homes. Even in Halabja, a town devastated by chemical attacks in 1988, residents are beginning to come back.
Kurdish political leaders have governed their own independent enclave in northern Iraq under American protection since 1991. In public, they say they want to be part of Iraq, but most ordinary Kurds do not want that. As American authorities propose remaking Iraqi institutions, Kurds say those very institutions -- the army in particular -- brought them only misery in the past.
"More than 80 percent of the people are for independence," said Farhad Pirbal, a professor of Kurdish history and literature at Erbil University. "It's etiquette, like a game. The politicians say what the Americans want to hear."
But, he continued, the Kurdish leader Massoud Barzani "in his heart" aspires to be president of "the country of Kurdistan."
Kurds are emerging as the most influential force in the political soup of Baghdad today. They are the only group with their own army, and Kurdish fighters -- unlike Shiite Muslim and other Iraqi militias -- would be allowed to keeptheir assault rifles and heavy weapons under an American draft proposal.
They are organized and politically conscious. They have a functioning economy in their independent zone, while the rest of Iraq has foundered. The two main Kurdish leaders, Mr. Barzani and Jalal Talabani, speak fluent English and have had dealings with the United States for decades.
"They're definitely the kingmakers, and the question is whether they might also be the kings," said Peter W. Galbraith, a professor of national security studies at the National War College in Washington.
Kurdish politicians talk of pragmatism. After all, the Kurds do not have their own state, but are spread out in four countries: Iraq, Iran, Syria and Turkey. The Kurdish enclave in Iraq is landlocked and could not survive without doing business with its neighbors and with Baghdad, no matter how good its relations with the United States.
"No Kurd can dissuade himself of the right to self-determination, but history and geography have been cruel to my people, and we know the possibility of a Kurdish state in Iraq is a very distant one," said Barham Salih, governor of the eastern Kurdish enclave. "The tangible thing for us is to work for a federal democracy and be a full-fledged Iraqi citizen."
But Kurds have already made substantial gains since the war. In Kirkuk, a northern city that was the center of Saddam Hussein's "Arabization" campaign to replace Kurdish residents with Arabs and give Baghdad more control over the region's oil fields, the local police force is now overwhelmingly Kurdish.
Kurds won another victory today when American forces here detained five members of an Arab delegation on its way to a city council election. The delegates were suspected of having been members of Mr. Hussein's Baath Party. The American commander in Kirkuk, Maj. Gen. Raymond T. Odierno, met with Mr. Barzani on Friday at his Kurdish base.
Kurdish political parties said today that they were confident they would win the governorship of the Kirkuk region in elections on Tuesday .
The northern city of Sulaimaniya sent more than 100 doctors to Kirkuk. Kurdish militia guard the gates of the Northern Oil Company, the state-owned oil company there. In addition, Kurdish groups appear to be quietly nursing relations with foreign neighbors independent of Baghdad. A Turkish consulate will open in Sulaimaniya this month, and the local government there is pushing ahead on several oil contracts with foreign companies -- more to stake out territory than to reap profits.
The strong new Kurdish presence has chafed on the Arab community in the region, particularly in Kirkuk. Arabs there say Kurdish police officers ignore their problems. They also say Kurds, encouraged by newly energized political parties, are moving into houses that do not belong to them.
American authorities are still unsure how to handle the problem. The new American civilian administrator of Iraq, L. Paul Bremer III, cut short a visit to northern cities last week. An American official who spoke on the condition of anonymity said the Kurdish issue was the main reason for the cancellation.
"The Kurds are the wild card in the Iraqi equation," said Professor Galbraith. "If they were given a choice, almost unanimously they would prefer not to be in Iraq. Over the long term, that's a big problem."
The problem is essentially one of trust. The main political parties, the Patriotic Union of Kurdistan and the Kurdistan Democratic Party, have similar aims, but fought bitterly for territory and influence throughout much of the 1990's. The leaders ofthe parties, Mr. Talabani and Mr. Barzani, seem to have struck a truce since the end of the American-led war. But trusting Baghdad, even if it is run by Americans, is proving difficult.
Mr. Barzani and Mr. Talabani lodged a formal protest with Mr. Bremer last week, saying the new United Nations resolution to lift sanctions and redistribute funds held from oil sales was unfair to Kurds. In addition, many Kurds think the Americans have been too soft and too slow in untangling the Arabization issue, which the Kurds see as the most important issue now.
"Our previous experience is making us anxious," said Nechirvan Barzani, the regional governor and a nephew of Massoud Barzani. "We feel that we're being kept in the dark about what's happening. People are anxious and unhappy with the way the United States is conducting the process."
Since breaking free from Mr. Hussein in 1991, northern Iraq has been a relative oasis of prosperity. Satellite dishes beam dozens of television channels from every roof. Goods fill shops. All large towns have Internet cafes.
The political parties have grown wealthy, in part on renegade trade across leaky borders with Syria, Iran and Turkey, and have ruled with a strong hand. They held elections only once over the past decade, and are dominated by powerful families, personalities and unilateral decision-making. Critics say the biggest challenge for American forces will be untangling that web.
"The society is like a little mosaic of many patronage networks," said David McDowall, author of "A Modern History of the Kurds." "Kurdish political parties today are not that different from the tribes of the 18th century. You don't get democracy as an end product. You get patrons delivering chunks of delivered votes."
Most Kurds say they are aching to re-enter the larger world after decades of isolation. Because of their uncertain status over the past decade, ordinary Kurds did not have passports. They pin their hopes on the United States to modernize Iraq.
"I have never ridden on a plane or a train," said Rooshad Muhammad, 23, a medical student in Sulaimaniya. "We just want to live like normal people."

HEADLINE: May 18-24; 
PUSHING THE ENVELOPE

BYLINE:  By Felicity Barringer

 BODY:
Back in the good old days, last month, a few basic texts supplied all the international laws invoked when one state occupies another. Now, in addition to the Fourth Geneva Convention and the Hague Regulation of 1907, there is United Nations Security Council Resolution 1483 of 2003. 
 Adopted by the Council without dissent Thursday, the measure takes international law on occupation to a place it has never been in modern history. It gives the United States and Britain sweeping authority to reconstitute Iraq's political system and control its economy. A senior United Nations official called the leap in international law "breathtaking." 
 There is little quarrel, however, with the Security Council's right to legislate as it did, ending nearly 13 years of sanctions against Iraq and giving a new United Nations special representative, Sergio Vieira de Mello, the current high commissioner for human rights, an independent but limited role in the country's physical and political reconstruction. The United Nations' lawyer, Hans Corell, had told Council members that they were free to adopt any measure they chose. But, he added, they should remember they were setting a precedent. Felicity Barringer

HEADLINE: New Rochelle Library Too Vital to Shut Down 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Many arguments can be made in support of the New Rochelle Public Library in the specter of its closing due to a lack of funding. 
 These include statistics indicating the heavy usage of the New Rochelle library (second highest among Westchester libraries); the critical role the library plays in nurturing literacy through its early childhood programs; the resources the library offers older children with homework help, computer access, materials for research projects, a source for developing a life-long love of reading and learning, and the safe haven in which the library offers these services for at-risk, disadvantaged youth; the cultural and social vitality that the library sustains through its programs in music, films and art exhibits; resume help and other job-hunting assistance for the unemployed or underemployed (particularly vital in this time of economic and employment insecurity); free English classes for new Americans seeking a better future for themselves and their children. 
 I and others are working hard to ensure that New Rochelle residents give a resounding yes for the library at the polls on June 3. But even should the vote be successful, the idea that the existence of our public library should be in jeopardy and requiring ongoing effort to keep open is simply unacceptable. 
 At a time when cities and towns throughout New York State are facing financial difficulties and are required to raise taxes to maintain city services (including their libraries), only the city of New Rochelle is hamstrung by a tax cap. This is a consequence of the short-sightedness of New Rochelle's representatives in the State Assembly, Ron Tocci and Amy Paulin. The tax cap currently prevents the city of New Rochelle from raising the funds necessary to keep the library open. But property values in New Rochelle will plummet if the library closes. In short, the tax cap is too costly.
 Even New Rochelle homeowners who do not frequent the public library and are unmoved by arguments made to keep the library open surely care about the value of their homes and property diminishing.

Amy Rosenbaum, Ph.D.
New Rochelle

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths; 
PLUNKET, , JOHN THOMPSON

 BODY:
 PLUNKET--John Thompson, 88, of Sarasota, FL, passed away May 7th in Cholula, Mexico. Devoted husband of Dolores, loving father of Lucy Silver, Robert, John Jr. and Patricia, revered grandfather of Sarah, Andrea, Rebecca, Benjamin, Orion and John III. Mr. 
Plunket's career spanned 50 years of Latin American business and politics. A former special agent of the FBI, he conducted intelligence work during WWII in Venezuela and Costa Rica. After the war, he served as legal counsel to Braniff Airways and later as an executive with American and Foreign Power Company. He was President of the Cuban Electric Company when it was nationalized by the Cuban government in 1960. In Mexico during the 70's and 80's, he helped develop Mexico's industrial growth and expansion. He served as President of the American Chamber of Commerce in Mexico and President of the American Chamber of Commerce in Latin America. After funeral services in Mexico, Mr. Plunket was buried in his hometown of Greenville, TX. A memorial service will take place in Sarasota. >>AD#

HEADLINE: Denver Election Is a Model of Civility 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: DENVER, May 23 

 BODY:
With Wellington E. Webb stepping down next month after three terms as mayor, city residents will elect a new leader for the first time in 12 years, and if the campaign has not made a lot of waves here or elsewhere, there is a good reason.
 As the leading finishers among seven candidates in an election on May 6, Democrats John Hickenlooper and Don Mares are headed for a June 3 runoff, and so far, they could not have been nicer to each other. 
 Theirs has been a race remarkable in modern American politics, one nearly devoid of rancor, mudslinging and negative advertising. Until now, at least, their debates and campaign literature have focused on issues. And sharing a podium, as they did here on Thursday at a forum sponsored by the Rotary Club, they actually seem to like each other. 
The amity has surprised some political strategists here, given that Mr. Mares, 46, a former state legislator who has served as city auditor for the past seven years, is a heavy underdog, and underdogs usually get nowhere by being nice.
"I'm very surprised," said Lori Weigel, a partner in Public Opinion Strategies, a polling firm, referring to Mr. Mares's sanguine approach.
In the general election, Mr. Mares won 22 percent of the vote compared with 43 percent for Mr. Hickenlooper, 51, a geologist turned restaurateur. 
City law requires a runoff between the top two finishers when no candidate reaches 50 percent.
Polls in the past two weeks showed Mr. Mares trailing badly.
"The race could tighten up, but it's pretty clear by our polling that he can't win by building himself up," Ms. Weigel said. "He has to tear Hickenlooper down. So far he hasn't, but there's still time."
While the candidates have vowed to run clean, upbeat campaigns, it was clear shortly after the general election that Mr. Mares was advised to go on the attack.
One of his seniorcampaign aides, Tim Knaus, a former chairman of the Colorado Democratic party, quit after a difference of opinion over strategy that included attack advertisements against Mr. Hickenlooper. The advertisements did not run.
In an interview, Mr. Mares said he had resisted advice from "people pressuring me" to run a more aggressive campaign over the final weeks. He was guided by a feeling, he said, that "society has been alienated" by nasty campaigns and that he should focus on problems and solutions.
"I'll point out what I think are differences, the contrast in our ideas," Mr. Mares said. "But that's all. I want us to stay aboveboard, and talk about the issues."
For all the civility, the campaign has come during Denver's worst financial crisis since Mr. Webb, a Democrat who has not endorsed either candidate, was first elected.
Like other cities that rode the high-tech wave into the mid-1990's, Denver is on a downward path by any economic measure. Over the past 18 months, the city has lost more than 17,000 jobs. Downtown office towers are begging for tenants. By next year, the city's budget deficit could reach $50 million.
Mr. Hickenlooper and Mr. Mares have made closing the deficit a cornerstone of their campaigns. Mr. Hickenlooper said he wanted to cut the city payroll by 4 percent and lower personnel costs. Mr. Mares said he would rather eliminate wasteful spending than jobs.
They agree on many issues, including job creation as critical to Denver's economic rebound, but they disagree on others. Mr. Hickenlooper said he would be open to a school voucher plan to improve educational choices; Mr. Mares opposes vouchers as a drain on the public school system. Mr. Mares said he would not rule out raising taxes; Mr. Hickenlooper said new taxes would discourage business development. Mr. Mares favors a smoking ban in restaurants, which Mr. Hickenlooper argues is antibusiness.
Mr. Hickenlooper's appeal to voters has come largely from his feisty campaign style and a strategy to sell himself as a fresh-faced political newcomer, a candidate with new ideas for lingering problems. He has pointed to his background as an out-of-work scientist who built a chain of restaurants and worked for nonprofit groups to convey his grit, management skills and community spirit.
"A lot of people are tired of politics as usual," he said on Thursday, branding himself as an outsider compared with Mr. Manes, who worked in government for years. "But I'm not the typical little guy who makes it big. In the process of building a business, I've been involved with the community and I've never shied away from speaking up when politicians didn't do so."
Mr. Mares pointed to his own frequent differences with Mr. Webb as evidence of his independence and right to say he is a political outsider.
Even so, Mr. Mares said he still needed to overcome Mr. Hickenlooper's broad appeal to close the gap, and time is running out. Mr. Hickenlooper said he feared the polls that showed him with a wide lead might scare people off. 
"My biggest enemy now is apathy," Mr. Hickenlooper said. "People are excited about the campaign, but they're not excited about politicians. My job now is to keep them turned on."

HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.; 
When Risks Eclipse Rewards in Corporate Bonds

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
EUGENE FLOOD JR., the chief executive of Smith Breeden Associates, has a warning for investors who have been enjoying the good returns in the corporate bond market.
 Investors, Mr. Flood said, are no longer being paid enough for the risk of carrying investment-grade corporate bonds in their portfolios. The big rally in this sector has narrowed the interest rate spread, or differential, between corporate bonds and Treasuries and has pulled the yields of corporates so low that they don't justify the risk of a downturn in the market. 
 "The reason we have changed our position is not that things are good or bad," he said. "It is because the compensation for bearing risk right now has fallen dramatically."
Mr. Flood said Smith Breeden, which manages $26 billion for institutional investors, including Unisys and the Asian Development Bank, began rejiggering its corporate bond portfolio last year and has accelerated the move in the last two months.
Smith Breeden, based in Chapel Hill, N.C., has pulled out about $7 billion from some volatile investment-grade sectors and moved the money into more conservative areas, like the agency bonds of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, commercial mortgage-backed securities and asset-backed securities. The firm has also changed its hedges against interest rate moves to make its portfolio less vulnerable to a sudden reversal in the corporate bond market.
Among corporate bonds that Smith Breeden has sold recently are those of Ford, AT&T and Verizon Communications. Last October, a Ford bond held by Smith Breeden had a yield of 9.75 percent. That is now down to 7 percent, which Mr. Flood said was not high enough to justify the risk that the economy would slow and the bond would sell off. He also reduced his holdings of residential mortgage-backed securities. They are less attractive because low interest rates have increased the probability of prepayments as homeowners refinance their mortgages. Commercial mortgage-backed securities have much less prepayment risk, so they are less volatile.
Mr. Flood's view that the risk-reward ratio is out of balance offers little solace to investors who, seeking safety, have put up with paltry yields of money market funds. He says that this is not a great time to take on more risk by going for attractive yields. "There are not a lot of things that are exciting on a risk-reward basis," Mr. Flood said.
Still, he said most investors should not keep much in money market funds now, because their yields are less than 1 percent and may keep falling. Some $2.15 trillion is invested in money market mutual funds, only slightly below the $2.27 trillion a year ago, according to AMG Data Services.
Mr. Flood outlined four alternatives.
The least-risky possibility is a short-duration bond fund, which mimics the performance of short-term securities and has a heavy emphasis on residential mortgage-backed securities. He said such funds could have a return of 2 percent this year, based on the yields and the profits from trading the mortgage-backed securities.
Foreign bonds, especially those from Europe, are another opportunity. Yields on European bonds are now higher than those of their American counterparts, and Mr. Flood said he expected that the European Central Bank would have to cut its benchmark interest rate soon. That would bolster European bond prices. In addition, the dollar could fall more, adding to the returns on foreign bonds when they are translated back into dollars. But this is also the riskiest alternative, because a sudden turn in the dollar could change gains into losses in a hurry.
Another option is the Treasury's inflation-protected securities, known as TIPS. But Mr. Flood warned that since mid-April TIPS have returned 8 percent and similar returns are unlikely in the near future. Falling inflation is also not good for TIPS.
The fourth possibility, high-yield or junk bonds, still provides enough return for the risk, he said, especially when compared with the alternative of putting money into the stock market, which is already up 6 percent this year.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Falling Premium"The yield spread between corporate bonds and Treasuries has declined sharply since last fall, reducing the risk premium for owning corporate bonds. Graph tracks the percentage points for corporate bonds and Treasuries since 2002. (Source: Moody's Investors Service)

LENGTH: 4599 words

HEADLINE: The Radical Bean Counter 

BYLINE:  By James Bennet; James Bennet is the Jerusalem bureau chief of The New York Times.

 BODY:
This is a story about fighting Palestinian chaos and corruption, about seeking to throw off Israeli occupation and build a democratic state of Palestine. It is about these things, because it is about one man's lonely pursuit of direct deposit.
 The man is Salam Fayyad, the Palestinian minister of finance, the kind of Palestinian you rarely hear about, an economist trained in Texas who has never fired a gun, sent men into battle or served time in prison or exile. He met recently in Gaza City with half a dozen men who had done these things -- who do some of them still -- the chiefs of Yasir Arafat's Gaza security services, the most hardened of Palestinian warriors. It was Fayyad's intention to intimidate them. 
 As the chiefs arrived at the Saraya, the military headquarters in Gaza, some of them wore fatigues and were trailed by men carrying guns. Fayyad, as usual, arrived alone, carrying his black satchel and wearing his nice blue jacket, red-and-blue tie and spectacles. 
Fayyad did not tell these men everything he thought: that he was horrified by the system, if it could be called that, for paying the 53,000 security officers from the dozen independent security agencies in the West Bank and Gaza; that he thought it was morally wrong to dole out $20 million in cash monthly, in plastic bank bags, to the security chiefs, to be handed out to their men, one by one; that he worried that some of the money, "paying" for ghost employees, might be lining the wrong people's pockets, perhaps even financing the kind of violence the security agencies were supposed to stop.
He did not make a point obvious to everyone in the room: that the power of the purse is power, period, and that his reform would help shift control of the officers from these chiefs, and from Yasir Arafat, to the first Palestinian prime minister, Mahmoud Abbas. In theory, Fayyad now reports to Abbas; in practice, he checks in with both him and Arafat, the president of the Palestinian Authority, who appointed him last June; in reality, he is choosing his battles for himself.
Fayyad presented his idea as a common-sense change that anyone who favored efficiency and clean government -- as security officers naturally did -- would support. He had already divided the chiefs by previously persuading two of them. Now he, the economist, not any of the military men, began pounding the table. Unless the chiefs switched to direct deposit of paychecks, he said, he could not guarantee that their salaries would be paid. Foreign donors would cut them off. Did they want to be forced by outsiders to change, or to act with a sense of pride?
Later, with the matter undecided, I rode with Fayyad from Gaza back to Ramallah, in the West Bank, where the Palestinian Authority is headquartered. He wondered whether he would have to use the weapon he held in reserve, a bean counter's laser-guided bomb: publicly naming the recalcitrant chiefs and declaring loud enough for the 124,000 Palestinian civil servants to hear that, if every agency switched to direct deposit, he would cancel the so-called intifada tax of 7 to 12 percent levied on paychecks by the Palestinian Authority during the uprising. He said he hoped that would turn the civil servants against the security leaders.
"There are battles that have to be fought, and have to be won decisively," he told me, as the car climbed toward Jerusalem. "And I may not win this battle. And then it will be over for me."
This is a terrible time to be the average Palestinian, and so it is a golden time to become an exceptional one. The Palestinians are at a historic moment in search of historic leaders -- the Jeffersons, Hamiltons and Washingtons who can wrest a viable, competent state from Israelis (even on the left) who are distrustful and angry; from a Bush administration that is chilly and distracted; and from Islamists who seem bent on endless conflict. 
Arafat remains pre-eminent. There is no Palestinian power vacuum. But there is a new softness at the core, because of the pressure on Arafat from not only the United States but also Europe. Inside Arafat's dominant Fatah faction, younger leaders are starting to attack him and his generation for mismanagement and cronyism. For them, the issue is not merely having a state, but what kind of state is worth having. Fatah members who grew up under the Israeli occupation are rebelling against the wrinkled exiles who came back from decades overseas to build a state and, in the view of these younger people, blew it.
"They can go to hell," said Khaled Elyazji, Arafat's former protocol chief, who is now running a center in Gaza for political change. We were talking about Fatah's Central Committee, composed of the faction's most venerable leaders. "These are the people who led us in the last four years from disaster to disaster."
Abbas, the prime minister, founded Fatah together with Arafat and returned like him from exile. He may surprise everyone, but most Palestinian politicians and diplomats in Jerusalem expect him to be a transitional figure between the era of Arafat and a new Palestinian leadership. (He likes to delegate authority, and to nap in the afternoon.) 
Fayyad, an ally of the prime minister and one who would clearly like to have his job someday, presents a different case study in the use of power. He dismissed the security detail that the Palestinian Authority offered him, in the belief he should never show fear. He travels by car service and taxi, walks alone across checkpoints and fields his own calls nonstop on a cellphone. The father of three children in a Jerusalem private school, he left a much more lucrative job to become finance minister at about $1,200 a month, and Israeli and American officials who study the Palestinian Authority say he is an honest man. He has been praised by Colin Powell, Ariel Sharon and Yasir Arafat; despite that, he has flourished politically. His suits, hair and skin are all rather gray, like the dense cloud of cigarette smoke in which he moves. At 51, he is fidgety, ambitious, profoundly sure of himself. He is a small, assuming man.
"If you have the authority, use it," Fayyad likes to say. "If you don't have it, create it."
The challenge to such new leaders is to fight two revolutions at once: against the Israeli occupation and against the aristocracy of revolution that has shaped the Palestinian national dream for 35 years. Arafat got his people very far -- within sight of their state -- but he has not delivered them. Many Palestinians believe that Arafat encouraged this uprising partly to save himself, to deflect anger over, to put it simply, bad government.
Ismail Abu Shanab, a senior political leader of Hamas, made an astonishing criticism of Palestinian self-rule to me recently in his home in Gaza City: "When the Israelis were here, we lived our lives better than now, in every way. Believe me.
"Look how the streets of Gaza are not clean," he complained.
This is a basic political point that Hamas understands as well as any Chicago alderman, but that the Palestinian Authority has not quite grasped. Hamas has gained strength not only through violence, but also through its schools, health clinics and reputation for incorruptibility. Arafat's failure is also a failure of the Israelis and the Americans, and it holds lessons for the United States as it tries to rebuild Iraq.
Successive Israeli and American administrations sought security above all else from Arafat, and did not pay much mind to how he went about building a proto-state, the governing Palestinian Authority called for under Oslo. Details like sacks of money dropped in the hands of security chiefs did not seem like such a problem, provided the security chiefs did what Israel wanted.
Reviving Palestinian security is central to the new peace plan, known as the road map, and the long-postponed drama with Hamas may lie ahead. But it turns out that dullness also counts: detailed budgets, due process, responsive bureaucracies -- the institutions and practices that may not capture headlines but that do improve people's lives and sustain peaceful states.
Now reform of the Palestinian Authority has gained prominence in the drive for Middle East peace. That is in part a triumph for Prime Minister Ariel Sharon, who for more than a year shifted the conversation away from Israeli military tactics and settlements. It is also, potentially, a problem for Palestinian reformers. To a degree, their two revolutions could conflict, because the struggle for good governance could be seen by Palestinians as a struggle on behalf of Sharon and President George W. Bush.
Fayyad rejects that link. He is not optimistic about the new peace process. But he argues that improving governance would benefit Palestinians day to day, and also foster "character rebuilding" -- restoring a sense of what they can accomplish on their own.
The occupation, he told me, "in no way should give us a license to resign. Or worse, a license for bad governance. To the contrary."
But there is a flip side to that message. As we rode into Gaza one day this spring, Israeli forces were withdrawing from a raid that left five Palestinians dead. We passed an Israeli tank, an armored personnel carrier and a giant D-9 armored bulldozer, with its man-size steel spike canted in the air behind it. Then we parted a crowd of Palestinian children, some with bookbags, who were milling in the stone-strewn, rutted road.
Paycheck reform was suddenly beside the point, and Fayyad seemed momentarily deflated. He said he had no sense of possibility that Sharon, despite his talk of painful concessions, would ever agree to more than a "Mickey Mouse state" west of the Jordan River.
"This reform business -- it's a matter of obligation, as far as I'm concerned," he said. "But poor governance is hardly an excuse for colonialism."
As we left later that day, a warning came over the car radio that Israeli helicopter gunships were above Gaza City. From the checkpoint, Fayyad heard the explosions as the Israelis fired missiles to kill a leader of Islamic jihad.
"Sometimes it seems we're meant to fail," he said, more to himself than to me.
Fayyad is an outsider to what has become the Palestinian political establishment. He grew up in the West Bank town of Tulkarm, son and grandson of members of the Parliament of Jordan, which then held the West Bank. The family moved to Jordan proper in 1968, after Israel seized and occupied the West Bank and Gaza Strip in the Six-Day War. Fayyad was starting 10th grade. He would not return to live in what he hoped would become Palestine for 27 years.
In accordance with his grandfather's wishes, Fayyad was sent off to college at the American University of Beirut. The university, like Palestinian colleges in the West Bank, was intensely partisan, fractured more along Marxist and "reactionary" lines than along the Islamist-secular fault that has developed since. Arafat was in Beirut then, and Fatah was in its revolutionary prime. 
Somehow Fayyad never got around to joining Fatah or any other faction. He did not like the way his friends seemed compelled to buy the party line when they joined. When he entered school politics and ran for his dormitory's council, he drew on several factions, named his list of candidates after the dorm, Penrose, and won. 
Those were the glory days of Arab economic power -- the days of OPEC and oil embargoes -- and Fayyad dropped his pursuit of chemistry for business and economics. After working in Jordan, he went to Austin, Tex., where eventually he earned a Ph.D. in economics at the University of Texas. After a brief stint at the Federal Reserve in St. Louis, and then nine years with the International Monetary Fund in Washington, he felt a tug from the Middle East. 
With the Oslo accords in 1993 came an in-gathering from the Palestinian diaspora, as intellectuals and businessmen rushed back from the United States, Europe, gulf states and elsewhere to join in building their national home. Fayyad said he felt antsy and even a little guilty reading The Washington Post and drinking coffee in his backyard in suburban Virginia. He arrived in Jerusalem at the end of 1995.
For the next six years he served as the International Monetary Fund representative to the Palestinian Authority, and he watched as the Palestinian state that was supposed to come into existence in 1999 receded toward the horizon in a haze of bad faith, corruption and violence. As Oslo collapsed, many Palestinian returnees grew disillusioned and left the occupied territories. But Fayyad said he was never tempted to leave.
"It's an opportunity to do good things, to build institutions that could last," he told me recently, as he wolfed down a cheeseburger for lunch at his desk (it was 5 p.m.). "I don't see how one could pass that up."
As it had with other returnees, America left its mark on Fayyad. At meetings in Gaza, while his assistants sip coffee from traditional thimble-size porcelain cups, he sucks it down from a mug. He chain-smokes Winstons. He speaks torrential English, and though he is a Muslim, he might refer in conversation to the feeling that comes after two or three glasses of wine.
Fayyad was such an outsider that it was hard to take him seriously when Arafat, under international pressure to reform, tapped him as finance minister last June. Fayyad talked big about change, but he had no popular support and no history with Fatah or any other faction. Then, one day in September, he went to meet with Arafat in the Mukata, his official compound in Ramallah.
A more experienced Palestinian official might have realized it was a good day to come very late or not at all. It was last Sept. 19, and Palestinian suicide bombers had just killed seven people in back-to-back attacks. The Israeli Army arrived at the Mukata so fast that Fayyad lost his briefcase. It was crushed inside the car in which he had come, under an Israeli armored vehicle.
Israel offered to let Fayyad leave, as it did some others inside. He stayed, while the army demolished most of the compound and snipers took up posts outside, until American pressure forced Sharon to lift the siege after 11 days. Fayyad emerged with new credibility on the street.
During the siege, more than 400 men were sealed into one building. Fayyad shared a small room with Arafat, the interior minister, Hani al-Hassan, and Arafat's top aide, Nabil Aburdeineh. Each man took a corner and slept on a pad. The room had an air-conditioner, which had the double advantage of cooling things off and bringing some fresh air into the fetid atmosphere. But it turns out that Arafat gets cold when he sleeps. He pulls on a cap and burrows under blankets. Each evening, Fayyad and Aburdeineh would blast the air-conditioner, only to wake up sweating in the middle of the night because the Palestinian leader had stealthily retrieved the remote control and shut the air-conditioner off. After a couple of nights, the remote control disappeared, and after ransacking the room the other men concluded Arafat had taken to sleeping with it under his pillow.
Jeffrey Feltman, the acting chief of mission at the United States consulate in Jerusalem, drew an obvious moral from this story when Fayyad told it to him: Arafat would not surrender any control. Fayyad saw it differently -- that power had devolved, and Arafat could not trust even his closest aides anymore.
At the Ministry of Finance, Fayyad's approach has been to act on the assumption that Arafat meant what he said when he granted him the authority to do his job. One of his first moves was to centralize the Palestinian Authority's income. Each ministry or agency had been holding onto the fees it collected for things like transportation, stamps or health insurance -- a total of about $24 million a month. This meant that ministries that collected little money, like Education, had little to spend.
Fayyad's approach was characteristically heavy-handed. He wanted to signal that he meant business. Acting through the Palestinians' monetary authority, he ordered all banks in the West Bank and Gaza to block checks written on those funds by other ministries. And he told the banks to transfer the money to the treasury. Then he dispatched a two-line "for your information" note to his colleagues.
Fayyad stripped authority over the civilian payroll from the Palestinian civil service bureau and brought it to his own ministry; this meant that the bureau in charge of hiring no longer also distributed checks, and it enabled Fayyad to obstruct a patronage system that was annually adding 10,000 to 15,000 people -- many with less than sterling resumes -- to the payroll. He issued the first detailed, public Palestinian budget, of $1.28 billion, and he posted it on the Web (www.mof.gov.ps). He tracked down $600 million in Palestinian Authority assets in 79 commercial ventures, from Canadian biopharmaceuticals to Algerian cellphones, and hired Standard & Poor's to examine them for their value and ownership structure. He published the results as they came in, identifying the officials involved, centralizing the investments under a new supervising agency and laying plans to sell them off.
And he began simply ignoring many of the slips that arrived bearing Arafat's signature, the ones requesting a job for someone or help with bills or students' fees. Fayyad now had an all-purpose answer for requests he deemed unworthy: there was no allocation in the budget for them, so he was powerless to act. "It's incumbent on the treasurer to say no," he says.
These changes are only a start, as Fayyad acknowledges. He has yet to audit the payrolls for ghost employees or to break up the Palestinian monopolies on oil and other commodities, which feed corruption. Longer term, he wants to modernize the Palestinians' income-tax code. But for now he is doing triage, focusing on areas where the problem is not inefficiency but, as he puts it, right and wrong.
"This guy is my next target," he told me gleefully one day, hanging up after talking to a high-ranking official involved in a continuing scam.
At each major step, Fayyad has been careful to keep Arafat apprised, if sometimes a bit after the fact. Arafat, Fayyad said, has never complained to him. If so, a major reason is that, as Fayyad's reforms took hold, the Bush administration began pushing Israel to release hundreds of millions of dollars in funds it had sequestered from the Palestinian Authority. The money comes from import duties and other fees paid by Palestinians that, according to Oslo, Israel is supposed to pass along.
In the fall and winter last year, at a time coordination had all but died between Israel and the Palestinian Authority, Fayyad quietly held a series of meetings with Israeli officials that were brokered by American diplomats. The Israeli argument -- that the authority would just spend any new funds on terrorism -- was becoming less persuasive as Fayyad's financial controls kicked in. Eventually, the Israelis relented. In January alone, Israel handed the Palestinian Authority about $50 million. It was about to go bankrupt.
When I asked Khaled Elyazji, the director of the center seeking political reform, if any of the two dozen ministers had impressed him, he mentioned only Fayyad. "At the beginning they accused him of being a spy, and said that he was imposed by the Americans," he said. "But he established a transparent financial institution. And who gained from that? The people. Who lost? The corrupt."
Gen. Abd Al-Razek al-Majaydah, a dignified man with a silver mustache and a green beret, is chief of the Palestinian "national security" forces. On a recent Sunday night in his office inside the Saraya, in Gaza City, I raised what proved the unappealing subject of direct deposit. "This doesn't work in the army," he said shortly. "It doesn't make any sense for a soldier with a gun to go to the bank. Imagine if I came here one day and everyone was at the bank."
He warmed to his argument. "Do you know any Arab army -- Egypt, Sudan, Yemen, Syria -- that gets its money from the bank?"
I suggested that Palestine could be first.
"Why us?" he asked. ("There is nothing innocent about this -- nothing!" Fayyad exploded, when I recounted the conversation to him later. Then he began muttering caustically to himself, "No Arab army. . . . ")
Majaydah insisted he was doing nothing wrong -- though he said he might have added a few extra unemployed men to the payroll just to help out -- and he said that "Mr. Salam" was welcome to send accountants to watch him. 
A different armed force in Gaza, this one devoted to "preventive security," had already signed up for direct deposit, and the men I spoke with in Gaza's streets seemed pleased. They were men with rifles, to be sure, but they were also men on the job, making about $200 a month and trying to take care of their families in a very difficult place. Direct deposit meant that they received their money precisely on schedule and, for some, that they had bank accounts for the first time.
"You feel you're respected," one 23-year-old sergeant explained, as he stood guard outside the central headquarters. "It's civilized. And it will make it much easier for me to get a loan."
Fayyad's pursuit of this reform is a textbook illustration of his method. Two days before he began pushing the security chiefs to adopt his plan, he conducted a pre-emptive strike at the official who controlled the monthly disbursement to the services in the West Bank. Fayyad learned that, after one month's payroll went out, this official still had about half a million dollars in his account. Without any warning, Fayyad snatched it from the bank.
"It was intended to be seen as malicious," he told me with relish. "I knew what I was going to do only two days later, and I wanted to go on the offensive." His general belief appears to be that some of his colleagues will run from a fight, and the only way to achieve reform is to keep your opponents perpetually on defense. "Make them react to you," he says.
For the next month's payroll, Fayyad issued the man half a million dollars less.
Having lined up two allies among the security chiefs, Fayyad held the Gaza meeting with the bosses. What he wanted was lists of all their employees, with identification numbers and bank accounts. But they balked. And until the entire security force was signed up, the system could have little effect on fighting corruption and centralizing payment and, with it, control.
Fayyad insisted to me that Arafat has backed him up on direct deposit, but allies of the finance minister said he had to argue it out with him. Regardless, Arafat did not exactly put his shoulder to the wheel.
So Fayyad's next stop was the Palestinian Legislative Council, the Parliament. For years, this was a debating society, but lately it has shown signs of strength. It forced Arafat to form a new government last fall, and it created substantial powers for the prime minister over Arafat's objections. Fayyad -- who is not particularly deferential by nature -- has chosen to be carefully polite to this body and, unlike other ministers, to meet regularly with the committee that oversees him. It is the right thing to do, he says. More to the point, the Parliament could prove a useful tool.
A few days after seeing the security chiefs, he met with the legislative committee privately and named names, telling them which officers were obstructing the reform. Gaza was a small place, he told me at the time, and word would get around.
His allies in Fatah distributed a leaflet asking: "Why do some of the commanders of the security forces still refuse to transfer the salaries of their personnel to bank accounts? Our people should ask this question."
Still, the chiefs would not relent, and so Fayyad went public. One Saturday in April, he met with the Palestinian press and dropped what he hoped would be his devastating bomb: the pledge to rescind the "intifada tax" for all Palestinian Authority employees, once the security chiefs relented.
"My timing was off," Fayyad complained to me a few days later. He had timed his most aggressive move to coincide with the formation by Abbas, the prime minister, of his new cabinet. Fayyad said he thought that the creation of the new government would generate irresistible momentum for his reform.
But Abbas, rather than simply presenting his cabinet to the Parliament, tried to reach a private compromise with Arafat on the very day Fayyad met with the press. Abbas put together a list of ministers that slighted the technocrats sought by reformers and included several old Arafat allies. Spotting weakness, Arafat pounced. He refused to support the cabinet and challenged Abbas to take it to the Legislature. Because it was a compromised list to begin with, reformers had no enthusiasm for it, either. It had no chance.
One result was a 10-day feud that prompted the intervention of more than a dozen foreign governments and swamped any talk of direct deposit. Abbas limped into office facing demands from Israel and the United States that he act immediately to stop all Palestinian violence, but Arafat is still in effective control of much if not most of the authority. Several of the ministers are longtime allies of Arafat, and more than half the security chiefs, including Majaydah, still report to him.
And this is where, for now, the reform hovers, in the same state of unsatisfying equipoise as the Palestinian Authority itself, teetering between Abbas and Arafat.
Like his colleagues, Fayyad is continuing to informally drop in on Arafat for regular chats. But he is also building an alliance with Muhammad Dahlan, the new minister of security, who seems equally interested in cultivating Fayyad. One evening in mid-May, Dahlan's black, armored Chevrolet Suburban pulled up outside Fayyad's ministry for a quiet meeting between the two men. Dahlan is pushing the paycheck reform behind the scenes as he tries to take control from Majaydah and the other chiefs.
Spending time with Fayyad, I often found myself thinking about some Palestinian electrical workers I met a year ago, as Israeli forces were withdrawing from the West Bank city Jenin and its smashed refugee camp. As we talked in their office, above a fire station, we could hear occasional explosions from the camp. 
For the previous 10 days, during the most brutal fighting, these men had put on their orange vests, gotten in their pickup trucks and gone out into streets emptied by Israeli curfew to try to repair the city's electrical grid, which they said soldiers were deliberately damaging. Some of the trucks had been holed by bullets, and the workers had had to scramble beneath them for refuge. These men were functioning on their own, scrounging wiring where they could find it, contacting the World Bank and the Israeli Army directly, sleeping four hours a night. They were not gunmen or soldiers or security officers, just city workers trying to sustain power to people who were trapped in their homes and dependent on their refrigerators, lights, televisions and radios. The chief was an exhausted engineer named Imad Khader, who was born in Jenin and trained in Syria. He proudly pulled out a pink bar graph showing a steady return of power to the city, from a level of dead 0 on April 11 to 72.72 percent on April 17.
I asked him what could possibly have kept him and his men going. His English was not great, and his answer was simple -- and one that Salam Fayyad, and most Palestinians, would subscribe to, I have no doubt. "To save the people," the engineer said, "there must be someone to do the job."

(Heidi Levine); Arafat and Prime Minister Abbas have been Fayyad's allies, or at least not his impediments. (Hussein-Hussein/PPO/Getty Images); The chain-smoking, American-trained Fayyad (in his office): "If you have the authority, use it." (Heidi Levine for The New York Times)
